Consumer complaint narrative:
Formal Dispute of Federal Student Loan Obligation Due to Administrative Transfer To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally dispute the enforceability of my federal student loan agreement on the basis of a **material alteration to the original contract**. 

According to the terms outlined in my promissory note, my loan was issued and administered by the **U.S. Department of Education** . Recent federal action has eliminated or reassigned the Departments responsibilities, with the **Small Business Administration ( SBA ) ** now serving as the managing entity.

This constitutes a **substantial and unilateral alteration of the agreed-upon terms**, materially changing the administrative authority, servicing infrastructure, and potentially the regulatory protections outlined under the original contract. As such, I dispute the continued enforceability of this obligation under its current structure. 

I am requesting that this loan be formally reviewed for discharge, cancellation, or legal reevaluation due to the change in administering agency. Please respond in writing with your position and any available dispute resolution options. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX Account # : XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) XXXX

Issue: Incorrect information on your report
Sub-issue: Information belongs to someone else
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am submitting a formal dispute against Aidvantage for inaccurately reporting my student loan under a name and date of birth that are not mine, in violation of federal consumer protection laws. While I did take out the loan, the account was reported using incorrect personal identifiers that do not match my legal identity. 

This has caused significant damage to my credit, including a XXXX drop in my XXXX XXXX. After I filed my original complaint with the CFPB, Aidvantage responded by stating that they would update the information if I provided a government-issued ID. I did not provide my ID because I am not requesting a correction I am disputing the legitimacy and legality of the account as it currently exists. The loan was reported with false information from the start and must be deleted, not amended. 

Furthermore, XXXX has already removed the incorrect name and date of birth from my credit file, confirming that this data is not associated with me. Aidvantage, however, continues to report the account under those same false identifiers, demonstrating noncompliance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ), which requires all consumer data to be accurate and verifiable.

Aidvantage has failed to conduct a meaningful investigation or resolve the dispute. Instead, they placed the burden on me to fix their reporting error which is not my legal obligation under the FCRA. Their failure to correct or delete this unverifiable account is causing ongoing financial harm and distress. 

I am requesting that the CFPB enforce the law and require Aidvantage to permanently delete this account from all credit reporting agencies, as it is tied to inaccurate and unverified personal information. This matter has gone unresolved for far too long, despite multiple efforts to dispute it properly.

Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Investigation took more than 30 days
Consumer complaint narrative:
Issue Summary : Servicing failure by Maximus Education XXXX ( XXXX Aidvantage ) led to derogatory credit reporting without borrower notification or account access. Despite full repayment and escalation, Ive received no resolution. 

What Happened? 
Aidvantage reported a late payment to the credit bureaus on a XXXX  student loan in my name, even though I, the legal borrower, was never contacted, never granted account access, and never notified of resumed repayment or delinquency. 

I discovered this only after seeing a XXXX point drop in my credit score, which severely impacted my ability to access business credit. Upon discovery, I immediately : -Paid the loan in full -Updated all contact information -Registered for account access ( for the XXXX  time ever ) -Submitted a formal goodwill adjustment request outlining the servicing failures Aidvantage ignored the core facts, sent XXXX canned responses, and never produced any evidence of contacting me, the borrower. Their only defense was that messages were posted to my " inbox, '' a portal I couldnt access because I was never given login credentials or account info. 

Servicing Failures ( All Documented ) : -No repayment notice after COVID forbearance ended ( a requirement under federal loan guidelines ) -No billing statements, emails, or delinquency alerts sent to me, only to my parents, despite being the borrower -No opportunity to cure the alleged delinquency prior to credit reporting ( a possible FCRA violation ) -No login credentials or account access ever provided, I could not monitor or pay this account until after the derogatory mark was made -No evidence ever provided by Aidvantage that communication attempts were made to me Federal Oversight Failure : On XX/XX/year>, I submitted a detailed complaint to the XXXX XXXX XXXX Ombudsman Group . Their auto-reply promised a response within XXXX days. 

I received no response. 

On XX/XX/year>, I submitted a second follow-up directly through the XXXX platform. 

It is now XX/XX/year> over XXXX days later and the case is still marked " In Review '' with no reply. This government silence has left me with no further path to resolution except for this CFPB filing. 

Requested Resolution : I am respectfully asking the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to : -Investigate Aidvantages failure to provide borrower-level communication or account access -Support my request for a Goodwill Adjustment and removal of the derogatory mark from all major credit bureaus -Review the breakdown in oversight and responsiveness from the XXXX XXXX XXXX Ombudsman Group Why This Matters : XXXXI have made every effort in good faith to resolve this without escalation. 

XXXXThe loan was relatively small and has been fully repaid. 

XXXXThe derogatory mark was caused solely by servicer negligence, not borrower behavior. 

XXXXThe late mark caused a XXXX point drop in my XXXX score, destroying XXXX years of perfect credit history. 

XXXXThis has directly damaged my small business, which depends on access to credit. 

XXXXI am not seeking to avoid responsibility only fairness.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Hi, I was enrolled in the SAVE plan in 2023 for my student loans through EdFinancial Services, and because of my current income, my payments were {$0.00} per month. I was told that since my payments were {$0.00}, that I did not have to make a payment and that interest was technically accumulating, but it was being covered by the government. I now checked on my loan website again, and now it says that I owe an additional ~ $ XXXX. I called and they said that if I had made a payment of even {$1.00} per month, that the interest would have been covered, but since it was XXXX, that it was not covered. Consumer complaint narrative:
I was in an XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) plan for almost XXXX years. I consolidated my loans in XX/XX/XXXX to take advantage of the one-time account adjustment and when I consolidated I selected the lowest payment plan which was XXXX. Because of litigation I was automatically placed in a XXXX level repayment plan which I never selected and which isnt XXXX so it wont count towards XXXX. I was initially told I am not not eligible for administrative forbearance because I was never in XXXX XXXX, but that is because of the timing of my application and the only option is for me to keep calling back to extend the forbearance. I also cant enter an XXXX plan even if I want to because there is a processing pause. 
On XX/XX/XXXX a Mohela supervisor extended my forbearance for XXXX year through XX/XX/XXXX so I did not have to call back each month. This helped me avoid making payments on a plan that would not count towards XXXX. I have a recording of this conversation. She also helped me submit a paper application for a new XXXX plan, but said she could not guarantee when this would be processed due to the pause, but in the meanwhile I would be in forbearance so I wouldn't have to worry. I uploaded the paper version of the XXXX application that day. 
Because of my XXXX application, I received a letter from Mohela on XX/XX/XXXX stating that " We recently received your income-driven repayment ( XXXX ) application, but since a federal court issued an injunction preventing the XXXX XXXX XXXX  ( XXXX ) from operating the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) Plan and other XXXX plans, XXXX application processing is taking longer than normal. 
Due to these delays your XXXX application is in a pending status and MOHELA is putting your account into a forbearance for up to XXXX  days. '' My XXXX  application got denied due to a missing signature ( even though a Mohela supervisor looked over my application and told me it was complete ), so after calling and speaking with another supervisor to determine why my XXXX was denied, I submitted a new XXXX application on XX/XX/XXXX with the signature needed. That supervisor explained that if my application is not approved before my next payment date of XX/XX/XXXX, I can call to be placed on processing forbearance. She understood that I did not want to make payments that were not in an XXXX plan because they would not qualify for XXXX. She said the processing forbearance wont be done automatically, but at that point I can call and ask because theyll see the new XXXX application on file. Unfortunately I have been trying to call to ask and can not get through to anyone because of the outrageously long hold times. However, I did receive a letter from Mohela on XX/XX/XXXX ( I will upload ) that said " A federal court issued an injunction preventing the XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) from operating the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) Plan and some other XXXX XXXX  ( XXXX ) plans. As a result of this ruling, XXXX has directed MOHELA to put your account into a forbearance because either : XXXX. You are currently a borrower on XXXX. 
XXXX. XXXX  Days have passed since we received your XXXX application, and it has not yet been processed. '' So again, like last time, I was told my account was in forbearance. Today, on XX/XX/XXXX, my account is saying PAST DUE from XXXX and I have another payment coming up on XX/XX/XXXX. I am worried this will wrongfully affect my credit. Clearly the forbearance was not properly put on my account. I have been trying every day to call for XXXX month, but each time I call the wait time is XXXX hours and I can never get through to a representative. In the past even if I was able to get a hold of an account representative, the first agent I spoke with insisted I had to be transferred. When I get transferred I am just put on hold for hours on end and a supervisor never calls me back, so my account is still wrongfully showed past due. I have called about this issue every day for the past month. The shortest wait time is XXXX hours even during the recommended time to call which is Thursday and Friday from XXXX. I will continue to try to call to resolve this issue, but in the meanwhile I felt this complaint was necessary as Im worried I will soon be reported to collections. Mohela is operating a deflection scheme to avoid resolving the issue and updating my account status.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this formal complaint against my student loan servicer/lender for violations of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) , as well as a serious breach of my personal data and educational records. These violations have resulted in unauthorized disclosure, mishandling, and/or exposure of sensitive information without my knowledge or consent.

Specifically, I have reason to believe that my educational and personally identifiable information ( PII ) protected under FERPA was accessed, disclosed, or compromised in a manner that directly violates federal law. This breach has caused me emotional distress, loss of trust, and potential long-term harm to my financial and personal privacy.

In addition to the FERPA violations, there appears to have been a data breach involving my student loan records, which may have allowed unauthorized third parties to access or misuse my personal information, including my Social Security number, financial data, and educational records.

Due to the severity of these violations, I am formally requesting the following : Immediate discharge and full withdrawal of the student loan associated with the affected account ( s ).

Permanent removal of all related loan data from any consumer credit reports or databases where it has been reported.

A complete audit and written explanation of how my information was handled, disclosed, and/or breached.

Confirmation that all records and data shared or distributed in violation of FERPA have been destroyed or secured. 
These actions are necessary to remediate the violation of my rights and ensure no further harm is done. 

Please consider this an urgent request for CFPB review and enforcement action and assist in ensuring that the responsible parties are held fully accountable for the breach and mishandling of my private data. 

Thank you for your time and support in addressing this serious issue.

Consumer complaint narrative:
STUDENT LOAN / FERPA VIOLATION COMPLAINT TEMPLATE XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXX/XX/year> To : U.S. Department of Education Student Privacy Policy Office XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX : Consumer Finance Subject : Formal Complaint Regarding Data Breach, FERPA and Title IV Violations, and Request for Immediate Discharge of Student Loans Dear CFBD, I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding the unauthorized access and breach of my educational records, financial aid data, and IRS tax information by the U.S.

Department of Education ( DOE ) and the Department of Government Efficiency ( DOGE ). This breach constitutes a direct violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and Title IV regulations, as well as an egregious violation of my personal privacy and financial security.

I recently discovered that my sensitive and legally protected records were accessed and potentially shared without my consent. This includes but is not limited to : 1. My academic records and personally identifiable information ( PII ).

2. My Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) data, including financial aid history and loan information.

3. My IRS tax transcripts, which were obtained and used without proper authorization.

These actions violate my rights under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), which grants me the right to control access to my educational records, as well as Title IV of the Higher Education Act, which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information. Furthermore, unauthorized access to my IRS tax data raises serious concerns regarding potential identity theft, fraud, and violations of federal data security standards.

Given the severity of this breach and the direct impact on my financial security and privacy, I demand the following corrective actions : 1. Immediate discharge and cancellation of all my federal student loans due to the breach of my financial aid and tax records, which invalidates the integrity of my loan agreements.

2. A formal investigation into this data breach, including details on how my records were accessed, who accessed them, and for what purpose.

3. A full report on the extent of my data exposure and the corrective measures being implemented to prevent future violations.

4. Immediate notification to all major credit bureaus ( XXXX XXXX XXXX, and XXXX XXXX ) to place a fraud alert and investigate any unauthorized activity that may have resulted from this breach.

This breach has caused significant distress and concern regarding the security of my personal and financial data. If my demands are not met within 30 days, I will be left with no choice but to escalate this matter through legal channels, including filing complaints with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), and pursuing legal action against the responsible parties.

I request a written response addressing these concerns and outlining the immediate actions being taken to remedy this situation. Please direct all correspondence to the address listed above.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this urgent matter. I look forward to your immediate response and resolution. 


Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am submitting this complaint regarding the federal student loan forgiveness program announced by the XXXX XXXX in XXXX 

I applied for and was approved for up to {$20000.00} in loan forgiveness. Based on official guidance and the repeated extensions of the payment pause, I was led to reasonably believe that my balance would be reduced before repayment resumed. 

Following this official direction, I did not make payments, as federal communication indicated no payments were necessary while forgiveness was pending. However, after the program was overturned by the Supreme Court, no alternative relief or adjustment was provided to borrowers like myself who acted in good faith based on government promises. 

As a result, I am now considered behind on my loans, not because of negligence, but because I trusted the guidance given at the time. I feel this situation is extremely unfair and has caused me financial and emotional stress. It has been a major mental and emotional struggle to even motivate myself to repay now, because it feels fundamentally unjust to be penalized for following what the government instructed me to do. 

I respectfully request that my loan account be restored to good standing without penalties or negative credit reporting. Additionally, due to the false hope provided and the harm caused by being placed into delinquency, I am formally requesting that a meaningful percentage of my loan balance be forgiven as compensation for the damage caused. 

Borrowers who relied on government communications should not be punished. I followed all instructions provided, and I am simply asking for fair treatment based on the promises that were made. Thank you for your urgent review and assistance.

Issue: Incorrect information on your report
Sub-issue: Account status incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally file a complaint against Nelnet concerning the misreporting of my federal student loan account. Despite my timely and full payments, Nelnet has inaccurately reported my account as delinquent to the credit bureaus, resulting in an unjustified and significant drop in my credit score. 

This action is in direct violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S. Code 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ), which stipulates that a furnisher of credit information must not report inaccurate information to a consumer reporting agency. Furthermore, under 15 U.S. Code 1681s-2 ( b ), once a consumer disputes the accuracy of any reported information, the furnisher is legally obligated to conduct a reasonable investigation and promptly correct any inaccuracies found. 

I have made all required loan payments on time and in full, and I have documentation to prove this. Nelnets failure to correct this errordespite my repeated efforts to resolve it directlyconstitutes not only negligence but potential willful noncompliance with federal consumer protection laws. 

I respectfully request that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau investigate this matter and compel Nelnet to : Immediately correct the inaccurate delinquency report with all credit reporting agencies. 

Notify all affected credit bureaus of the correction as required under 15 U.S. Code 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) ( A ). 

Provide written confirmation of the correction and explanation for the initial error. 

The misreporting has already caused material harm to my financial standing, including diminished access to credit and potentially higher interest rates. I seek a full remedy and restoration of my credit profile as it existed prior to this incorrect delinquency report. 

Please let me know if you require any further documentation. I appreciate your attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

My CreditWise report shows multiple entries from DEPT OF ED / NELNET, all listed as 120 days late, with each entry showing different balances. These entries appear to be duplicative or improperly separated by individual loan segments, resulting in multiple negative marks for what appears to be the same or related federal student loan debt.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
Formal Dispute Regarding False Identity Theft Designation and Failure to Investigate CFPB Complaint ID XXXX and XXXX From : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX Account Number XXXX XXXX To : Aidvantage Dispute Resolution Department XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX CC : XXXX, CFPB, FTC Subject : Formal Demand for Investigation and Correction of False Fraud Classification on Student Loan Account To Aidvantage Dispute Resolution Department, This letter serves as a formal dispute and demand for correction regarding your false designation of my student loan account as associated with an identity theft or forgery claim. I did not initiate, authorize, or consent to any identity theft claim or fraud dispute on this account. Your actions have triggered a chain of violations under federal and XXXX consumer protection laws. 
This letter supplements and escalates my previously filed complaints with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau under CFPB Complaint ID XXXX and CFPB Complaint ID XXXX. 
Aidvantages responses dated XX/XX/year>, and XX/XX/year>, both failed to address the core allegations raised in those filings. Instead of conducting a lawful investigation into the unauthorized fraud classification of my account, Aidvantage issued vague, boilerplate responses that ignored my sworn and notarized documentation, misrepresented the source of the alleged fraud designation, and improperly redirected the issue to an unrelated complaint against XXXX. 
These responses collectively reveal a pattern of procedural misconduct and regulatory evasion. 
Breach of Federal Servicing Obligations and Public Trust Standards Aidvantages designation as a federal loan servicer is not a privilege of discretionit is a position of legal obligation. By accepting federal funds, handling federally-backed consumer accounts, and transmitting information to consumer reporting agencies, Aidvantage operates under binding statutory, fiduciary, and commercial standards enforceable by law, irrespective of any federal agency intermediary. 
Aidvantages conduct in this matterfalsely labeling a consumer loan as associated with identity theft, failing to provide investigative records, and misrepresenting the source of the classificationconstitutes a direct breach of the following core obligations : Statutory Compliance : Aidvantage is legally bound to adhere to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), the Consumer Financial Protection Act ( CFPA ), and all federal consumer protection laws governing data accuracy, investigatory integrity, and truthful consumer communication. These are not optional. Violation of these statutes renders the servicer liable under 15 U.S.C. 1681n and 1681o ( willful/negligent noncompliance ), and 12 U.S.C. 5536 ( UDAAP ). 
Fiduciary Duty to the Borrower : Servicers of federal accounts are entrusted with sensitive financial and identity-related data. Misclassifying an account as fraudulent without consent or evidence violates the fundamental duty of care owed to consumers and erodes the trust that underpins all federally-linked servicing relationships. 
Contract-Based Responsibilities : Regardless of whether specific contractual terms are publicly disclosed, any entity entrusted with the management of federally supported debt must act in accordance with implied covenants of good faith and fair dealing. Assigning a fraud designation without basis, ignoring formal rebuttals, and demanding that the consumer write a letter to fix the servicers own misconduct is a textbook breach of commercial servicer conduct. 
Public Trust Accountability : Aidvantage acts as a federal-facing data gatekeeper. It is accountable not just to the borrower, but to the integrity of the public credit infrastructure and consumer reporting ecosystem. Misuse of this role constitutes a material breach of public trust, with potential implications for systemic risk, regulatory scrutiny, and litigation exposure. 
Aidvantages pattern of evasion, misrepresentation, and procedural noncompliance in this case places the company on a collision course with multi-agency enforcement. The breach is not merely technicalit is institutional. 
I. Summary of Violations and Procedural Failures 1. Misclassification Without Authorization You labeled my student loan as part of an identity theft claim without my consent. No identity theft or fraud claim was submitted by me to Aidvantage or XXXX regarding this account. 
2. Failure to Investigate and Provide Evidence You failed to disclose : Who submitted the alleged fraud report Any communication logs showing attempted outreach Any documentation used to support the identity theft designation 3. Improper Burden-Shifting Both your XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX responses instructed me to write a letter to remove the fraud designationdespite the fact that I never initiated it. This is procedurally and legally improper under FCRA 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ), which requires furnishers to correct false information without placing the burden on the consumer. 
4. Misdirection and False Claims to a Federal Agency You repeatedly cited CFPB Complaint ID XXXX ( filed against XXXX ), falsely claiming it triggered your internal fraud process. This is a material misrepresentation to both me and federal regulators. 
5. Failure to Acknowledge Sworn and Notarized Evidence You ignored the Affidavit of Truth and FTC Fraud Report submitted in connection with my disputeboth of which clearly confirm that I never filed an identity theft or fraud-related dispute. Your failure to acknowledge or address these materials violates your duties under the FCRA and CFPA. 
II. Legal and Statutory Violations Federal Law : FCRA 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ) : Furnishing inaccurate information without authorization. 
FCRA 1681i ( a ) ( 6 ) : Failure to provide documentation related to a disputed claim. 
FCRA 1681e ( b ) : Failure to ensure maximum possible accuracy of reported data. 
CFPA 12 U.S.C. 5536 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ) : Unfair, deceptive, and abusive acts ( UDAAP ). 
15 U.S.C. 45 : Unfair and deceptive acts under the FTC Act. 
18 U.S.C. 1001 : False statements or misrepresentations to a federal agency. 
D.C. Law : D.C. CPPA 28-3904 ( e ) : Material misrepresentation of a consumer transaction. 
D.C. CPPA 28-3904 ( f ) : Failure to perform legal duties required by law. 
III. Formal Legal Demands Aidvantage is required to take the following actions within 30 business days : 1. Remove the Fraud Designation You must provide written confirmation that all fraud-related classifications on my student loan account have been permanently removed. 
2. Confirm No Adverse Credit Reporting If you reported this fraud code to any CRAs, you must provide documentation that it has been corrected and no longer appears in my file. 
3. Disclose the Investigation Record Provide the full internal investigation record, including : Name of the individual or system that initiated the fraud designation Any internal correspondence Any documentation provided to XXXX 4. Explain Why CFPB Complaint ID XXXX and XXXX Was Not Addressed Provide a direct written explanation as to why your responses failed to address my core allegations in the original CFPB complaint. 
IV. Notice of Escalation if Aidvantage Fails to Comply If you do not take immediate corrective action, I will escalate this matter to the following agencies for formal investigation and enforcement : Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) : As the primary regulatory authority for FCRA and UDAAP violations, the CFPB is responsible for enforcing 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2, 1681i, and 12 U.S.C. 5536 where furnishers misreport, mishandle disputes, or shift legal burdens onto consumers. 
Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) : The FTC enforces prohibitions against unfair and deceptive business practices under 15 U.S.C. 45. Aidvantages misrepresentation of complaint origins and failure to investigate constitute actionable deception and fraud. 
Federal Communications Commission ( FCC ) : The FCC oversees electronic and mailed communications that involve deceptive representations or the simulation of legal or regulatory process. Misuse of identity theft packets and false claims of consumer outreach fall under its jurisdiction. 
National Association of Attorneys General ( NAAG ) : State Attorneys General may coordinate multistate enforcement where violations of state consumer protection lawssuch as D.C. CPPA 28-3904 ( e ) and ( f ) suggest a broader pattern of systemic harm across jurisdictions. 
U.S. Department of Justice ( DOJ ) Civil and Criminal Divisions : Aidvantages materially false statements to a federal agency, along with the use of mail or electronic communication to support a false fraud classification, may trigger liability under 18 U.S.C. 1001, 1341 and 1343, and 18 U.S.C. 19611968 ( RICO ). 
DOJ Consumer Protection Branch ( CPB ) : The CPB has jurisdiction over enterprise-level consumer fraud and systemic FCRA violations . Aidvantages pattern of misclassification, evasion, and misdirection meets the threshold for CPB referral due to its obstruction of lawful dispute processes and regulatory oversight. 
V. Attached Documentation The following supporting documents are enclosed : Affidavit of Truth ( Sworn and Notarized ) Legal certification of my position and dispute history. 
FTC Fraud Report ID XXXX Confirming no identity theft dispute was submitted on this account. 
FTC Fraud Report ID XXXX Documents false identity theft classification by Aidvantage and XXXX and confirms no fraud dispute was ever submitted by the consumer. 
CFPB Complaint ID XXXX ( CLOSED ) Irrelevant XXXX complaint misused in Aidvantages response XXXX 
CFPB Complaint ID XXXX ( CLOSED ) Core complaint ignored in Aidvantages prior response. 
CFPB Complaint ID XXXX ( CLOSED ) Rebuttal to Aidvantages Misclassification and Failure to Address CFPB Complaint ID XXXX VI. Final Notice to Aidvantage Aidvantage is now on formal notice. You are required to immediately correct this false identity theft designation, produce all investigative and internal records as outlined above, and issue a legally sufficient resolution within 30 business days of receipt of this notice. 
Failure to comply will be treated as willful, ongoing statutory noncompliance, triggering immediate escalation to federal and state enforcement bodies, referral to oversight agencies listed herein, and the pursuit of all available civil and legal remedies under applicable law. 
All correspondence, internal communications, and investigative documentation related to this matter will be treated as subject to subpoena, discovery, and FOIA/public records review in any subsequent regulatory action, litigation, or oversight proceeding. 
This record is now active. No further warnings will be issued. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

I am writing to formally continue my dispute the delinquency reported on my student loan account dated XX/XX/year>, and to raise serious concerns regarding mishandling of my Income-Driven Repayment ( IDR ) and Public Service Loan Forgiveness ( PSLF ) applications currently in process. 

Summary of Issue : I submitted IDR and PSLF applications on XX/XX/year>, via StudentAid.gov. 

As of today, my XXXX XXXX confirms PSLF approval, showing XXXX out of XXXX qualifying payments. 

On XX/XX/year>, I spoke with EdFinancial rep XXXX, who confirmed my loans are on temporary hold until XX/XX/year>, due to the IDR application. They were very reluctant to help, refusing to transfer my call to his supervisor and refused to give me his name. When requested he stated no for both, lacking transparency. It wasn't until he could no longer provide relevant information I requested that he granted my transfer to his supervisor. 

He informed me the delinquency would be reversed and my account would be reported as current by XX/XX/year> due to my pending IDR application A supervisor, XXXX, confirmed retroactive payment adjustments and provided a timeline of prior contact attempts many of which I never received. 

I have already filed disputes with XXXX XXXX XXXX and submitted My first complaint to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ). 

This now the issue I am having with EdFinicial : PSLF Concerns : During the call, XXXX pushed me to consolidate my loans, despite the fact that doing so would cause me to lose all XXXX qualifying PSLF payments already recorded. He also insisted that they, EdFinicial, would still be my loan servicers. This was deeply concerning, especially since XXXX is the designated servicer for PSLF, and my loans have not yet been transferred from EdFinancial. 

Violations and Legal Basis : Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), data furnishers like EdFinancial must report accurate and timely information. Reporting me delinquent while in active repayment plan review appears to violate this principle. They are waiting over a week, despite being current as of today. 

Under the Higher Education Act ( HEA ), borrowers in the process of applying for an income-driven plan should not be penalized with negative credit marks or be given misleading servicing advice that jeopardizes PSLF eligibility.

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Problem with forgiveness, cancellation, or discharge
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Complaint Regarding Outstanding Federal Student Loans from XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX University Dear Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, I hope this letter finds you well. I am writing to formally file a complaint concerning my federal student loans associated with both XXXX XXXX ( XXXX  ) and XXXX XXXX University ( XXXX ), which are still showing outstanding balances despite the recent announcements about loan forgiveness under the borrower defense to repayment regulations. 

In XX/XX/XXXX, the U.S. Department of Education announced it would forgive {$71.00} XXXX in federal student loan debt, holding XXXX liable for {$24.00} XXXX. This decision was based on the recognition of deceptive practices that misled students about the value of their degrees and the quality of education provided. Furthermore, XXXX has faced similar scrutiny due to its recruitment tactics and promises that were not fulfilled, leading many graduates, including myself, to seek relief through the same borrower defense process. 

As a borrower who attended both XXXX and XXXX, I was hopeful that my loans would be included in this forgiveness initiative. However, upon reviewing my loan status, I found that my balances remain unchanged, which has caused substantial financial and emotional distress. This situation is further exacerbated by my repeated attempts to contact my loan servicer, where I have received inadequate responses and no clear guidance on how to address my concerns. Also, I received communications stating the discharge of loans if the lawsuit was successful. So far, I have not received the dismal from the account balance. 

Not only do I find it frustrating to witness the federal government 's acknowledgment of wrongdoing by these institutions, but I am also deeply troubled that my loans do not reflect this action. The lingering balances are a constant reminder of the financial burden I believed would be alleviated. 

Given this context, I respectfully request your assistance in resolving this matter. Borrowers like me must receive timely and accurate information regarding our rights under the borrower defense to repayment regulations. Additionally, I urge the CFPB to take action to ensure that loan services adhere to federal directives and correctly process the discharge of loans for affected students from both XXXX  and XXXX without unnecessary delays. 

Also, I would like to bring to the attention potential violations of laws that XXXX have occurred at XXXX University and XXXX XXXX University ( XXXX ) regarding their marketing practices and the educational services they provide to students, which include : Under the Higher Education Act of 1965 ( HEA ), schools are required to adhere to specific regulations that ensure transparency and fairness in their student recruitment practices. The " XXXX XXXX to Repayment ( BDR ) '' provision, established under the HEA, protects borrowers from institutions that mislead them about their programs or the value of their degrees. Students who have been misled or those who suffered financial harm as a result are eligible to seek relief under this law. 

Additionally, the specific regulations defined in 34 CFR 685.206 outline the BDR process and the criteria for eligibility. XXXX and XXXX made false representations about their programs, services, and job placement rates, students have valid claims for loan forgiveness based on these regulations. 

Furthermore, the " Federal Student Aid ( FSA ) Guidelines '' issued by the U.S. Department of Education stipulate that educational institutions must provide clear and accurate information regarding their programs. Any misrepresentations could be grounds for students to pursue claims under the BDR provisions.

Moreover, various " consumer protection laws '' at both the federal and state levels protect students from deceptive practices. These laws require educational institutions to be forthright in their marketing and communications. If either XXXX or XXXX misrepresented critical aspects of their educational offerings, they were held accountable under these laws. 

I urge the appropriate regulatory bodies to thoroughly investigate these matters to ensure that students who have been affected are granted the relief they deserve. 

Thank you for your attention to this pressing matter. I look forward to your prompt response and any guidance you can provide to help rectify this situation.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to express serious concerns about a recent situation involving my student loans serviced by Nelnet. Since the XXXX loan deferment period, I had been consistently making payments on my Parent PLUS loans, believing that I was current and in good standing. At no point did I receive any communication from Nelnetvia phone, physical mail, or emailindicating that another loan under my name had become delinquent. 

Instead, Nelnet sent email communications regarding the outstanding balance to my father. Upon receiving XXXX such message, he contacted Nelnet and referenced the account number provided in the email, but was informed that Nelnet had no record of that account number. This further contributed to our confusion and concern. 

On XX/XX/year>, while preparing to purchase a new vehicle for my growing family ( with a baby due in early XXXX ), I checked my credit report and was shocked to find that my credit score had plummeted from XXXX to XXXX since XXXX. Fearing identity theft, I ordered a full credit report, only to discover XXXX delinquencies reported by Nelnet totaling approximately {$39000.00}. 

When I called Nelnet for clarification, I was met with indifference. I was told to simply create an online account and begin paying the delinquent balance. When I inquired why I was never contacted directlyby phone, physical mail, or through my own email addressI was told, We sent an email ; we did our part. When I explained that these emails were not sent to me, the representative essentially shrugged it off. 

This situation has had a severe and immediate impact on my financial wellbeing and ability to support my family. I believe this lack of communication and refusal to take accountability is negligent and potentially unlawful.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I've already filed a complaint. They incorrectly responded with a very blatant automatic response. The " evidence '' they presented has numerous problems. I will re-submit my response to this as a new complaint here : I have reviewed Aidvantage 's response to my complaint XXXX, including the attached document XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
While I acknowledge they received my XXXX  request XXXX their response remains inadequate and does not resolve my complaint for the following reasons : Failure to Respond Correctly to Debt Validation : While Aidvantage has now attached a document to this complaint response, they failed to provide any validation or response directly to my debt validation letter, sent via certified mail on XX/XX/year>, within the timeframe required by law. Improper Collection Activity : Despite receiving my validation request, Aidvantage continued collection activities by sending a bill statement dated XX/XX/year>. This action occurred after they received my validation letter but before providing the legally required validation in response to that letter. This appears to be a violation of the FDCPA, which requires ceasing collection attempts until validation is provided after a timely request. 
Inadequate Validation Document : The document provided with the complaint response was not sent in direct response to my formal validation letter as required. Furthermore, this document alone may not constitute sufficient validation, which typically requires a more detailed accounting of the debt. 
Failure to Address the Core Issue : Aidvantage 's response neglects to address the central issue : their failure to cease collection and provide timely validation in response to my original certified letter, and the potentially unlawful collection activity ( the XX/XX/XXXX bill ) that occurred as a result. Attaching a document later to a regulatory complaint does not retroactively cure the initial failure to comply with the FDCPA upon receiving the direct request. Therefore, their response is unacceptable. I reiterate my request that Aidvantage cease all collection activity until proper and complete validation of the debt is provided correctly according to legal requirements. I also request an investigation into the collection activities following my XX/XX/XXXX letter and the correction of any related negative information on my credit report.

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX, MO, XXXX XXXX XXXX Nelnet Attn : Claims Loan Discharge or Forgiveness Claims XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX Subject : Urgent FERPA Violation Dispute Unauthorized Access & Deletion of Student Loan Data Dear Nelnet, I am formally disputing the unauthorized access and deletion of my student loan data as reported in the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX " XXXX and FERPA : Did Doge Breach Student Loan Contracts? '' ( XX/XX/year> ). The report raises alarming concerns regarding potential violations of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) due to unauthorized access and tampering with student loan records.

As a borrower with active student loan obligations, I am highly concerned that my rights under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ) have been violated. Unauthorized deletion or modification of my education records is strictly prohibited under federal law. These reported actions have severely impacted my financial and educational standing, and I demand immediate corrective measures. I am formally requesting the following actions : 1. Immediate Investigation A full audit into whether my records were accessed, altered, or deleted without my consent.

2. Full Disclosure A comprehensive list of entities or individuals involved in accessing, modifying, or deleting my records.

3. Restoration & Rectification Immediate correction of any unauthorized deletions, accompanied by a written statement confirming all corrective actions taken.

4. Future Compliance Assurance A formal, written confirmation that my student loan records will remain fully protected under FERPA and that no further unauthorized access or modifications will occur.

I expect a written response within 30 days from the date of this letter, detailing the steps taken to address this matter. If my concerns are not properly addressed, I will escalate this issue by filing a formal complaint with the U.S. Department of Educations Family Policy Compliance Office ( FPCO ) and explore legal remedies. 
Please contact me at XXXX or XXXX with updates. I trust that you will handle this matter with the urgency it demands. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

However, despite my repeated efforts, no one has responded to my requests, provided any support, or honored this commitment. Since graduating, I have struggled to find employment in my field, and the jobs I have been working at do not align with my degrees pay grade. The lack of response from my schools job placement team and recruiters they claimed would contact me has made it incredibly difficult to secure a career that matches my education. This has caused me significant hardship, and I feel deeply misled by the false promises made to me when I enrolled. 



This situation is unacceptable, and I am formally requesting that my student loans be discharged immediately due to the schools failure to uphold their obligations. I urge you to process my claim as soon as possible, as this has had a severe financial and emotional impact on me. 



Please confirm the next steps in my claim process. If necessary, I am prepared to escalate this matter with the XXXX Department of Education and other consumer protection agencies. I appreciate your prompt attention to this matter.

Issue: Improper use of your report
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am submitting this formal complaint to bring to your attention a serious violation of my consumer rights and data privacy committed by Navient, a federal student loan servicer. 

It has come to my attention that Navient has shared, disclosed, or otherwise permitted access to my personal, financial, or sensitive information without my informed consent or authorization. This action is unacceptable and unlawful under several federal statutes designed to protect consumers personal data. 

Specifically, Navients conduct violates the following laws and regulations : Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ( GLBA ), 15 U.S.C. XXXX This act requires financial institutions to explain their information-sharing practices and to safeguard sensitive data. There is no record of Navient providing me with proper disclosure nor obtaining my consent prior to the dissemination of my private information. 

Privacy Act of 1974, 5 U.S.C. 552a This act strictly limits the sharing of personal data maintained by federal agencies or their contractors ( including student loan servicers ) without written consent or statutory authorization. 

Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq. Under this law, consumer information may only be shared for permissible purposes with clear and specific consumer authorization. 

Navients unauthorized disclosure of my private information has not only breached these laws but has also placed me at risk of financial harm, fraud, and invasion of privacy. As a responsible borrower actively working to improve and repair my credit standing, this type of negligent behavior undermines my financial security and erodes trust in the federal loan servicing system. 

Demand for Immediate Resolution I hereby request the following corrective actions : A full and formal investigation into Navients unlawful disclosure of my personal data.

Immediate written confirmation detailing when, to whom, and for what purpose my information was shared.

Immediate cessation of all unauthorized data-sharing practices related to my account. 

A written assurance of compliance with all applicable privacy laws going forward. 

Any available compensation, protections, or corrective actions under the law to remedy this violation. 

Please consider this letter a formal complaint and request for action under applicable federal privacy protections. I also reserve the right to escalate this matter to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), and any other regulatory authority if this issue is not resolved in a timely and satisfactory manner.

My student loan is serviced by XXXX XXXX XXXX It is a Consolidation Loan, standard repayment plan, XXXX XXXX, and the lender name XXXX. I was told that the date of the original terms had passed and now I needed to adjust to a new payment amount, over double the previous amount. The payment was due immediately. 

I just received an email today, XX/XX/XXXX, stating that my monthly payment is {$500.00}. Again I received no warning and no explanation for this substantial increase. The payment is due, in full, tomorrow. 

This can not be a fair business practice and if it happening to me, I can be sure that I am not the only one. If there are to be substantial increases in payments, there needs to be notifications and sufficient explanations with clear guidance for the customer.

Nature of Complaint : Unauthorized access to loan and personal information Violations of privacy and data security Wrongful denial of loan discharge due to privacy violations Other : Unauthorized access by XXXX XXXX and associated parties 2. Description of the Issue : I am filing this complaint due to the unauthorized access and potential misuse of my student loan and personal information by individuals, including XXXX XXXX, through the Department of Government Efficiency ( DOGE ). This data breach compromises my right to privacy under the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and Title IV regulations. 
In XX/XX/year>, multiple reports emerged indicating that XXXX XXXX and associated parties accessed sensitive student loan data without authorization. Legal actions have been initiated by unions and educational organizations to address this egregious violation of privacy. For example : The American Federation of Teachers filed a federal lawsuit alleging an unprecedented and illegal hack of private data. 
The University of California XXXX XXXX filed a lawsuit against the Department of Education for sharing the personal financial data of millions of student loan borrowers with XXXX XXXX and unauthorized entities. 
Lawmakers are actively investigating the Department of Government Efficiency 's access to internal systems containing the personal information of tens of millions of Americans. 
These unauthorized actions raise significant concerns regarding potential identity theft, fraud, and violations of federal data security standards. Due to the severity of this breach and its direct impact on my financial security and privacy, I am demanding the immediate discharge and cancellation of my federal student loans. 
I am also requesting a thorough investigation to determine how my records were accessed and who was responsible for this breach. Immediate measures should be taken to safeguard my information and ensure that similar violations do not occur in the future. 

3. Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/year>, XXXX XXXX instructed his team of XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX to gain access to multiple internal systems within the Department of Education, including financial aid dataset that contains the personal information of millions of students enrolled in the federal student aid program. My information was among that dataset that has been compromised. I have been forced into forbearance for the last several months without access and cohesive communication, intentionally misleading information, inaccessible support structure to remedy this. I have chosen a career based on the agreement for pslf and loan structure, and the loan servicer and department of education, federal government are violating agreement and conducting business in a way that is intentionally corrupt, misleading, fraudulent. Moreover, my previous servicer pushed the SAVE program on me, and I signed up for it with their advice and pressure. Investigation and restitution is asked as it regards the dept of education, mohela, nelnet, and aid advantage. Further, my information has been violated and unauthorized access and breach of my educational records, financial aid data, and IRS tax information by the U.S. Department of Education ( DOE ) and the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ). This breach constitutes a direct violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and Title IV regulations, as well as an egregious violation of my personal privacy and financial security. 
I recently discovered that my sensitive and legally protected records were accessed and potentially shared without my consent. This includes but is not limited to : 1. My academic records and personally identifiable information ( PII ). 
2. My Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) data, including financial aid history and loan information. 
XXXX. My IRS tax transcripts, which were obtained and used without proper authorization. 
These actions violate my rights under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), which grants me the right to control access to my educational records, as well as Title IV of the Higher Education Act, which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information. Furthermore, unauthorized access to my IRS tax data raises serious concerns regarding potential identity theft, fraud, and violations of federal data security standards. 
Given the severity of this breach and the direct impact on my financial security and privacy, I demand the following corrective actions : 1. Immediate discharge and cancellation of all my federal student loans due to the breach of my financial aid and tax records, which invalidates the integrity of my loan agreements. 
2. A formal investigation into this data breach, including details on how my records were accessed, who accessed them, and for what purpose.

3. A full report on the extent of my data exposure and the corrective measures being implemented to prevent future violations. 
4. Immediate notification to all major credit bureaus ( XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX XXXX ) to place a fraud alert and investigate any unauthorized activity that may have resulted from this breach. 
This breach has caused significant distress and concern regarding the security of my personal and financial data. If my demands are not met within 30 days, I will be left with no choice but to escalate this matter through legal channels, including filing complaints with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), and pursuing legal action against the responsible parties. 
I request a written response addressing these concerns and outlining the immediate actions being taken to remedy this situation. Please direct all correspondence to the address listed above. 
Thank you for your prompt attention to this urgent matter. I look forward to your immediate response and resolution. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Problem with forgiveness, cancellation, or discharge
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX, my federal student loan servicer, Nelnet, improperly shared or disclosed my private student loan information with an entity known as the Department of Government Efficiency ( DOGE ). This group is not a recognized federal agency, nor was I informed or asked for consent prior to the disclosure. This appears to be a direct violation of the Privacy Act of 1974 and FERPA ( Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ). 

I filed a previous complaint on XX/XX/XXXX, but Nelnet responded with a generic explanation that ignored the core issue : why and how my records were disclosed to an unauthorized third party. My complaint was prematurely closed despite Nelnet failing to address or acknowledge this breach. 

This unauthorized access has compromised my personal financial data and has put my identity and loan status at risk. I am now seeking : 1. A formal investigation into Nelnets handling of my private student loan data.

2. Written clarification on any authority or legal basis used to release this information.

3. Immediate evaluation for full student loan discharge due to the privacy violation.

4. Enforcement action to ensure that my rights under federal law are upheld.

I have also submitted complaints to the U.S. Department of Education and Office for Civil Rights, and am requesting that this issue be escalated beyond the initial level due to its legal and personal implications.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
The only option that were offered were to either put, my loans into forbearance or deferment. While these were accessible early on as a payment option, interest on each loan continued to accumulate, which placed me in a difficult position when payments resumed. If I lowered my monthly payments, the interest alone would negate any payments made and would continue accumulate and extending the time needed to payoff the total amount owed. If that were to happen it would inevitably increase the total interest per loan over time, snowballing into a greater total sum. 

After XXXX years of making payments on a {$16000.00} loan ( XXXX subsidized & XXXX unsubsidized ) from XX/XX/XXXX to XXXX, I still have a balance of {$15000.00} and I see no way of paying this off by estimated payoff date of XXXX. If I were to increase monthly payments, I would not be able to afford my bills, day to day necessities, food, and transportation to and from work. All available options offered to me would extend the period of time needed to payoff the loans and increase the amounts necessary to pay it off. 

Many student loans borrowers, including myself, do not qualified for Public Service Loan Forgiveness ( PSLF ) or Teacher Loan Forgiveness ( TLF ). We took on these loans at a young age, assuming that by graduation we would have secured jobs that could support both student debt repayment and basic living expenses. However, I feel mislead by loan servicers due to lack of information provided about compounding interest, inflation, and stagnant wages all of which make monthly repayment an unrealistic expectation. 

These financial hardships are not only limited to public servants. Today 's economy is made up of, but not limited to contract works, freelancers, and home aides all of whom contribute significantly to society. While I fully support loan forgiveness for public servants, I also believe that this benefit should be offered to those who do not qualify under ( PSLF or TLF ). Millions of borrowers across various professions are buried under unmanageable student debt and continue to struggle financially not because of irresponsibility, but because they were denied a chance at financial stability simply due to not having the right job title.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally explain the circumstances surrounding my student loan debt, which I believe qualifies for discharge or removal from my credit due to the nature of the institution involved.

My personal information was compromised, and I was informed that I may be eligible to apply for a program that can help remove my student loans from my credit report. These loans are directly tied to my time at XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, a school that is now permanently closed. 

The closure of this campus, and the school as a whole, stemmed from a lawsuit filed by former students. These individuals, like myself, were unable to secure employment after graduating or found that their credits would not transfer to other institutionsleaving them in a position of having paid for an education that ultimately held little to no value. The lawsuit highlighted the misleading and fraudulent practices carried out by the institution, which led to significant student debt with no return on investment.

I firmly believe that being forced to bear the burden of this debt is unjust and financially damaging, especially considering the schools closure was due to verified misconduct and misrepresentation. These loans continue to affect my credit, making it harder for me to move forward financially and professionally.

I respectfully request that my situation be reviewed for loan discharge or credit removal under any applicable borrower defense or similar relief program.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
In XX/XX/XXXX ( CFPB ID : XXXX ) I asked why my SAVE application was not processed AND/OR PLACED IN FORBEARANCE WITH NO INTEREST ACCRUAL. On XX/XX/XXXX - the company replied with the following : Thank you for reaching out to the CFPB with your concerns regarding your federal student loan account. We understand you are concerned that your newly consolidated loan has not been enrolled in the SAVE plan. You also stated that when you contacted Aidvantage we were unable to advise why the loan hasnt been enrolled in the plan. However, our records show that when you called Aidvantage on XX/XX/XXXX you were correctly advised that due to a Federal court issued injunction the U.S. Department of Education is prevented from implementing parts of the SAVE Plan and other IDR Plans. As advised on XX/XX/XXXX, we are unable to process the plan due to the court injunction. Youre welcome to call us at XXXX, with any questions you may have concerning this issueXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Given the updates made by the government, my application should have been placed on forbearance until new recertification amounts could have been made, which is what I stated in my previous complaint XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  ; I believe Aidvantage intentionally did not place me in forbearance ( with no interest accrual after 60 days ), and am requesting for them to now follow up on the application that I submitted back in XX/XX/XXXX, to place me in general forbearance with no interest accrual. It has been over 60 days with interest accruing, and the SAVE application should now be in forbearance since I applied and it was never processed. The government states : As of XX/XX/XXXX, borrowers may apply for the following IDR plans : Pay As You Earn ( PAYE ), SAVE ( previously known as REPAYE ), Income-Based Repayment ( IBR ), and Income-Contingent Repayment ( ICR ), if borrowers meet any plan specific eligibility requirements.. For borrowers who would prefer to make payments during this time -- such as borrowers pursuing PSLF or low-income borrowers who would owe no monthly payments -- enrolling in PAYE or ICR may be an option to consider. Borrowers are still permitted to apply for the SAVE plan ( previously known as REPAYE ), even though the court has enjoined some of the SAVE and other IDR plan provisions, including forgiveness. The Department is working with servicers and contractors to update their systems to align with the terms of the SAVE plan, based on the terms of the injunction. This process will take several months. Ultimately, the terms of the SAVE Plan and other IDR plans are subject to the outcome of ongoing litigation. If servicers need time to process a borrowers IDR application, servicers will move the borrower into a processing forbearance for up to 60 days. Interest accrues during this short-term processing forbearance, and time in the processing forbearance that does provide IDR and PSLF credit. If the borrowers application is not processed by their servicer within 60 days, the borrower will be moved into a general forbearance that does not count toward PSLF or IDR until their application is processed. Interest will not accrue in this general forbearance. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  This was supposedly " resolved '' by the company in my last CFPB complaint - but I recently received a notification stating my account is being removed from forbearance ( 0 % interest and no payments until more information is available ) effective XX/XX/XXXX - even though forbearance has largely been extended to all SAVE applicants and enrollees due to the current changes made by the administration.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX Previously XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
XXXX, Ca XXXX XXXX XXXX XX/XX/year> To Whom It May Concern : Subject : Formal Dispute of Unauthorized Access and Use of Personal Data FCRA 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) I am writing to formally dispute unauthorized access to and use of my personally identifiable information ( PII ) related to my student loans. This communication is filed in accordance with Section 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), which provides consumers the right to dispute information in their file that is incomplete or inaccurate.

It has come to my attention that an entity identified as DOGE accessed my private data, including but not limited to my name, Social Security number, financial data, and student loan information, through the U.S. Department of Education ( DOE ) without my knowledge or consent. This access appears to have resulted in unauthorized use, sharing, or modification of my student loan information.

Key points of my dispute : 1. I did not authorize DOGE or any affiliated entity to access or utilize my data held by the DOE.

2. No prior notification, consent, or legal disclosure was provided to me regarding this access or data sharing.

3. This potential data breach raises serious concerns regarding compliance with priva

cy regulations, FERPA, and consumer protection statutes. 4. I am requesting a full investigation and immediate correction of any related records that may have resulted
in inaccurate reporting, unauthorized servicing, or erroneous debt assignment.

Requested Actions : Initiate a formal investigation into this unauthorized access and use of my information.

Provide documentation verifying the legal basis upon which DOGE accessed my DOE records.

Remove or correct any inaccuracies or unauthorized activity from my credit file and/or loan servicing record.

Suspend any debt collection or loan-related activity connected to this unauthorized access until the investigation is complete.

Please treat this as a formal dispute and a demand for correction under FCRA 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ). If this matter also involves a potential breach of data security, I request your agencies coordinate with the Department of Educations Office of the Chief Privacy Officer and relevant cybersecurity authorities. 
Attached are copies of my identification, supporting documentation, and any relevant loan account records for your reference. 
I appreciate your immediate attention to this serious matter. Please confirm receipt of this letter and provide a written response within the time frame required by law. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Despite contacting the company and requesting an investigation, verification of the loan, and resolution, the servicer continues to pursue collection without addressing my formal dispute.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Re : Immediate Cease & Desist of Student Loan Reporting and Collection Due to Department of Education Abolishment To Whom It May Concern, I am disputing the legitimacy and enforceability of the student loans associated with my account. As you are aware, President Trump has signed an executive order to abolish the U.S. Department of Education, thereby creating a material legal void concerning all student loan obligations previously managed under its authority. 

# # # Demand for Verification & Cease and Desist Pursuant to 15 U.S.C. 1692g ( FDCPA ) and 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( FCRA ), I am requesting immediate verification of the legal ownership, servicing rights, and validity of the alleged student loan debt under your authority. Failure to provide this information within 30 days constitutes a direct violation of federal law. 
Furthermore, under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) and FCRA, I am demanding the following : - Immediate cessation of collection efforts until full legal verification is Provided. 

- A detailed breakdown of loan ownership and servicing rights post-Department of Education abolishment.

- Written confirmation that you will cease reporting this unverified debt to credit bureaus. 

If you fail to comply, I will escalate this matter to the CFPB, FTC, and pursue legal action for violations of my consumer rights.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Don't agree with the fees charged
Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/XXXX Subject : Final Notice of Noncompliance with Cease & Desist, Demand to XXXX XXXX  Account, and Restitution of All Interest Paid To Whom It May Concern, This letter serves as a formal notice of Aidvantages continued violations of federal law, including but not limited to, the Truth in Lending Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1601 et seq. ), the Fair Credit Billing Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1666b ), the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1692 et seq. ), the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ( b ) ), and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ( 15 U.S.C. 78a et seq. ), arising from your failure to cease all communication and collection attempts regarding an alleged debt for which Aidvantage is not the original creditor or holder in due course. 

1. Failure to Provide Verification of Debt Upon written request, the alleged servicer must provide the original promissory note with all wet-ink endorsements and assignments in compliance with the Uniform Commercial Code ( UCC ) Article 3. Aidvantage has failed to produce such verification and, as such, has no lawful standing to report, collect, or otherwise engage in any enforcement action against me. 

2. Failure to Comply with Cease & Desist Order Pursuant to the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), Aidvantage has been explicitly instructed in writing to cease all communications regarding this matter. Any further attempt to contact me, report adverse information, or collect on this unverified account constitutes continued willful noncompliance and harassment under federal law and is subject to legal recourse. 

3. Failure to Report Account as Disputed & Unlawful Credit Reporting Under 15 U.S.C. 1666b, Aidvantage was required to report this account as disputed while under review. Instead, you falsely and maliciously reported it as late, causing irreparable harm. Any negative reporting while an account remains in dispute constitutes a willful violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( b ) ), opening the door for substantial legal liability. 

4. FERPA Violations and Unauthorized Disclosure of Non-Public Information Under 20 U.S.C. 1232g ( b ), financial records linked to educational loans fall under the protection of FERPA. Any transfer, servicing, or assignment of this alleged account without my explicit consent constitutes a breach of privacy rights under federal law. 

5. Securities Fraud & Unlawful Securitization If this alleged debt has been securitized and transferred through financial instruments without full disclosure and proper accounting under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ( 15 U.S.C. 78a et seq. ), Aidvantage is then complicit in an unlawful scheme to deceptively trade student loan instruments in violation of SEC regulations. 

Demand for Immediate Corrective Action In light of the above statutory violations, fraudulent misrepresentations, and failure to lawfully validate the alleged debt, I hereby demand the following corrective actions be completed within fifteen ( 15 ) calendar days of receipt of this notice : 1. Immediate discharge and XXXX XXXX  of the account due to failure to produce the original promissory note and lack of standing to collect. 

2. Complete removal of all adverse credit reporting related to this disputed account across all credit bureaus. 

3. Refund and restitution of all interest paid on the alleged debt, as it was collected under fraudulent pretenses without full disclosure and lawful standing. 

4. Written confirmation of compliance with the above demands to be sent via certified mail. 

Failure to comply within the stated time frame will result in immediate escalation, including formal complaints to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), Securities and Exchange Commission ( SEC ), and initiation of civil litigation for damages, statutory penalties, and injunctive relief. 

This letter serves as legal notice under federal law. Any further adverse action taken against me without full compliance will be deemed an intentional violation of my rights and will be met with the appropriate legal response. 

This matter is time-sensitive. Govern yourselves accordingly. 


Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to report a significant and deeply concerning breach of my personal data related to my student loan records. It has come to my attention that my federally protected personal information was accessed by, shared with, or otherwise disclosed to XXXX XXXX or entities under his control, without my consent or knowledge.

This unauthorized access violates multiple federal laws and protections : The Privacy Act of 1974 ( 5 U.S.C. 552a ) This law prohibits federal agencies from disclosing personal information without written consent, except under specific, lawful exceptions. My student loan informationmaintained by the U.S. Department of Education or its servicersshould have been safeguarded under this law. Any unauthorized sharing of my data constitutes a direct violation.

The Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ) FERPA protects the privacy of student education records and prohibits disclosure without student consent, including financial aid and loan data when administered by educational institutions or federal programs. This breach appears to contravene FERPAs strict data handling policies.

The Federal Trade Commission Act ( 15 U.S.C. 4158 ) Under Section 5, the FTC prohibits unfair or deceptive acts or practices, including those involving misuse or unauthorized disclosure of consumer data. The disclosure of my private loan information without permission, especially to a non-governmental individual or company, may be an unfair practice and subject to FTC enforcement.

Department of Education Data Governance and Sharing Regulations Under federal student aid regulations, third-party access to loan data must be strictly controlled and logged. Unless expressly authorized or contractually bound to the Department of Education, no external entityespecially not a private corporate actor such as XXXX XXXXshould

be permitted access to my loan or personal records. This disclosure indicates a failure in oversight or a breach of the Departments regulatory framework.

Given the seriousness of these violations, I am requesting the following actions : A formal investigation into how my information was accessed, who authorized it, and for what purpose.

Immediate remedial action to secure and restrict further access to my personal data.

Written confirmation of how my rights were violated under the laws listed above.

Consideration of full loan cancellation or discharge, as restitution for the breach, loss of trust, and potential harm to my identity and financial wellbeing.

I have also submitted complaints to the Federal Student Aid Feedback Center, the Federal Trade Commission, and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. I reserve the right to pursue further legal or civil remedies should this matter not be addressed promptly and appropriately.

Please confirm receipt of this complaint and advise me of the steps your office will take in response. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX
