Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom It May Concern, am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding the unauthorized access and breach of my educational records, financial aid data, and IRS tax information by the U.S.Department of Education ( DOE ) and the Department of Governmental Entities ( DOGE ). This breach constitutes a direct violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and Title IV regulations, as well as an egregious violation of my personal privacy and financial security.

Irecently discovered that my sensitive and legally protected records were accessed and potentially shared without my consent. This includes but is not limited to : 1.

My academic records and personal identifiable information ( PlI ).

2. 


My Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) data, including financial aid history and loan information 3.

My IRS tax transcripts, which were obtained and used without proper authorization These actions violate my rights under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. $ 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), which grants me the right to control access to my educational records, as well as Title IV of the Higher Education Act, which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information. Furthermore, unauthorized access to my IRS tax data raises serious concerns regarding potential identity theft, fraud, and violations of federal data security standards Given the severity of this breach and the direct impact on my financial security and privacy, I demand the following corrective actions : Immediate discharge and cancellation of all my federal student loans due to the breach of my financial aid and tax records, which invalidates the integrity of my loan agreements.

2.

A formal investigation into this data breach, including details on how my records were accessed.

who accessed them, and for what purpose.

3.

A full report on the extent of my data exposure and the corrective measures being implemented to prevent future violations 4. Immediate notification to all major credit bureaus ( XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX XXXX ) to place a fraud alert and investigate any unauthorized activity that may have resulted from this breach.

This breach has caused significant distress and concern regarding the security of my personal and financial data. If my demands are not met within 30 days, I will be left with no choice but to escalate this matter through legal channels, including filing complaints with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), and pursuing legal action against the responsible parties. 
I request a written response addressing these concerns and outlining the immediate actions being taken to remedy this situation. Please direct all correspondence to the address listed above Thank you for your prompt attention to this urgent matter. 1 look forward to your immediate response and resolution. I submitted this letter to all parties and I feel that all of this is a breach of contract please help me find resolution because my rights were violated more than one way!!!!

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Immediate Action Needed : Approve Outstanding Borrower Defense Applications To the Departments Overseeing School & Loan Server Compliance, We are writing as a collective group of defrauded students and alumni who attended XXXX schools, urging immediate action to approve outstanding Borrower Defense applications and provide full relief for those impacted. 

Many of us attended the following institutions owned by or affiliated with XXXX, where misrepresentations and predatory practices have been well-documented : XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX The Department of Education has already found significant evidence of misconduct by these schools. Specifically, XXXXXXXX XXXX misrepresented job placement rates to prospective students between XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX falsely claiming that 90 % of graduates secured jobs in their field of study within six months of graduation. This claim, widely advertised in national campaigns and direct mailings, was later revealed to be grossly inaccurate. XXXX included old jobs held by mid-career students before enrolling and excluded graduates who found employment outside their field of study. 

At its peak, XXXX enrolled nearly XXXX students across campuses in 26 states and through an online program accessible nationwide. The scale of this deception has left countless students burdened with unmanageable debt and limited opportunities, as documented in the Department of Educations Borrower Defense Executive Summary and Statements of Facts. 

We are asking you to take immediate steps to : 1. Approve all outstanding Borrower Defense applications for students who attended these institutions. 

2. Discharge all loans associated with fraudulent practices, including consolidated loans.

3. Repair borrowers credit reports to reflect the removal of these fraudulent debts.

Delaying action only prolongs the harm caused by these predatory institutions, leaving borrowers unable to move forward with their lives. Many of us pursued higher education to achieve the American Dream, but this dream was stolen by the very institutions we trusted to help us achieve it. 

We implore you to act decisively to ensure justice for all borrowers who were misled and exploited. The stakes are simply too high to risk further delays. 

Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter. 

Sincerely, Students & Graduates of XXXX XXXX

If this matter is not resolved promptly, I am prepared to escalate my complaint to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), and take legal action as necessary. I expect a response within 30 days from the date of this letter. 

Please direct all correspondence regarding this matter to my address above. I appreciate your prompt attention to this serious issue. 

Sincerely XXXX XXXX

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to file a formal complaint regarding the inaccurate and harmful credit reporting associated with my federal student loan account, previously serviced by Nelnet and recently transferred to XXXX. This situation has caused significant and immediate damage to my credit profile, and I believe it reflects a broader systemic issue affecting many borrowers during the transition out of pandemic-related deferment. 

Here is a detailed account of my experience : My student loans originated 12 years ago and have been in deferment for the past XXXX years. 
I have a track record of making on-time payments during periods when the loans were in active repayment. 
Without clear or sufficient warning, my loans exited deferment, and XXXX missed payments were reported all at once indicating a XXXX delinquency despite receiving no XXXX or XXXX notices. 
I was only made aware of the delinquency after it was reported to the credit bureaus, at which point I acted immediately. 
I made a payment of {$500.00} on XX/XX/2025, bringing my account current. My total balance across all XXXX loan accounts is {$3500.00}. 
The very next day, on XX/XX/2025, my account was transferred from Nelnet to XXXX and placed into forbearance, without explanation, adding to the confusion and instability of servicing. 

I want to clearly state that I acknowledge there is some fault on my part. It is the borrowers responsibility to remain informed and current. However, after such a long period of deferment, the sudden reactivation of the loans without any formal XXXX notice was not an effective or fair practice. Instead of official communication, the only warnings I received were unfamiliar phone calls which I, like many others in this era of widespread scam activity, ignored for security reasons. In todays climate, unrecognized calls are not a reasonable substitute for formal written or electronic notices. 

Since the incident occurred, I have taken responsible steps to address it : I wrote to both Nelnet and XXXX requesting a goodwill credit adjustment. 
I filed a complaint with my XXXX Attorney XXXX office. 
I have disputed the late payments with the major credit bureaus. 

This situation is part of a nationwide pattern, where borrowers who acted in good faith during deferment are now facing disproportionate financial harm due to inadequate communication, mismanagement, and sudden servicing transitions. I am fully capable and committed to maintaining on-time payments, and I am asking that this issue be reviewed with consideration for a credit reporting correction or relief, based on the circumstances and my prompt action. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I am happy to provide any documentation or communication history needed. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) XXXX XXXX XXXX

This entry is incorrect, and I believe it stems from either a misclassification of debt, a privacy violation, or an unauthorized transfer of personal financial data, which is a direct violation of multiple federal laws.

Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I have the legal right to : Dispute inaccurate or unverifiable information under 15 U.S.C. 1681i Receive a full disclosure of the origin, purpose, and use of any item listed under 15 U.S.C. 1681g ( 609 ) Be protected from the negligent or willful misuse of my credit data under 15 U.S.C. 1681n and 1681o Additionally, the improper handling or sharing of my personal information, especially if this loan was never authorized by me or wrongly reclassified, may also violate : The Privacy Act of 1974, which prohibits the unauthorized use of personal identifiable information ( PII ) by federal agencies and their partners.

The Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ( 15 U.S.C. 68016809 ), which requires financial institutions to protect nonpublic personal information and mandates consent before sharing such information with third parties.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally report a significant data breach involving the unauthorized access and potential misuse of my protected education records. This incident involves the U.S. Department of Education and the Department of Government Efficiency ( DOGE ), which was recently under the leadership of XXXX XXXX. I have reason to believe that sensitive data belonging to me and other American students may have been accessed, shared, or manipulated without proper consent, violating both legal protections and public trust. 
The records accessed without my authorization include : - My academic transcripts and personally identifiable information ( PII ) - My Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) data, including my financial aid history and loan documents- My IRS tax transcripts, which are protected under federal law and should not be accessible to third parties without explicit consent These actions are clear violations of my rights under the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ), codified at 20 U.S.C. 
1232g and 34 CFR Part 99. They also violate provisions of the Higher Education Act. Unauthorized access to IRS documents raises red flags for identity theft and financial fraud risks. 
I am formally requesting the following actions : 1. Immediate discharge and cancellation of all federal student loans under my name 2. A comprehensive investigation into the breach, identifying all involved parties 3. A report detailing what data was accessed, when, and how it was stored or shared 4. Preventive security measures to avoid future violations 5. Identity protection support, including fraud monitoring services This incident has caused emotional, reputational, and financial harm. If these requests are not fulfilled within 30 days, I will escalate the matter with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), and pursue legal remedies. 
Supporting evidence of broader systemic issues : - XXXX article : XXXX  : XXXX - XXXX report : XXXX  : XXXX - The Record coverage : XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX - XXXX XXXX report : XXXX : XXXX? XXXX

Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem

Consumer complaint narrative:
RE : FORMAL DISPUTE INCORRECT LATE PAYMENT REPORTING ACCOUNT XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  To Whom It May Concern, This letter is a formal dispute and demand for immediate correction regarding erroneous information being reported to the credit bureaus on the above-referenced student loan account.

Your records reflect that this account was 90 days late XXXX time ( s ), which is entirely false and inaccurate. This student loan was in an approved forbearance/deferment status during the alleged time frame of delinquency. Reporting this account as late while it was legally in forbearance is not only misleadingit is a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and Department of Education regulations regarding federal student loan servicing and reporting. 

DEMAND FOR ACTION I hereby demand the following actions be taken immediately : Remove all inaccurate late payment notations ( specifically the 90-day lates ) from this account across all credit bureaus. 

Correct the payment history to reflect Pays as Agreed / In Forbearance for the entire disputed period. 

Provide a written statement confirming the correction has been submitted to Equifax, Experian, and TransUnion. 

VIOLATIONS Reporting late payments on a federally-backed student loan while it is in forbearance constitutes : Violation of FCRA, 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) Furnishing inaccurate data Violation of the Higher Education Act Misreporting federal student loan status Violation of FDCPA, 15 U.S.C. 1692e False or misleading representations Violation of consumer protection rights under CFPB oversight Each violation is subject to statutory damages under federal law. 

FINAL WARNING If you fail to take immediate corrective action, I will proceed with the following : File complaints with the CFPB, Department of Education, FTC, and State Attorney General Dispute this item directly with all three credit bureaus under FCRA 611 Retain legal counsel to seek damages for defamation of credit, financial injury, and emotional distress I have maintained records proving the account was never delinquent and was in good standing during the entire disputed period. Continued misreporting will not be tolerated. 

You have 15 days to respond with a resolution in writing.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am formally requesting the full payoff, satisfaction, and discharge of all XXXX student loans, as well as a refund of the payments I have overpaid over the last 38 years. Despite making substantial payments totaling {$24000.00}, my principal balances have not been properly adjusted, and I am still being charged an unjustified outstanding balance of {$13000.00}. Additionally, loan records contain serious discrepancies, including missing payments, miscalculations following a court judgment, and errors related to my Social Security number. 
Severe Financial Hardship Due to Loan Mismanagement These loans originally totaled just {$7700.00}, yet I have now paid more than XXXX times that amount. Despite my repeated good faith efforts to resolve these issues, the financial burden has made it impossible for me to maintain even a minimal standard of living for myself and my son. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) and its associated servicers have failed to properly credit my payments, provide accurate accounting, or offer a fair resolution. Their mismanagement has directly contributed to my financial hardship, preventing me from securing stable housing, accessing essential medical care, and affording basic necessities. This situation is beyond unreasonable and must be rectified immediately. 
Summary of Loan Payments and Issues ( EXHIBITS XXXX ) Loan Payment Breakdown All data has been transferred from Trellis loan payment history ( EXHIBIT XXXX ), and XXXX Case Reconstruction Reports ( EXHIBIT XXXX, EXHIBIT XXXX ). 
Loan XXXX ( XXXX, Original Balance : {$2500.00} ) Total Paid : {$9100.00} Loan XXXX ( XXXX, Original Balance : {$2600.00} ) Total Paid : {$8000.00} Loan XXXX ( XXXX, Original Balance : {$1500.00} ) Total Paid : {$4100.00} Loan XXXX ( XXXX, Original Balance : {$1100.00} ) Total Paid : {$3400.00} Major Issues Identified XXXX. Incorrect Balance Calculation Despite making payments far exceeding my original loan amounts, my balances have not decreased accordingly. 
XXXX. Removed Payments {$1800.00} principal payment made in XXXX was removed without explanation from my account records. ( EXHIBIT XXXX PAGE XXXX, EXHIBIT XXXX PAGE XXXX ) XXXX. Inconsistencies in Interest and Principal Allocation Some payments were applied entirely to interest, while others were partially allocated to principal without any clear pattern, in violation of standard loan servicing practices. According to the Higher Education Act ( HEA ) of XXXX and Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) regulations, servicers are required to apply payments fairly and transparently, ensuring borrowers receive accurate accounting of their repayment progress. If proper allocation guidelines had been followed, all loans would have been fully paid off by XXXX. 
The failure to correctly apply payments and provide a clear breakdown of how they were allocated constitutes bad faith loan servicing and a breach of federal regulations. Per the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) and the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), loan servicers must maintain accurate records and disclose how payments are applied. Instead, Trellis has engaged in deceptive practices, resulting in excessive interest charges. It is financially unreasonable and legally indefensible for me to have paid {$6200.00} in interest on a {$2500.00} loana clear indication of mismanagement and predatory servicing. 
XXXX. Judgment Miscalculation ( Case # XXXX ) ( EXHIBIT XXXX ) In XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX sued me in XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and won a judgment for {$10000.00}. 
Instead of adjusting my balance, XXXX added {$10000.00} to my loan balance, effectively charging me twice. 
XXXX. Unjustified Loan Rehabilitation and Consolidation Denials Multiple attempts to rehabilitate, consolidate, and enter repayment plans have been denied, with no valid reason provided. 
XXXX. XX/XX/XXXX Hearing Request Denial In XX/XX/XXXX, I requested a hearing to dispute my loan status. 
On XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX sent me a letter stating : " In reviewing your account as part of the hearing process, XXXX has determined your account no longer meets the qualifications for XXXX. Based on this information, it is unnecessary to continue with the hearing process at this time. '' The balance listed on this notice was {$12000.00}. 
XXXX. Other Loans Fully Paid Off While dealing with these unjust loan issues, I continued to make payments on XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, both of which were paid in full. ( EXHIBIT XXXX ) XXXX XXXX Loan : Paid in full : {$1700.00} XXXX Unsubsidized XXXX Loan : Paid in full : {$2500.00}.

Trellis refused to provide a full Satisfaction of XXXX for XXXX # XXXX, even if I made the payment. 
This further proves that Trellis is acting in bad faith and failing to provide transparent, fair, and accountable loan servicing. 
Requested Actions & Immediate Resolution Given the proven financial hardship, gross errors, and repeated mismanagement, I formally demand the following : A Paid in Full Acknowledgment for each of the XXXX loans that are open and serviced under both of my Social Security numbers.

I am now looking at colleges for my son, yet I am faced with the heartbreaking reality that these loansmeant to help people better themselveshave done the complete opposite. Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX XXXX instructed his staff at the Department of Government Efficiency ( DOGE ) to unlawfully enter the U.S. Department of Education. On XX/XX/XXXX, DOGE agents took control of the Departments internal systems, locking out employees and members of Congress. This lockout was widely covered by major news outlets, including XXXX, XXXX, and other prominent stations. During this unauthorized access, it remains unclear exactly what actions were taken or what specific records or data were accessed, altered, or taken during that time. 

This breach directly impacted my personally identifiable education records, which are maintained by XXXXXXXX XXXX, the U.S. Department of Education, and service providers such as XXXX ( which handles federal student loan servicing ). These records include my academic transcripts, enrollment history, and borrower-related information linked to the federal student loans taken out by my parent XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX on my behalf. 

The unauthorized access and potential misuse of these records constitutes a violation of several laws, including : Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ), which protects the privacy of student education records. The unauthorized disclosure of my education records and personal information is a direct violation of FERPA. 

The Privacy Act of 1974, which safeguards personal information held by federal agencies. The breach by DOGE agents violates the protections established by this law, as they accessed personal and educational data without authorization. 

The Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act, which criminalizes the unauthorized use of personal information. Given the potential for misuse of my financial and educational records, this may be applicable to the actions taken by DOGE and XXXX XXXX. 

Given that DOGE is not a legitimate government agency, and XXXX XXXX holds no official authority within either XXXXXXXX XXXX or the Department of Education, this action was entirely unauthorized. The breach of my records, as well as the potential misuse of my parents loan information, is a serious violation of privacy and security. 

I demand an immediate and thorough investigation into the actions taken during this security breach, including identifying what specific data was accessed or stolen, and any potential misuse of both my personal information and my parents financial records. I expect a prompt response detailing the actions being taken to rectify this situation and ensure that such a breach does not happen again. Removal loans off both my credit report and my parents credit ( XXXX XXXX ) report from any reference to this loan or associated financial obligations, as there is uncertainty about the authenticity of the information. This should include the deletion of any and all records related to the loan from both parties credit history, to prevent long-term damage to our financial standing. This should also be communicated to the credit bureaus XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX. 

According to the Privacy act Located in our Master Promissory Note ( attachment provided ) 1. Who Can Access the Information : The privacy act outlines that access to your information is authorized for : Federal, state, or local agencies ( but these agencies must have a legitimate purpose as defined under law or regulation ). 

Specific private parties ( like financial institutions, guaranty agencies, and educational institutions ) under controlled circumstances ( e.g., loan servicing, fraud investigation ). 

Consumer reporting agencies for credit-related purposes or loan delinquency tracking. 

XXXX XXXX DOGE ( Department of Government Efficiency ) does not fall into any of these categories. Specifically, there is no legal or formal authorization for DOGE or its personnel to access or handle educational loan records from the Department of Education. DOGE is not listed as an authorized agency or party under the Master Promissory Note 's routine uses. This means that any action by DOGE, including accessing or disclosing loan-related information, would violate the terms set forth in this agreement and would be an unauthorized disclosure. 

2. No Explicit Authorization for DOGE or XXXXXXXX XXXX : The privacy statement does not list DOGE or any organization associated with XXXX XXXX as a permissible third party. The language about disclosures specifies agencies and institutions involved in loan servicing, fraud prevention, and collection efforts, but DOGE is not among them. Additionally, DOGE is not a government agency that could be granted access to federal records like the Department of Educations student loan data. 

3. Legitimate Purposes : The passage details the legitimate purposes for data access and disclosure, such as fraud investigation, verifying eligibility, loan servicing, and collections. DOGE does not have a recognized legal or institutional role within these processes. Unless DOGE had been explicitly granted a role by an appropriate federal authority ( which has not been documented or authorized ), they would have no legal standing to access educational records, including loan records under the Master Promissory Note. 

4. Violation of FERPA and Privacy Act : The Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) also protects educational records from unauthorized access, and based on the information in your complaint, its clear that DOGEs actions likely violated FERPA as well. FERPA limits access to student records without the student 's written consent, except in specific circumstances ( such as disclosures to specific educational officials or authorized third parties ). XXXX XXXX, acting through DOGE, did not have the necessary authorization under FERPA to access these records. 

5. Absence of Transparency on Data Usage : Since there is no clear or documented disclosure allowing DOGE to access or utilize the educational records, it would be safe to say that DOGEs actions likely constitute a violation of not just the Master Promissory Note 's terms but also of privacy and security regulations set out by the Department of Education and relevant federal laws. 

Conclusion : The privacy act of 1974 you from our Master Promissory Note outlines the specific and authorized uses of personal information related to student loans, none of which includes access by DOGE. Therefore, XXXX XXXX XXXX had no legitimate or legal authority to access the Department of Educations records, and their actions represent a clear violation of the terms of the Master Promissory Note, as well as possibly violating federal laws like FERPA and the Privacy Act. 

Reference Information below How XXXX XXXX DOGE Took Over the Education Department, One Office at a Time Published : Wed, XX/XX/XXXX, XXXXXXXX XXXX EST Updated : Wed, XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX XXXX EST XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Inside DOGE 's Takeover of the Education Department Staffers at the Department of Education worry the Department of Government Efficiency is accessing sensitive information and spreading confusion. 
XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX Says Department of Education No Longer Exists XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/year>, XXXX XXXX instructed his Team to gain access to multiple internal systems within the U.S. Department of Education ( DOE ) and the Department of Governmental Entities ( DOGE ). I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding the unauthorized access and breach of my educational records, financial aid data, and IRS tax information by the U.S. Department of Education ( DOE ) and the Department of Governmental Entities ( DOGE ). This breach constitutes a direct violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and Title IV regulations, as well as an egregious violation of my personal privacy and financial security. 
I recently discovered that my sensitive and legally protected records were accessed and potentially shared without my consent. This includes but is not limited to : 1. My academic records and personally identifiable information ( PII ). 
2. My Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) data, including financial aid history and loan information. 
3. My IRS tax transcripts, which were obtained and used without proper authorization. 
These actions violate my rights under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), which grants me the right to control access to my educational records, as well as Title IV of the Higher Education Act, which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information. Furthermore, unauthorized access to my IRS tax data raises serious concerns regarding potential identity theft, fraud, and violations of federal data security standards. This breach has caused significant distress and concern regarding the security of my personal and financial data.

However, my loan balance continued to balloon due to high interest. 
Over the years, my loan balance has nearly doubled because of compounding interest. If I had been properly informed about income-driven repayment options early on, I would not be in this position. Issue: Improper use of your report
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
Nelnet Education Loan Funding , Inc. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, NE XXXX Subject : Cease and Desist Demand for Unlawful Practices Dear Nelnet Education Loan Funding , Inc. , I am writing to formally notify you that your actions related to my personal information and your continued collection attempts are in violation of federal statutes, and I demand that you immediately CEASE AND DESIST from any further unlawful activities concerning my personal data, credit reporting, or communications. 

I am invoking the following laws : 15 U.S.C. 6802 - The Right to Privacy of Personal Information Under this statute, you are prohibited from disclosing, sharing, or utilizing my personal information in ways that are unauthorized and unlawful. If you are continuing to collect, share, or utilize my personal data for purposes other than those for which I have expressly consented, you must immediately cease such activities. 

15 U.S.C. 1681b - Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act, any inquiry into my credit report or the use of my credit data must have a permissible purpose. If your actions regarding my credit report or credit file do not align with permissible purposes defined under this law, I demand that you immediately stop any such inquiries, requests, or use of my credit information.

18 U.S.C. 1028A - Aggravated Identity Theft If any of your actions, whether by you or on your behalf, have involved the unauthorized use, disclosure, or solicitation of my personal identifying information, such conduct may fall under identity theft statutes. If your actions are determined to be unlawful or represent an attempt to unlawfully use my personal identity for any unauthorized purposes, I will not hesitate to pursue legal remedies to the full extent of the law, including notifying the appropriate authorities for further action. 

As such, I demand the following : That you immediately CEASE AND DESIST from any further attempts to collect or report any information about me without my express consent, in violation of the above-mentioned laws. 

That you immediately cease any unlawful inquiries or misuse of my personal information or credit report. 

That you provide me with a written confirmation within [ Specify a time frame, e.g., 15 days ] from the date of this letter that you have ceased and desisted from the above activities and any related actions. 

Failure to comply with this demand will leave me with no choice but to pursue all available legal remedies, including filing complaints with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), and other relevant authorities, as well as seeking civil damages under applicable law. 

Please consider this matter seriously and take immediate action to prevent further escalation. 

Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
XXXX, MO XXXX [ Your Email Address ] [ Your Phone Number ] Make sure to specify a reasonable time frame for the creditor to respond ( typically 10-15 days ), and consider sending the letter via certified mail with return receipt to ensure you have a record of it being received. Additionally, it's always a good idea to consult a legal professional if you're unsure about any part of the process.

Issue: Incorrect information on your report
Sub-issue: Public record information inaccurate
Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, AZ XXXX SSN : XXXX XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX To : Sallie Mae XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, DE XXXX RE : Dispute of Unverified Student Loan Accounts Immediate Deletion Requested To Whom It May Concern, This letter is a formal dispute submitted in accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq., concerning the reporting of student loan accounts associated with [ Insert Loan Servicer Name or Account Number ( s ), e.g., XXXX on my credit file. 

XXXX. ISSUE : Lack of Verification of a Signed Master Promissory Note ( MPN ) Relevant Law : Under 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ), a credit reporting agency must conduct a reasonable reinvestigation if a consumer disputes the completeness or accuracy of any item in their file. Additionally, under 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ), the CRA must ensure maximum possible accuracy of the information it includes. 
Demand : I am demanding immediate deletion of the referenced student loan account ( s ) from my Experian credit file unless the data furnisher can provide the original, wet-ink signed Master Promissory Note ( MPN ) establishing a valid, enforceable obligation in my name. Electronic reproduction or summary data is not sufficient under federal evidentiary standards, particularly when the debt is disputed. The burden of proof lies with the furnisher. If the original contract does not exist, the tradeline must be removed. 

XXXX. ISSUE : Failure to Verify Current Status Forbearance or Administrative Hold Relevant Law : Per 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( b ), the information furnisher is obligated to investigate disputed information and correct or delete any data found to be inaccurate or unverifiable. If a loan is in administrative forbearance, deferment, or a non-repayment status due to federal policy or executive order, such status must be clearly and accurately reflected in the reporting. Failure to do so constitutes willful misreporting and inaccurate furnishing of information.

Demand : Please verify whether this account is presently subject to administrative forbearance or any federal hold. If it is, it can not legally be reported as delinquent or in default. If this can not be fully verified and proven by the data furnisher, the account must be removed immediately for failure to meet accuracy and verification standards outlined by the FCRA. 

XXXX. ISSUE : XXXX XXXX and CDIA Compliance Failure Relevant Law : The Consumer Data Industry Association ( CDIA ) XXXX XXXX  Format Guidelines, which Experian has adopted for credit furnishing, require that all tradelines be accurate, complete, and up-to-date. Reporting disputed, unverifiable, or administratively frozen debts violates these guidelines. 
Demand : You are required to remove any entry that does not conform with XXXX XXXX and XXXX standards. Student loans that are not contractually verified or are impacted by legislative changes ( such as federal repayment pauses or executive actions ) must not be reported as adverse. If you can not validate this account according to those standards, it must be removed. 
Failure to Comply Will Result in Further Action This is a legal dispute under the FCRA. Should you fail to respond within 30 days with sufficient documentation, I will escalate the matter with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and consider further legal action under 15 U.S.C. 1681n and 1681o for willful or negligent noncompliance.

Summary of Accounts to be Investigated and Deleted : Sallie / Account Number Ending in XXXX Sallie / Account Number Ending in XXXX Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Based on my income and enrollment in the Income-Driven Repayment ( IDR ) Plan Pay As You Earn ( PAYE ), the correct payment should be approximately {$1300.00} per month. I have contacted Aidvantage repeatedly over the past four weeks, speaking with more than five different representatives, and their staff has openly admitted this is a systemic error on their end. 

Each time I called, I was assured that the issue would be corrected by XX/XX/year>2025. However, when I followed up on XX/XX/XXXX, the representative I spoke with had no knowledge of any prior conversations, showed no awareness of the XX/XX/XXXX resolution deadline, and provided no clear path forward. I was told the issue could or may not be resolved, and despite my repeated requests, I was not permitted to speak with a supervisor. The lack of continuity, transparency, and accountability is completely unacceptable and deeply distressing. 

To make matters worse, Aidvantage has placed my loans into forbearance while they attempt to resolve their internal error, further disadvantaging me as a responsible borrower. This forbearance negatively impacts my progress toward Public Service Loan Forgiveness ( PSLF ), by potentially disqualifying these months from my qualifying payment count. I feel I am being punished for a failure that is entirely theirs. I have done everything asked of me, complied with all requirements and deadlines, and stayed on top of my repayment obligations. 

This situation has caused me extreme XXXX. I am currently experiencing a high-risk XXXX, and this ongoing issue is directly affecting my health and well-being. The time and energy required to repeatedly follow up with Aidvantageoften during business hourshas also interfered with my responsibilities as a XXXX XXXX XXXX compounding my XXXX and professional burden. 

I respectfully request immediate intervention to : 1. Correct my monthly payment to the appropriate amount ( approximately {$1300.00} per PAYE guidelines ).

2. Remove the forbearance designation and ensure all eligible months count toward PSLF.

3. Prevent any negative credit reporting, interest capitalization, or financial penalties resulting from this error.

4. Hold Aidvantage accountable for its failure to resolve this acknowledged issue and the unacceptable lack of internal communication and customer support.

I am happy to provide documentation including income verification, repayment plan records, correspondence logs, and more.

Thank you for your time and attention to this matter. 

Sincerely XXXX XXXX XXXX

My credit report was recently updated to reflect over 2 late payment entries from Dept Of Education which has caused my credit score to drop by over XXXX points. This action was taken without any prior notice, warning, or correspondenceI did not receive any emails, letters, or alerts informing me of this drastic change before it was reported to the credit bureaus. 

Additionally, I have become aware of an ongoing data breach involving student loan accounts, which raises serious concerns regarding unauthorized access to my personal and financial information raising concerns over a FERPA violation. Given this security lapse, I have reason to believe that my account records may have been compromised or altered without my consent. 

I am in the process of purchasing a home and this has caused my loan to be halted until this is remedied. This has caused extreme financial distress and this error in reporting needs to be remedied immediately. I did not authorize any changes to my account status, and I no longer feel comfortable having my student loans serviced and reported to the credit bureaus under these conditions. 

Violations and Consumer Protection Rights 1. Failure to Provide Notice of Negative Credit Reporting - Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), loan servicers are required to provide accurate and fair reporting. I was not notified in advance that these accounts would be marked late, which denied me the opportunity to address any potential issues before they were reported.

2. Possible Unauthorized Reporting and Account Compromise Due to Data Breach - The reported data breach involving Nelnet raises serious questions about the integrity of my loan accounts. If my data was exposed or manipulated, Nelnet may have incorrectly or fraudulently reported late payments that I did not actually incur.

3. Failure to Properly Investigate and Verify Account Status - Given the security risks and errors in reporting, I request full verification and documentation proving the legitimacy of the late payments, including a detailed account history showing how and when they were marked late.

Requested Resolution - Immediate removal of all reported late payments from my credit report, as they were reported without proper notice and under potentially compromised circumstances.

- A formal investigation into Department of Education reporting practices to determine whether my data was mishandled or compromised.

- A written response from Department of Education confirming the deletion of these late payments from my credit file. This situation has caused me extreme distress, financial harm, and damage to my creditworthiness.

- I expect a prompt and thorough resolution in compliance with federal consumer protection laws.

Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter.

Consumer complaint narrative: In either XXXX or XXXX of XXXX, the Federal government paused student loan repayments. Since that time, I have received no communication from EdFinancial regarding my loans or repayment status. Then, on XX/XX/XXXX, I received a series of letters in the mail ; one provided a statement, another a notification of a failed auto-payment and a third stating that my account was over 120 days late. I had no clue what these letters were and was shocked. I went to the link that the letters directed, and realized this was for EdFinancial and it wasn't a scam, seeking payment. When I logged into the account, I saw through the payment history, that they'd been attempting auto-debits since XX/XX/XXXX to an account that I had closed in XXXX. No notification had ever been sent to me to state that loans were going back into repayment. That aside, no notification has ever been sent to me to indicate that they'd been unsuccessfully attempting payment for the last 18 months. Only on XX/XX/XXXX had I received notice. I paid the late payment through my new checking account with another institution. When I spoke with an agent, she informed me that I was on electronic notification delivery. That said, not once had EdFinancial e-mailed me to say that they were attempting payment and payment had failed, or that they were even going into repayment status. Those messages sat in the EdFinancial inbox and no e-mail had ever been sent to my e-mail, which was on file with them, to indicate messages were waiting for me to read. Further, they had not sent me any letters in the mail either. They have now reported me 120 days late, even though I'm current and made myself current as soon as they actually notified me. This is incredibly deceptive and I made the late payment but if I'd been sent letter previously, as they finally did on XX/XX/XXXX, I would have addressed this before it ever went into a late status. They collected interest on me for loans that I could have already have paid off by now, if they'd only been responsible enough to reach out to me. I have received no e-mail or written letter from them in nearly 5 years and now they report me late without allowing me the opportunity to pay.

XX/XX/year> : The consolidation was completed, and a final document was supposedly sent - per aidvantage customer service rep. 

Key Issues : Lack of Disclosure : After submitting the application, I was informed that the consolidation was on hold due to a court injunction. However, without further notice, the consolidation was completed. I was not given any information about the loan terms, interest rates, or repayment details. 

No Opportunity for Informed Decision-Making : I was not given the chance to review or consider the loan terms before the consolidation was finalized. Had I been informed, I would have excluded multiple loans with lower interest rates from the consolidation.

Unexpected Payment Amount : The final payment amount is three times higher than the estimate I was provided. This discrepancy now jeopardizes my ability to qualify for a mortgage, as I am set to close on a home purchase in a week. Was the loan initially selected the best option for lowest monthly? No idea, no help, no one assisting students to make this huge decision. 

Failure of Adequate Communication : At no point were the final terms of the consolidation shared with me before it was processed. I was only provided with the original estimate, which does not reflect the actual payment or terms of loan.

ISSUE Within the last few months there was a change, and the loan went from forbearance to default and resulted in a negative impact to my credit score.

My Loan servicer is Ed Financial. 

As of their own Billing Statement dated XX/XX/2025 ( which I downloaded and printed ) my account balance was {$15000.00}. This is a subsidized loan and I was making payments as I could. 

I also had an unsubsidized loan which was paid-off as of the XX/XX/XXXX Billing Statement ( the Billing Statement only shows One loan open -- the unsubsidized loan ).

'' ( I didn't even know there was such a thing as " Reverse Payments. '' ) So, now it appears I never made the payments described even though I did pay them.

This breach constitutes a direct violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and Title IV regulations, as well as an egregious violation of my personal privacy and financial security. 

These actions violate my rights under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), which grants me the right to control access to my educational records, as well as Title IV of the Higher Education Act, which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information. Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer

Consumer complaint narrative:
As per the Privacy Act, I understand that it ensures that the U.S. Department of Education ( ED ) handles my student loan data responsibly, collecting only necessary information, explaining how it will be used, and providing safeguards to protect it from unauthorized access or disclosure. 
Under this process, I am afforded key protections. Under the four collections afforded to me, three are in direct violation. They are as follows : Use of information : The ED must ensure that the records are used only for the reasons given, or seek permission for other uses.The recent access by DOGE is a direct violation of this Privacy Right. 

Safeguards : The ED must provide adequate safeguards to protect the records from unauthorized access and disclosure.The recent access by DOGE is a direct violation of this Privacy Right. 
Access to records : Borrowers can access their records and correct any inaccuracies.The recent access by DOGE is a direct violation of this Privacy Right.

Although the ED has access to student loan data, including borrowers XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ; names, Social Security numbers, financial information, and contact information, student advocacy groups and members of Congress have expressed concern about the access granted to DOGE. Additionally, as per the original complaint, I am allowed key protections under the Privacy Act and this access, without my verbal and/or written consent has caused great concern on the validity of the data showing in these accounts. 
Violation of the Privacy Act of 1974 : The mishandling and unauthorized disclosure of my personal information contravenes federal requirements that safeguard the privacy of individuals data managed by federal agencies and contractors. 
Breach of the Higher Education Act : The Higher Education Act requires servicers to maintain strict confidentiality and compliance in loan transfers. The transfer of my loan to XXXX and subsequent data demonstrate clear negligence. 
Breach of Contract and Data Security Obligations : By failing to protect my sensitive information, both MOHELA and XXXX have breached contractual terms and obligations, rendering these debts unenforceable.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX, I submitted my loan application through the companys website. On XX/XX/XXXX, I was informed that Section 1 of the application was missing. I immediately contacted the company for assistance. A representative instructed me to print and re-upload the application, which I did promptly.

A few weeks later, I received another notice stating that Page 4 required a physical ( handwritten ) signature. During my third call to the company, I spoke with a representative who advised me to go to a library or print the document, sign it, and return it. He failed to inform me that I could simply re-submit the signed application through their online portal, which would have allowed me to electronically sign the documentjust as I did during my original submission. 

Given my circumstances, I explained that I could neither print the document nor visit a library at that time. I then escalated the issue and spoke with a supervisor, XXXX, on what was likely my fourth or fifth call. I made it clear that the delay, caused by their lack of clear instructions, had negatively impacted my credit score by more than XXXX points. XXXX informed me that there was nothing more they could do and suggested that I dispute the negative report directly with the credit bureaus. 

I did everything as instructed. I made multiple calls, followed up promptly, and would have gladly resubmitted the documents had I been properly informed from the beginning. I should not be penalized for an employees failure to provide accurate and complete information. Now, the company is refusing to remove the negative mark on my credit report, claiming they provided adequate documentation. I firmly disagree. This internal communication failure on their partnot my actionscaused this issue. 

I understand that the company is legally obligated to report accurate information to the credit bureaus. However, as a licensed insurance agent, I know firsthand the professional responsibility that comes with providing correct information. If I were to provide incorrect guidance to a client, I could lose my license. Yet, in this case, the companys employee failed to give me the correct information, and now Im left jumping through hoops to fix the damage. This is both unfair and unacceptable.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative:
NelNet XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX Formal Appeal Case # XXXX To Whom It May Concern, I am submitting this letter as a formal appeal for the findings and closure of Case # XXXX. The response provided did not adequately resolve or address my core concerns, which involved serious violations of my privacy, unauthorized changes to my account, and resulting harm to my credit. 


Summary of Appeal Grounds : XXXX. Unauthorized Email Change via Vendor Search Your records indicate that my email address was changed on XX/XX/XXXX, following a vendor search prompted by alleged email bounce backs. I did not authorize this change, nor was I notified prior to or after the update. This constitutes a clear violation of my privacy and established consumer protection laws. The use of third-party vendors to alter personally identifiable information ( PII ) must be consent-based and verifiable. 
Under the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ( GLBA ) Privacy Rule, nonpublic personal information XXXX not be shared with or modified by nonaffiliated third parties without express notice and the opportunity to opt out. Additionally, the Federal Student Aid Master Promissory Note ( MPN ) does not XXXX blanket authorization for vendors to conduct independent information searches or to modify borrower data without the borrowers direct involvement. 
XXXX. Inability to XXXX XXXX Account The unauthorized change to my email address prevented me from logging in or resetting my password, effectively locking me out of my account. As a result, I missed important billing notices and communications. This lack of access stemmed directly from the changes your system initiated without my knowledge or approval. 


3. Negative Credit Reporting and Harm Due to the breakdown in communication and account access, I was unaware that my account had entered a past-due status following the expiration of the on-ramp period. I discovered this delinquency in XX/XX/XXXX when I received a credit monitoring alert showing a drop of approximately XXXX points in my credit score. This damage was caused by circumstances entirely outside of my control, originating with unauthorized changes to my account initiated by your vendor. 
4. Violation of My Promissory Note, GLBA, and the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) The unapproved use of third-party data to modify my account without consent is not only inconsistent with the terms of my promissory note, but it may also violate the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). Furnishing inaccurate or unverifiable information to credit reporting agencies, especially information stemming from system errors or unauthorized account changescould be deemed noncompliant under federal law. Additionally, the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) prohibits deceptive or unfair practices during collection, including wrongful handling of borrower information. 

Relief Requested : Immediate removal or correction of all negative credit reporting related to this incident. 
A full investigation and explanation of the vendor process used to change my email address without my knowledge or approval. 
A written statement confirming all corrective actions taken to secure my account and prevent further unauthorized modifications. 
Copies of all documentation and internal records relating to the vendor search, email update process, and associated decision-making. 

Please consider this my official appeal and request for reconsideration, as outlined in your letter. I respectfully request that this matter be reviewed by a different associate or escalated team via your internal protocol. I expect a written response within the 30-calendar-day timeline required for formal disputes and appeals. 
Thank you for your attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX Account # XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, OH XXXX

Issue: Incorrect information on your report
Sub-issue: Account information incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am disputing a 90-day delinquency that was reported on my federal subsidized student loan from XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX , serviced by EdFinancial. This delinquency appears on my XX/XX/XXXX credit report. I submitted a formal dispute to EdFinancial on XX/XX/XXXX, and followed up on XX/XX/XXXX, but I have not received any acknowledgment or resolution. 

The delinquency is inaccurate for the following reasons : The reported missed payments occurred during the Department of Educations On-Ramp Protection period ( XX/XX/XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  ), which clearly stated that missed payments during this time would not be reported to credit bureaus. 
I received no prior notice of delinquency until XX/XX/XXXX, XXXXafter the 90-day late mark had already been reported. 
The past due amount reported is only {$86.00}, while my monthly payment is {$21.00}. This amount does not equal or exceed three full missed payments and does not support a 90-day delinquency status.

In my original dispute, I requested the following : 1. Immediate removal of the 90-day delinquency from all credit bureaus ( XXXX, XXXX, XXXX ) .

2. Written confirmation that my account is not being treated as in default.

3. Cessation of any adverse actions such as collections, wage garnishment, or loan acceleration while the dispute is under review.

4. A response within 30 days, which I have not received. 

This reporting appears to violate protections under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), FDCPA, HEA, TILA, and the CARES Act On-Ramp policy. I have also submitted my dispute to the credit bureaus, and it is currently pending reinvestigation. 

I am requesting that the CFPB assist in compelling EdFinancial to investigate this matter properly and remove the inaccurate derogatory information from my credit report.

I am filing this complaint against Nelnet due to severe and unjustified negative credit reporting that has significantly impacted my financial standing. My credit report was recently updated to reflect late payment entries from Nelnet student loan, which has caused my credit score to drop by over XXXX points. This action was taken without any prior notice, warning, or correspondenceI did not receive any emails, letters, or alerts informing me of this drastic change before it was reported to the credit bureaus. 

Additionally, I have become aware of an ongoing data breach involving student loan accounts, which raises serious concerns regarding unauthorized access to my personal and financial information raising concerns over a FERPA violation. Given this security lapse, I have reason to believe that my account records may have been compromised or altered without my consent. 

I am in the process of purchasing a home and this has caused my loan to be halted until this is remedied. This has caused extreme financial distress and this error in reporting needs to be remedied immediately. I did not authorize any changes to my account status, and I no longer feel comfortable having my student loans serviced and reported to the credit bureaus under these conditions. 

Violations and Consumer Protection Rights 1. Failure to Provide Notice of Negative Credit Reporting - Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), loan servicers are required to provide accurate and fair reporting. I was not notified in advance that these accounts would be marked late, which denied me the opportunity to address any potential issues before they were reported.

2. Possible Unauthorized Reporting and Account Compromise Due to Data Breach - The reported data breach involving Nelnet raises serious questions about the integrity of my loan accounts. If my data was exposed or manipulated, Nelnet may have
incorrectly or fraudulently reported late payments that I did not actually incur.

3. Failure to Properly Investigate and Verify Account Status - Given the security risks and errors in reporting, I request full verification and documentation proving the legitimacy of the late payments, including a detailed account history showing how and when they were marked late.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Need information about your loan balance or loan terms
Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX Email : XXXX Date of Birth : XX/XX/XXXX StudentAid.gov Loan Account No : XXXX Date : XX/XX/XXXX To : Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) Subject : FORMAL CFPB COMPLAINT UNAUTHORIZED ACCESS, FEDERAL VIOLATIONS, AND DEMAND FOR LOAN DISCHARGE I am filing this formal complaint with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau against the XXXX Department of Education and any affiliated third-party contractors or agencies involved in the unauthorized access, mishandling, and breach of my personal and federal student loan information related to XXXX XXXX Account No. XXXX. 

This breach occurred via the Department of Government Efficiency ( XXXX ) prior to its official access being revoked in XX/XX/XXXX and constitutes multiple violations of federal law, a total collapse of custodial integrity, and gross negligence on the part of those entrusted to secure my most sensitive personal and financial information. 

Violations and Legal Grounds 1. Violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) 20 U.S.C. 1232g My education and loan records were accessed without proper consent by an unauthorized agency. This directly violates FERPAs protection of personally identifiable information ( PII ). The Department of Education failed in its duty to prevent and respond to this violation.

2. Privacy Act of 1974 5 U.S.C. 552a This breach also constitutes a direct violation of the Privacy Act, which mandates that personal records maintained by federal agencies be protected from unauthorized access and dissemination. I demand to invoke my rights under this law to contest and amend any records accessed or altered through this unlawful breach.

3. Federal Rules of Evidence Rule 901 ( Chain of Custody & Document Authentication ) This breach calls into question the legitimacy, source, and accuracy of all documents, contracts, and data associated with my federal loans. Due to the broken chain of custody and compromised data security, I am formally challenging the enforceability of these debts.

4. Federal Trade Commission Act 15 U.S.C. 4158 ( Unfair and Deceptive Practices ) This incident represents clear federal negligence in protecting consumer data. The U.S. Department of Education and its affiliates have engaged in unfair and deceptive practices by failing to properly secure my private information, putting me at significant and ongoing risk of identity theft and financial harm. 

Actions Ive Been Forced to Take to Protect Myself Due to your failures, I have had to independently take these emergency measures : Changed credentials on all major personal and financial platforms ( including StudentAid.gov ) ; Enabled multi-factor authentication across accounts ; Filed fraud alerts with Experian, Equifax, and TransUnion ; Subscribed to identity theft monitoring and credit protection services ; Reviewed and documented all financial activity for suspicious behavior. 

These are not preventativethey are reactive countermeasures forced upon me because your systems failed. 

Formal Demands for Immediate Relief 1. Full cancellation and discharge of all federal student loans under Account No. 9459158461, based on the irreparable breach of custodial integrity, FERPA violations, and Privacy Act infractions.

2. Immediate freeze and suspension of all collections, interest accrual, credit reporting, or enforcement actions related to this account until a full legal audit is completed. 
XXXX. Comprehensive forensic report detailing : All unauthorized access events, Dates and nature of breach, Individuals and agencies involved, The legal basis ( or lack thereof ) for such access. 
XXXX. Written confirmation that this complaint has been formally escalated within your agency and that appropriate regulatory enforcement procedures are underway. 

If I do not receive a full and lawful resolution within 30 calendar days, I will escalate this matter to : The Family Policy Compliance Office ( U.S. Department of Education ), The Federal Trade Commission, Congressional oversight committees, and Pursue legal action through private counsel.

Any further attempt to collect on these compromised loans will constitute continued legal misconduct and subject your agencies to further liability. 

Respectfully, XXXX XXXX Signature : ___________________________ Date : XX/XX/XXXX 2025

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Problem with forgiveness, cancellation, or discharge
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally express my concerns regarding potential violations of my rights under the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and the improper handling of student loan data by the Department of Education ( DOE ) and its potential transfer to the Small Business Administration ( SBA ) in 2025.

As a borrower of federal student loans, I entered into a contractual agreement with the Department of Education. My promissory note explicitly states that my obligations are to the DOE, and I did not consent to any transfer of my loan management to the SBA or any other entity. The reported move of student loan oversight from the DOE to the SBA under the upcoming administration raises serious legal and ethical questions regarding the sanctity of this agreement and my rights as a borrower.

Furthermore, I am deeply concerned about the improper handling of my personal and financial information. If this transfer occurs, it may constitute a breach of my right to privacy and a violation of FERPA, which protects the confidentiality of student records. I am also alarmed by the potential unauthorized access to my loan data by third-party entities, including individuals or corporations with no legal right to this information.

Given the gravity of these concerns, I respectfully request that your office : Investigate whether the proposed transfer of student loans from the DOE to the SBA in 2025 constitutes a breach of contract and a violation of borrower rights.

Examine whether this transfer or any related actions violate FERPA by exposing students ' personal and financial data to unauthorized entities.

Determine whether third-party entities, including private individuals or corporations, have accessed or mishandled borrower information in a manner that infringes upon privacy laws.

Take legal action, if necessary, to protect borrowers from any unlawful or unconstitutional policies that may arise from this transition.

I urge your office to take swift action to prevent potential harm to millions of student loan borrowers who may be impacted by this unprecedented shift in student loan administration. Please provide guidance on what legal protections are available to borrowers in my situation and any steps I can take to safeguard my rights.

Thank you for your time and attention to this urgent matter. I look forward to your response. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer

Consumer complaint narrative:
2nd complaint about Navient. 
My name is XXXX XXXX XXXX, and Im writing to demand accountability and answers. I am a XXXX XXXX  XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX I borrowed less than {$7000.00} in student loans between XXXX, which were consolidated and marked paid in full by XXXX. I have not returned to school or taken out any new student loans since. 

Yet in XX/XX/XXXX, a new XXXX XXXX XXXX for {$23000.00} appeared on my account. It was labeled as a disbursement, but I never requested or authorized it. I never gave informed consent. I was not told this loan was being created. I didnt apply for anything. This was done behind my backor buried in a sea of confusing paperwork. If I did sign something, it was under false pretenses during a time when I was already overwhelmed by financial hardship, bankruptcy, and mental health trauma. 

Before XXXX took over this loan, it was handled by Navient, a servicer that has already been exposed for illegal and deceptive practices. I believe Navient initiated or influenced this fraudulent consolidation as part of a so-called clean-up after years of mismanagementlikely without clear disclosure to me, and without any option to opt out. 

My student aid file is filled with conflicting information : Loans are listed multiple times as Paid in Full Through Consolidationyet the debt never goes away. 

The XXXX loan falsely shows a disbursement, as if I was a student again. I was not. 

Interest and fees have piled on for years through capitalized interest, forbearance cycles, and default statuses I was never fully informed about. 

What began as a manageable debt from my XXXX has grown into a {$24000.00} financial burden that I should not owe. 

This feels like systemic abuse. This feels like gaslighting. I am a real person who has tried to do the right thingonly to be caught in an endless, confusing, and soul-crushing loop of lies, consolidations, and rebranded debt. 

I am demanding : A full investigation into how the XXXX consolidation loan was created. 

Proof of any consent I gave. 

Confirmation that my original loans were resolved in XXXX. 

Legal accountability for Navients actions, and oversight of XXXX role in continuing this harm. 

This is no longer about just a loan. This is about truth, justice, and reclaiming my name from a system that profits off confusion and silence.

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Problem with forgiveness, cancellation, or discharge
Consumer complaint narrative:
To whom it may concern, I am writing to formally express my deep concerns and submit a complaint regarding my federal student loans and parent plus loans associated with my degree in XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, which I earned in the year XXXX. My college career started in XXXX and was ended abruptly in XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. While I pursued this program with passion and the expectation of stable career opportunities, unforeseen and long-lasting circumstances have significantly impaired my ability to enter and thrive in this field. 

As you are well aware, the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX was one of the hardest-hit sectors during the COVID-19 pandemiXXXX, beginning in early XXXX same year I XXXX  The global shutdown of travel, hotel operations, events, and restaurants lasted well beyond initial projections, extending over four years in many areas. During this critical time, job opportunities became virtually non-existent, and many businesses in the industry permanently closed their doors. 

In addition to the lengthy disruption, the entire landscape of the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX has changed dramatically. The education I received is now outdated, with many of the skills and practices I was taught no longer relevant or applicable in the post-pandemic world. Employers now demand different qualifications and competencies that were not part of my original curriculum. Furthermore, the competition in the job market has intensified, with displaced experienced professionals re-entering the workforce and securing roles that would have otherwise been available to recent graduates like myself. 

I believe it is both unreasonable and unjust to expect repayment for a degree that has notand likely will notprovide the return on investment it was intended to deliver due to circumstances completely beyond my control. Like many others in my graduating class and industry, I am left with significant debt and little to no opportunity to use the education I paid for. 

Therefore, I am respectfully requesting a review of my student loan status and consideration for full or partial loan forgiveness under existing or new hardship, economic disruption, or borrower defense provisions. I am more than willing to provide documentation, including my graduation records, employment history, and proof of industry decline, to support this request. 

This situation has placed a considerable financial and emotional burden on me, and I hope you will consider the broader context and long-term impact this disruption has had on my ability to succeed in the industry I trained for. 

Thank you for your time and attention to this matter. I look forward to your response and am hopeful for a compassionate and fair resolution.

I am writing to formally dispute my federal student loan obligations due to a significant breach of my personal and financial information. My private data was compromised without my authorization, violating multiple federal laws designed to protect student records and personal privacy. 

Under the following legal protections, my information should have been safeguarded : -Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) : Ensures the confidentiality of students records and prohibits the unauthorized disclosure of personal information.

-Higher Education Act ( HEA ) : Establishes the responsibility of educational institutions and loan servicers to protect student data.

-Privacy Act of 1974 : Prohibits the unauthorized sharing of personal information held by federal agencies. 

-Breach of Contract : The unauthorized sharing of student loan borrowers personal and financial information with third parties, including XXXX XXXX XXXX constitutes a violation of the contractual obligations to protect borrower data. 

Given the severity of this data breach and the failure to uphold federal protections, I formally request the immediate discharge and cancellation of my student loan debt in full. I appreciate your prompt attention to this matter and look forward to response.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative: I was informed that since I was in school from XXXX XXXX that my loans were deferred and that upon graduating XXXX school my loans would be sent into the 6 month Deferment Grace Period. I noticed my accounts did not reflect this so I called the servicer ( EDFinancial ) and was informed that since I graduated then I would have that 6 month grace. I called back in month 5 to set up my schedule for repayments to start and was informed that I was never in the grace period. I quickly pulled up my credit, after I had just checked it 2 weeks prior with no marks on it, and my credit had tanked with late remarks since XXXX. I asked the lady on the phone at Ed Financial to please help remove those remarks and place me on forbearance for the moment. She said that she would place me on forbearance and that would removed the delinquent remarks off my credit. After 3-4 days I noticed nothing had changed so I called back only to be told the First Lady never even set up my forbearance. So again started the process and the I asked how long I could expect before seeing the delinquents removed and was informed they wouldn't be. I have been exceptional with my repayments and my credit. I had signed a contract on a house and applied for a new job which both run your credit for. I am being denied both job and home due to being misinformed by ED Financial and was never informed in any way that my accounts were going bad- by phone, email, mail, credit reporting or otherwise.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am on an Income-Driven Repayment ( IDR ) plan and submitted my recertification to Aidvantage. My application is marked as processing, but I was informed it can not be completed due to a court order. Despite this, my monthly payment has tripled. 

I explained to Aidvantage that the Department of Education extended IDR recertification deadlines until at least XX/XX/XXXX for all IDR plans not just SAVE and that borrowers should not be penalized while processing is delayed. They refused to adjust my payment or offer administrative forbearance. 

During a live chat on XX/XX/XXXX, an Aidvantage representative named XXXX made an unprofessional political comment, saying : Sorry for the inconvenience this is due to the president and his order which as we all can see is no greater than him. I found this highly inappropriate and irrelevant to my repayment issue. 

This behavior is unacceptable from a federally contracted loan servicer, and I believe Aidvantage is failing to follow both policy and professional conduct standards.

Consumer complaint narrative: I have already complained about my student loan servicer Aidvantage in XXXX. I was supposed to have been placed in a XXXX interest forbearance at that time, and since then I have been making payments but my balance owed has actually gone up. Attempts to ascertain the reason for this have been fruitless, including inexplicably being disconnected from chat due to " being idle for too long '' although I was not idle. I just want to know that my payments are being received and are applied to the balance owed in a fair manner and it is extraordinarily difficult to figure this out compared to any other financial institution I have worked with. Do I have the option to apply these payments directly to principle? Why has my balance owed increased?

Issue: Improper use of your report
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint against XXXX  due to severe and unjustified negative credit reporting that has significantly impacted my financial standing. My credit report was recently updated to reflect over 20 late payment entries from DEPT OF EDUCATION/XXXX , which has caused my credit score to drop by over XXXX points. This action was taken without any prior notice, warning, or correspondenceI did not receive any emails, letters, or alerts informing me of this drastic change before it was reported to the credit bureaus. Additionally, I have become aware of an ongoing data breach involving student loan accounts, which raises serious concerns regarding unauthorized access to my personal and financial information raising concerns over a FERPA violation. Given this security lapse, I have reason to believe that my account records may have been compromised or altered without my consent. I am in the process of purchasing a home and this has caused my loan to be halted until this is
remedied. This has caused extreme financial distress and this error in reporting needs to be remedied immediately. I did not authorize any changes to my account status, and I no longer feel comfortable having my student loans serviced and reported to the credit bureaus under these conditions.

Violations and Consumer Protection Rights 1. Failure to Provide Notice of Negative Credit Reporting - Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), loan servicers are required to provide accurate and fair reporting. I was not notified in advance that these accounts would be marked late, which denied me the opportunity to address any potential issues before they were reported.

2. Possible Unauthorized Reporting and Account Compromise Due to Data Breach - The reported data breach involving XXXX  raises serious questions about the integrity of my loan accounts. If my data was exposed or manipulated, XXXX  may have incorrectly or fraudulently reported late payments that I did not actually incur.

3. Failure to Properly Investigate and Verify Account Status - Given the security risks and errors in reporting, I request full verification and documentation proving the legitimacy of the late payments, including a detailed account history showing how and when they were marked late.

Requested Resolution - Immediate removal of all reported late payments from my credit report, as they were reported without proper notice and under potentially compromised circumstances.

- A formal investigation into ENTER YOUR STUDENT LOAN COMPANIES NAME HERE reporting practices to determine whether my data was mishandled or compromised. - A written response from ENTER YOUR STUDENT LOAN COMPANIES NAME HERE confirming the deletion of these late payments from my credit file. This situation has caused me extreme distress, financial harm, and damage to my creditworthiness. - I expect a prompt and thorough resolution in compliance with federal consumer protection laws. Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter.
