Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative:
In XX/XX/XXXX, reports confirmed that the Department of Government Efficiency ( DOGE ), led by XXXX XXXX, obtained access to sensitive federal agency systems, including the Department of Education. This access included student loan databases containing personal and financial data such as names, Social Security numbers, loan balances, and contact information of millions of borrowers, myself included. 

This access was unauthorized, and it violated the expectations of borrower privacy under the Privacy Act of 1974 and FERPA. In XX/XX/XXXX, a federal judge issued an emergency injunction blocking DOGE from accessing federal education data, citing risks of data misuse and privacy violations. Two investigative articles detailing these events include : XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX As a result, I submitted a formal dispute to XXXX XXXX XXXX ( case # XXXX ) in XX/XX/XXXX, requesting a full discharge of my student loans due to the breach of my personally identifiable information. I included supporting documentation, including Nelnets previous XXXX breach notice, and detailed my concern about the long-term consequences of this unauthorized access. 

XXXX replied with a generic explanation of privacy policies and closed the case without addressing the substance of my claims or investigating the potential misuse of my information. 

Actions Taken : XX/XX/XXXX : Submitted formal loan dispute to XXXX XX/XX/XXXX : Received generic response ; no investigation or resolution ; case closed XX/XX/XXXX : Filed additional complaints to public officials and now to CFPB Resolution Requested : Investigate the exposure of student loan data and borrower information to unauthorized federal actors ( DOGE ) Determine whether my borrower rights under federal privacy laws were violated Require FSA or the appropriate agency to reopen and formally investigate my dispute Approve a full discharge of my XXXX XXXX XXXX  balance based on the breach of trust, unauthorized access, and failure to safeguard my information

Subject : Request for Discharge of Student Loans Due to XXXX and Financial Hardship ( Veteran ) To Whom It May Concern : I am filing this complaint through the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau in regard to my federal student loans, which are currently in forbearance. 
I am a XXXX veteran with a service-connected XXXX rating of 80 % through the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs . I served honorably for XXXX years and currently work as a federal contractor. Despite my employment, I face substantial financial and emotional challenges directly related to my XXXX and the burden of my student loan debt. 
The continuation of these loanseven in forbearancecreates undue hardship. I respectfully request that my student loans be fully XXXX under the XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) XXXX program or other applicable veteran-based discharge programs. 
It is my understanding that veterans with a service-connected XXXX may be eligible for loan discharge through the U.S. Department of Education upon proper verification from the VA. I am seeking CFPB 's assistance in ensuring that my case is reviewed promptly, fairly, and with consideration to my veteran status and ongoing hardships. 
Paying these loans would impose significant emotional and financial strain, interfering with my ability to maintain a stable and healthy life. As such, I am asking for CFPB 's support in advocating for full discharge of my student loans or, at the very least, providing clear guidance to initiate the appropriate process with my loan servicer ( XXXX ) and the Department of Education. 
Thank you for your time, understanding, and for standing up for veterans like myself. 

VA XXXX XXXX available upon request.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am submitting a complaint against my student loan servicer for failing to apply disaster-related administrative forbearance during Hurricane Helene, despite having my correct address on file at the time. 

I resided in a FEMA-declared disaster area and was eligible for the automatic forbearance extensions provided by the U.S. Department of Education for borrowers affected by natural disasters. However, my servicer did not apply the forbearance to my account, and I was reported as late.

This inaccurate reporting has significantly damaged my credit and prevented me from repairing my financial standing. I have submitted disputes and provided documentation of my address and eligibility, but the servicer has not corrected the error.

I verbally requested a review of my account and a determination from the servicer on XX/XX/year>. I submitted the requested documents to their servicing platform to perform the review on XX/XX/year>. 

I am requesting that the CFPB investigate and ensure : 1 ) Forbearance is retroactively applied 2 ) Late payment entries are removed from my credit report 3 ) The servicer is held accountable for compliance with federal forbearance guidelines

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am disputing the legitimacy and enforceability of the student loans associated with my account. As you are aware, XXXX XXXX has signed an executive order to abolish the U.S. Department of Education, thereby creating a material legal void concernin

g all student loan obligations previously managed under its authority. Demand for Verification & Cease and Desist Pursuant to 15 U.S.C. 1692g ( FDCPA ) and 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( FCRA ), I am requesting immediate verification of the legal ownership, servicing rights, and validity of the alleged student loan debt under your authority. Failure to provide this information within 30 days constitutes a direct violation of federal law.

Furthermore, under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) and FCRA, I am demanding the following : - Immediate cessation of collection efforts until full legal verification is provided. 
- A detailed breakdown of loan ownership and servicing rights post-Department of Education abolishment.

- Written confirmation that you will cease reporting this unverified debt to credit bureaus.

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Problem with forgiveness, cancellation, or discharge
Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX To : U.S. Department of Education Student Privacy Policy Office XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX CC : XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, GA XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, TX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, PA XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, PA XXXX XXXX : Formal Complaint Regarding Data Breach, FERPA and Title IV Violations, and Request for Immediate Discharge of Student Loans To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding the unauthorized access and breach of my educational records, financial aid data, and IRS tax information by the U.S. Department of Education ( DOE ) and the Department of Government Efficiency ( DOGE ). This breach constitutes a direct violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and Title IV regulations, as well as an egregious violation of my personal privacy and financial security. 
I recently discovered that my sensitive and legally protected records were accessed and potentially shared without my consent. This includes but is not limited to : 1. My academic records and personally identifiable information ( PII ).

2. My Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) data, including financial aid history and loan information. 
XXXX. My IRS tax transcripts, which were obtained and used without proper authorization. 
These actions violate my rights under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), which grants me the right to control access to my educational records, as well as Title IV of the Higher Education Act, which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information. Furthermore, unauthorized access to my IRS tax data raises serious concerns regarding potential identity theft, fraud, and violations of federal data security standards.

Given the severity of this breach and the direct impact on my financial security and privacy, I demand the following corrective actions : 1. Immediate discharge and cancellation of all my federal student loans due to the breach of my financial aid and tax records, which invalidates the integrity of my loan agreements.

2. A formal investigation into this data breach, including details on how my records were accessed, who accessed them, and for what purpose.

3. A full report on the extent of my data exposure and the corrective measures being implemented to prevent future violations.

4. Immediate notification to XXXX  XXXX  credit bureaus ( XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX XXXX ) to place a fraud alert and investigate any unauthorized activity that may have resulted from this breach. 
This breach has caused significant distress and concern regarding the security of my personal and financial data. If my demands are not met within 30 days, I will be left with no choice but to escalate this matter through legal channels, including filing complaints with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), and pursuing legal action against the responsible parties. 
I request a written response addressing these concerns and outlining the immediate actions being taken to remedy this situation. Please direct all correspondence to the address listed above. 
Thank you for your prompt attention to this urgent matter. I look forward to your immediate response and resolution. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Issue: Improper use of your report

Consumer complaint narrative:
Formal dispute of inaccurate student reporting.

To whom this may concern, I am formally disputing an inaccurate reporting of federal student loan on my credit report. The account falsely reports payments being made for years, despite the fact that I have never made a single payment. this constitutes willful misrepresentation and a violation of the fair credit reporting act ( FCRA ) 15 U.S.C 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ), which requires furniture to report accurate information.

Additionally, per 15 USC 1681b, I am requesting full verification, including original promissory note with my wet ink signature, a full payment history detailing where these allege payments originated, and any contracts or agreements authorizing this reporting. Failure to provide these documents confirm that this information is unverifiable and must be removed per 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ). If this account can not be verified with requested documentation, it must be deleted immediately. Continued false reporting of payments extends the life of this account beyond legal reporting limits, violating the fair credit reporting act. Please provide resolution in writing within the legally required timeframe.

When my loans were transferred from XXXX to Aidvantage, I enrolled loans 1 through 6 in autopay. At that time, loans 7 and 8 had not yet been transferred to Aidvantage. Once all my loans were with Aidvantage, autopay was set up for the entire account. At no point was I asked to specify which individual loans should be placed on autopay, nor was I made aware that loans 7 and 8 were not included. 

I was never notified of any delinquency on loans 7 and 8 until I discovered it while checking my credit report. During that time, I was actively making payments on the rest of my loans under the assumption that everything was current. This situation would not have occurred had XXXX not gone out of business and the loan transfer process been clearer. 

I have never missed a payment on any of my loans, all of which have been on autopay. I respectfully request that the delinquency reported for loans 7 and 8 be removed from my credit report.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding the unauthorized access and breach of my educational records, financial aid data, and XXXX XXXX information by the U.S. Department of Education ( DOE ) and the Department of Government Efficiency ( DOGE ). This breach constitutes a direct violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and Title IV regulations, as well as an egregious violation of my personal privacy and financial security. 
I recently discovered that my sensitive and legally protected records were accessed and potentially shared without my consent. This includes but is not limited to : 1. My academic records and personally identifiable information ( PII ).

2. My Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) data, including financial aid history and loan information. 
XXXX. My XXXX XXXX XXXXranscripts, which were obtained and used without proper authorization. 
These actions violate my rights under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), which grants me the right to control access to my educational records, as well as Title IV of the Higher Education Act, which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information. Furthermore, unauthorized access to my IRS tax data raises serious concerns regarding potential identity theft, fraud, and violations of federal data security standards. 
Given the severity of this breach and the direct impact on my financial security and privacy, I demand the following corrective actions : 1. Immediate discharge and cancellation of all my federal student loans due to the breach of my financial aid and tax records, which invalidates the integrity of my loan agreements.

2. A formal investigation into this data breach, including details on how my records were accessed, who accessed them, and for what purpose.

3. A full report on the extent of my data exposure and the corrective measures being implemented to prevent future violations.

4. Immediate notification to all major credit bureaus ( Equifax, Experian, TransUnion, and XXXX XXXX ) to place a fraud alert and investigate any unauthorized activity that may have resulted from this breach. 
This breach has caused significant distress and concern regarding the security of my personal and financial data. If my demands are not met within 30 days, I will be left with no choice but to escalate this matter through legal channels, including filing complaints with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), and pursuing legal action against the responsible parties. 
I request a written response addressing these concerns and outlining the immediate actions being taken to remedy this situation. Please direct all correspondence to the address listed above.

To Whom It XXXX Concern, I am writing to formally dispute the validity of the private student loan ( XXXX ) associated with my name and Social Security number, on the basis of violations under the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) and the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( XXXX ). 

First, under 15 U.S.C. 1650, I retain the right to bring a civil action in any court of competent jurisdiction for violations of the Truth in Lending Act, which requires creditors to make accurate and complete disclosures about the cost and terms of credit. Upon review of my loan documents, I believe that the required disclosures were either : - Not provided at the time of signing, - Misleading or inaccurate regarding interest rates, total repayment costs, or - Delivered in a manner that did not allow me a fair opportunity to review and understand them. 

Additionally, I am invoking my rights under XXXX. If any educational records, including enrollment status or academic performance, were accessed or disclosed without my informed written consent in connection with the loan 's origination or servicing, such actions would constitute a violation of federal law. 

Given the above, I request the following : XXXX. A complete and itemized account of all disclosures provided at the time of the loans initiation. 
XXXX. Documentation of any and all educational records used to originate or certify this loan, along with proof of my consent. 
3. Immediate suspension of all collections and reporting activity related to this loan while this dispute is under review. 
XXXX. A formal response to this dispute within 30 days of receipt, as required by federal law. 

Please note that failure to adequately resolve this matter XXXX result in legal action, where venue XXXX be established either where the original loan transaction occurred or where the creditor is located, pursuant to 15 U.S.C. 1650. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. Please confirm receipt of this letter and address all future correspondence regarding this dispute to the address listed above. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX Furthermore, I did not give written consent for this loan information to be reported to any credit reporting agency. If such reporting has occurred, it is a direct violation of my rights under XXXX and XXXX.

I am requesting that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau compel the Department of Education to respond to my Borrower Defense application and provide a final determination.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative:
U.S. Department of Education\nFederal Student AidXXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX  XXXX To Whom It May Concern : RE : Formal Dispute of Student Loan Request for Review, Validation, and Discharge I am writing to formally dispute the validity and enforceability of the federal student loan ( XXXX ) associated with my name and Social Security Number, under the authority of the Higher Education Act ( HEA ) of 1965, Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), and Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ). I respectfully request a comprehensive investigation, verification, and validation of the origin, accounting, and legality of the aforementioned loans. Until such time, I request a hold on any collections, wage garnishment, or reporting to credit bureaus. 
Furthermore, in light of recent legal and administrative developments, including proposed executive actions to restructure the U.S. Department of Education and shift student loan servicing and oversight to other federal agencies such as the Small Business Administration, I seek immediate clarification of how such structural changes may impact the legitimacy and continuity of any outstanding obligations. 
Legal Basis for Dispute Higher Education Act of 1965 ( 20 U.S.C. 1087e ) : \nUnder this act, federal student loans must comply with very specific disclosure, servicing, and borrower protection requirements. I request copies of all signed master promissory notes ( MPNs ), disbursement records, and evidence of compliance with disclosure requirements. 
Truth in Lending Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1601 et seq. ) : \nAny entity involved in extending credit or collecting payments must provide clear, timely, and transparent information about terms, interest rates, and repayment options. I dispute whether such disclosures were provided or understood at the time of origination. 
Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1681 ) : \nIf this loan is being reported to credit bureaus, you are required to ensure that all information is accurate, verifiable, and complete. Inaccurate reporting constitutes a violation of my rights and may result in legal penalties. 
Administrative Procedure Act ( 5 U.S.C. 551559 ) : \nAny major change in agency structure, authority, or regulation ( such as dismantling the Department of Education or transferring loan oversight ) must be governed by due process and public rulemaking. Until such clarity is established, enforcement of loan obligations may be legally premature. 
Borrower Defense to Repayment ( 34 CFR 685.206 ) : \nIf the school or lender engaged in deceptive or unlawful practices, I reserve the right to pursue a full discharge under this program. I request a review of whether my educational institution is under investigation or has been involved in any such misconduct. 
Request for Action Provide full validation and accounting of the loan ( s ), including : Original loan agreements and disbursement records Payment history Interest and fee breakdown Place the loan in forbearance or administrative hold during the investigation Cease any collection or wage garnishment efforts Refrain from reporting negative information to credit bureaus Clarify any upcoming changes in loan servicing authority related to agency restructuring If this matter is not resolved within 30 days, I reserve the right to escalate my concerns to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), State Attorney General, and/or pursue remedies through legal channels. 
Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I expect written confirmation of receipt and a full response in compliance with federal consumer laws. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXXSSN : XXXX [ Last 4 digits ] XXXXnLoan Account XXXX XXXX ( Nelnet )

I was told from Nelnet and Dept of Ed that neither one had control of the loan and to contact the other entity. XXXX ignored my request to discuss the matter and instead sent me this link to file a complain. 
In a nut shell, I am being asked to pay {$320.00} for money that was NEVER USED! Yes, the request ( XXXX ) was processed, the first time erroneously and WITHOUT my ever knowing it and the second time I returned it within 2 months! I did my due diligence, I spent hours tracking down their mistake, was told that it was taken care of and yet, I am stuck with a {$320.00} bill for money that NEVER even applied/used/withdrawn etc. 
Please help me resolve this! I thought I had taken care of everything and yet, it continues. XXXX has not offered any help even though they are solely responsible and Nelnet keeps telling me they don't have anything to do with the loan which I can not understand their position since they issued the loan! 
Please, I am not trying to get away with anything, my wife and I have helped our children ( ironically three of them went to XXXX ) and they have worked their tails off academically and over the summers so that we would never have to borrow money. This was the first and will be the only time that we borrow and it has proven to be nothing but a headache and I feel as though it is not our fault nor should we be asked to repay anything since no money was used. 
Thank you very much for your time and effort on our behalf!

Issue: Improper use of your report
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint because my federal student loans, originally held and managed by the U.S. Department of Education, were reportedly accessed, managed, or shared with third partiesincluding private entities such as XXXX XXXX ventures and/or small business loan platformswithout my knowledge or consent. 

I was not informed that my data would be used, accessed, or transferred in this way. I have concerns about the legality and ethics of these actions, especially since this may have violated my rights under federal privacy laws and the original terms of my loan agreement. 

I would like a full investigation into how my student loan data was handled, whether consent was obtained, and if any of these actions negatively impacted my credit, financial standing, or personal privacy. 


I would like this issue investigated and a full explanation provided. If any misuse or unauthorized access to my student loan data occurred, I want it corrected immediately and any related credit report damage reversed or deleted. As well has having my loans forgiven.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally file a complaint concerning the servicing of my Federal Perkins Loan ( or NDSL/Defense Loan ) by HeartlandXXXX in connection with actions taken by the University of Texas at XXXX XXXX XXXX office . 

I was recently informed via a letter from the University XXXX XXXX at XXXX that my Federal Perkins Loan has been transferred to the U.S. Department of Education for collection. This transfer was due to an alleged default on my loan that occurred over 24 months ago. However, I would like to clarify several key issues regarding this situation that I believe constitute violations of my borrower rights. 

XXXX. ) Lack of Communication : I have never received any prior correspondence from HeartlandXXXX XXXXr was I informed of any default status on my loan. I was unaware that Heartland/XXXX XXXXas the servicer of my loan, and I received no notices about any late payments or issues with my loan. This lack of communication is particularly concerning given that I was unaware of any default status until the recent transfer notice. 

XXXX. ) Inaccurate Reporting and Default Status : My loans have been in forbearance, and they were in forbearance at the time of the alleged default. I have made diligent efforts to maintain the terms of my loan and was under the impression that my loans were properly serviced and managed during this forbearance period. The negative/adverse credit reporting associated with this situation is misleading, and I strongly contest the accuracy of the reported default. 

XXXX. ) Failure to Resolve the Issue with HeartlandXXXX : I made several attempts to resolve this issue directly with Heartland/XXXX  However, despite my efforts, the servicer failed to provide meaningful assistance or clarification regarding the status of my loan. This lack of support and communication has led to unnecessary confusion and hardship. 

XXXX. ) Violation of Borrower Rights : I believe that my rights as a borrower have been violated due to the failure of HeartlandXXXX to communicate with me adequately regarding my loan, the apparent mishandling of the forbearance status, and the adverse reporting of my credit. 

Given these issues, I respectfully request that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau investigate this matter and assist in rectifying the negative impact caused by the incorrect default status and the lack of communication from HeartlandXXXX. I seek the removal of any incorrect default information from my credit report and the proper resolution of my loan status in line with the protections provided to borrowers under federal law.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative: I am writing to formally dispute my federal student loans and request a full discharge due to a serious breach of my personal and financial information. My information was compromised without authorization, violating multiple federal laws to protect student records and personal privacy. Under these circumstances, I request the complete cancellation and discharge of my student loan debt, as my rights have been severely violated. Below are the key reasons for my request : Violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) ; My student records were disclosed without my consent, in violation of FERPA 's strict confidentiality protections, and breach of the Privacy Act of 1974 ; My personal and financial information were improperly accessed and shared without my authorization, in violation of the Higher Education Act. As a student borrower, my information should have been protected, but the mishandling of my data demonstrates a failure to uphold these legal protections, in breach of Contract and Negligence. The entity responsible for safeguarding my data failed to do so, risking my financial security with unauthorized disclosure to third parties.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
Unfortunately, I have found that I was taken advantage of by a textbook example of forbearance steering, as defined by the CFPBs 2022 enforcement actions against XXXX and supported by federal regulation ( 34 CFR 682.211 ( f ), 685.205 ( b ) ). 

Between XXXX and XXXX, I contacted XXXX repeatedly due to financial hardship. Rather than informing me of my eligibility for income-driven repayment ( IDR ) plans or the federal loan rehabilitation program ( per servicer obligations under Title IV of the Higher Education Act ), I was steered into a series of long-term forbearances. Customer service representatives pressed that I qualified for " XXXX dollar payments '' and that there were no consequences, and no other options were provided to me. 

When the forbearance expired around XXXX, I was contacted and told that unless I could afford an exorbitant paymentunaffordable at the timemy only option was consolidation. I was NOT told about IDR or rehabilitation, both of which I later discovered would have preserved my balance, avoided interest capitalization, and maintained progress toward loan forgiveness. 

As a result of this coercive consolidation by XXXX, my balance ballooned from ~ {$48000.00} to over {$85000.00}. It capitalized interest and reset my forgiveness clock. Since then, I have made over 151 qualifying IDR payments. 

Critically, the data shows that I was placed in repeated forbearances at XXXX 's recommendation during my financial hardship. I was not informed that these forbearances would expire or that they could lead to default. When my forbearance period expired, I was contacted by XXXX and told that my only option was to either consolidate or make unaffordable payments in excess of {$500.00} per month. This created a false urgency and removed any meaningful choice-no income-driven repayment ( IDR ) or rehabilitation plans were offered. This tactic aligns with the forbearance steering practices that were cited in the CFPB 's 2022 enforcement actions against student loan servicers. It was at that point, under financial duress and without being informed of legal alternatives, that I was coerced into consolidating, causing irreversible financial harm. 
This case represents a textbook instance of forbearance steering, as defined by the CFPB 's 2022 enforcement actions against XXXX and supported by federal regulation ( 34 CFR 682.211 ( f ), 685.205 ( b ) ). During the period from XXXX  to XXXX, XXXX failed to inform me of available income-driven repayment ( IDR ) plans or the federally mandated 9-month rehabilitation program, both of which were legal options under Title IV of the Higher Education Act. Instead, I was repeatedly placed into forbearance until its expiration, at which point I was pressured into consolidating under the threat of unaffordable monthly payments exceeding {$500.00}. This practice violated servicer obligations and has since been identified by the Department of Education and the CFPB as a systemic failure. My experience directly aligns with the borrower harms being remedied under the IDR Account Adjustment initiative ( XXXX ), which was implemented to address improper servicing, including coerced consolidations and loss of forgiveness progress. 
Through modeling and consultation with financial experts, I now understand that if I had entered a rehabilitation plan instead of consolidating, my balance today could be nearly half of what it is now. 
Rehabilitation would have preserved my original loans, minimized interest capitalization, and maintained forgiveness eligibility. I have attached a visual comparison of my current repayment path versus the alternative I was never informed of.

Additionally, I made a good-faith attempt to obtain documentation regarding my original disbursements, at the suggestion of my current servicer, Aidvantage. I was advised that with those documents, a balance review could potentially occur. I contacted the XXXX  XXXX XXXX  Financial Aid Office, but was informed that records were no longer available due to the time elapsed since graduation. Likewise, my prior servicer, XXXX, no longer retains access to these historical records. 
This systemic failure to retain critical borrower documentation, compounded by coercive servicing practices, has caused enduring financial harm. I believe this case exemplifies the very forbearance and consolidation steering practices cited in prior CFPB and state attorney general actions against XXXX.

I was informed I will be granted the forgiveness of the loan and it would be taken away then I was told the following : XXXX, This email provides you with an update on the one-time Student Loan Debt Relief plan that XXXX XXXX and XXXX announced on XX/XX/XXXX. 

We reviewed your application and determined that you are eligible for loan relief under the Plan. We have sent this approval on to your loan servicer. You do not need to take any further action. 

Unfortunately, a number of lawsuits have been filed challenging the program, which have blocked our ability to discharge your debt at present. We believe strongly that the lawsuits are meritless, and the Department of Justice has appealed on our behalf. Your application is complete and approved, and we will discharge your approved debt if and when we prevail in court. We will update you when there are new developments. 

The XXXX XXXX is committed to helping borrowers as they recover from the pandemic. 

Education is a great equalizer, and we will never stop fighting for you!

In XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, FL XXXX Phone : [ Your Phone Number ] Email : [ Your Email Address ] Date : [ Insert Today 's Date ] To : Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Washington XXXX DC XXXX Subject : Formal Complaint Against Aidvantage and Request for Investigation and Relief Dear CFPB Officer, I am filing this formal complaint against Aidvantage, the student loan servicer for the U.S. Department of Education, regarding their mishandling of my personal and financial information, resulting in violations of federal laws and my consumer rights.

Recently, credible reports have surfaced confirming that the Department of Education and associated third parties, including organizations tied to XXXX XXXX, engaged in breaches involving unauthorized access to and sharing of borrower data. These actions constitute violations of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ), which mandates the protection of student educational and financial records.

Given the severity of this breach : My private financial data has been compromised.

The ongoing servicing and reporting of my student loan debts are based on unlawfully mishandled information.

Aidvantage has failed to take corrective action despite notification. I respectfully request that the CFPB investigate this matter and that appropriate enforce
ment actions be taken. Specifically, I am requesting : Immediate discharge and forgiveness of my student loan debt serviced by Aidvantage.

Immediate deletion of any student loan tradelines from all consumer credit reports ( Equifax, Experian, and TransUnion ).

Written confirmation that all adverse records related to this debt are permanently removed.

Imposition of penalties and sanctions if violations of FERPA, the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), or other consumer protection laws are found.

Attached is a copy of my cease and desist notice and prior communications with Aidvantage for your review. 

Thank you for your attention to this serious matter. I trust that the CFPB will act swiftly to protect my rights as a consumer and citizen. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Don't agree with the fees charged
Consumer complaint narrative: On XX/XX/XXXX, I received an email saying my credit score dropped. When I opened my banking app, I saw that my credit dropped XXXX points overnight. I saw that the Department of Education was named on the loans, so I called the Dept. of Ed. on the XXXX. I talked to XXXX, asking about the loans, as I was unaware of any more student loans linked to my account because I did not see any loans on my Firstmark Services account where I had been paying off {$30000.00} in student loans. I made my last payment in XXXX of XXXX to pay off the {$30000.00} debt. XXXX told me it could be fraud and suggested I ask for forbearance until I could get the loans disputed. On XX/XX/XXXX, I called Firstmark Services to see if I could get any information about the other student loans that seemed to be causing the drop in my credit score. I saw no additional or unpaid loans on my Firstmark account. XXXX at Firstmark Services said that the loans causing the issue may be linked to the federal student loan servicer Nelnet. I then called Nelnet to ask about the loans and to verify if they were legitimately my student loans or if this was a case of fraud. XXXX from Nelnet told me the loans were linked to XXXX XXXX and XXXX University, both institutions I attended. She verified the dates the loans were taken out, which match the dates of my attendance. She told me I owe {$33000.00} total according to the Nelnet account. She said {$2800.00} of interest has accrued at this point. I also have late fees attributed to this account, which is why my credit dropped. She said the payments were due on XX/XX/XXXX. I asked her why I had never received a notification from them. She said they had sent an email, but upon further investigation, we found that the email was incorrect. I asked her why she never sent me a piece of physical mail or called my phone number to inform me about the loans, and she said she could only send an email despite having my home address and phone number. She then told me there was nothing they could do to help me, so I filed a dispute with Nelnet on XX/XX/XXXX. After filing an initial complaint through the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, I received a generic response from Nelnet on XX/XX/XXXX claiming they had reached out to me via phone and email prior to my payments becoming late. However, the response did not clarify where these emails were sent, or which phone number was called. I request that Nelnet provide proof of these communications, as I had never received any phone calls, emails, or letters from Nelnet until I shockingly discovered my credit score had dropped dramatically last month for what seemed to be no reason. Nelnet had not notified me of the late fees, and I do not know when they would have ever notified me if I had not investigated my credit score issue. By the time I uncovered the cause of my credit score drop, late fees and interest had already accumulated on my loans. Let me be clear : I received no communication from Nelnet until after I filed my complaint in XX/XX/XXXX, and as a result, I had no way of making timely payments on these loans. For context, I can provide proof of my history with Firstmark Services, where I consistently paid my loans on time and early. I can also provide evidence that I have always paid my car payments in full and on time I submit these facts as supporting evidence that I had no access to my student loans held with Nelnet, and if I had, they would have been paid on time. Additionally, since Firstmark is a division of Nelnet, I would also like an explanation as to why Nelnet did not send communications to the active email address associated with my Firstmark Services loans, which were being properly paid. If Nelnet had access to my Firstmark loan information and contact details, it is negligent that they did not use this information to ensure I was contacted through methods I would have received. I am employed and have no intention of avoiding my student loan responsibilities. However, Nelnets failure to provide me with access to my account has led to the accumulation of late fees and interest, significantly impacting my credit score. If I had been able to access my loans, I would have made timely payments, accrued less interest, and avoided these late fees. Nelnet did not respond to my complaint with adequate information and again was negligent in providing me with the information needed to access and pay off my student loans. On XX/XX/XXXX, I received a new response from Nelnet. Unfortunately, this response failed to address any of the concerns I previously raised. I would like to outline the shortcomings of the response in addressing my claim below : " XXXX authorized the transfer of your federal student loans from Great Lakes XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) to Nelnet, on XX/XX/XXXX. We have included a copy of the Welcome Letter that was sent on XX/XX/XXXX. '' This portion of the letter does not clarify the address to which the Welcome Letter was sent. I am requesting the specific address to which this letter was dispatched, as well as confirmation that I received it. Additionally, I want to highlight that the Welcome Letter Nelnet attached to the claim response appears to be from a webpage or email, but there is no proof that it was actually sent to any of my addresses, either physical or email. " While your loan was in repayment, we sent you billing statements each month. When your account became past due, we also tried to reach you in other ways such as calling and sending both email and postal mail to help bring your account up to date. '' This section fails to specify which email address, phone number, or mailing address was used to contact me during the repayment period and when my account became past due. I have previously requested dates of contact, proof of the addresses used to reach me, and evidence of my acknowledgment of the billing statements. " Per your promissory note, it is your responsibility to update your contact information to ensure that you receive important communications regarding your student loan account. '' I would like to emphasize that I was unable to update my contact information on an account I was unaware of, nor did I know that such a website existed for this purpose. Finally, the latest response I received claimed to attach a Master Promissory Note stating my responsibility to make payments despite never receiving a bill. The Master Promissory Note was never attached to the response. I have never seen this Master Promissory Note and have yet to receive such a document from the company.

Consumer complaint narrative: I took out a federal loan with XXXX during my college years ( XXXX ) for {$7000.00}. Upon graduation in fall of 2017, I set up automatic withdraw payments to my checking account for ~ {$70.00} per month. Unbeknownst to be, XXXX then shuttered and transferred my loan to Aidvantage. I, unaware of this company, did not receive any emails from Aidvantage because they went to my spam as I never consented to work with Aidvantage. They unenrolled me from my automatic payments for years, i assumed payments were paused due to the XXXX pandemic but would resume whenever the billing resumed and that i was accurately set up because I had always been on time with my loans and enrolled in autopay. Without contacting me, Aidvantage ( whom I had never worked with before ) resumed my billing but no longer had me enrolled for autopay. Without every contacting me via mail, they submitted my account as past due to the credit bureaus and significantly negatively impacted my credit score. I have always paid my bills on time and understand the importance of that. I was never made aware a. ) to whom I owed money b. ) when payment would restart, c. ) that i was 30 days overdue, d. ) that my autopay had been discontinued. This feels like a flagrant attempt to disenfranchise the American people by means of greed and deception. The IRS does not contact people exclusively via email, they mail letters. Why is the XXXX XXXX XXXX any different? Email addresses expire. Will we really be held accountable for not checking the spam from an unknown sender in a XXXX XXXX XXXX email address? I am XXXX of millions of American students who are suffering from their avarice and lack of communication.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am requesting that the late payment be removed from my credit report as reported by aidVantage. I have contacted them to request they contact the credit bureaus but they have refused, ignored and been belligerent with me. They have done me serious harm for something that is entirely their fault. 

They took my student loan from XXXX and even though XXXX had my correct, updated information, aidVantage was contacting dramatically outdated addresses, emails and I have no idea what phone number, if any, they had. 

So I had NO idea that my previously deferred loan was with this new company, was no longer deferred, and payments were due until XXXX XXXX alerted me to a XXXX point drop in my credit. In a couple days I paid everything outstanding and brought it to date and tried to find out what happened. 


In short, aidVantage was sending mail to addresses from XXXX on XXXX XXXX in XXXX. I lived in XXXX from XXXX through XXXX which I can prove, and have lived at XXXX addresses after this. I now live at XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and have for over a XXXX  months. SO none of their mail was reaching me. In the attachment you will see XXXX was sending mail to my house at XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX so aidVantage has no excuse to have used a XXXX XXXX XXXX address. 

I have attached proof that XXXX was mailing my current home and that any email to the address aidVantage claims they were using would have been bounced back to them- so that one they should have known was not being received. I also have attached proof that even my DL was at the address this company was using, so there is no reason for them to have using this old address.. 

Now my family could not even rent safe housing in XXXX due to to the negligence of this company. This is like the electric company sending your light bill to your neighbors and shutting of your lights when you don't pay! Now I am paying dearly for it in the form of drastically reduced credit score and will be for years to come - this is not right! 

I have attached evidence. Please assist me in getting this mark removed from my credit report. I have contacted the Department of Education in XXXX but since that department is now essentially gone, there is nobody to help.

Consumer complaint narrative: I have been really confused about how my student loans have been handled since XX/XX/XXXX. My loans have been in repayment since XX/XX/XXXX. I was on IBR Plan until XX/XX/XXXX, when I was told to switch to SAVE Plan by my servicer EDFinancial. I was thrown into forbearance status XX/XX/XXXX, with no clear explanation, or options given. I read in XX/XX/XXXX that I should be allowed to go back on IBR Plan. I tried to switch back to IBR, and not be in forbearance in XX/XX/XXXX. I called EDFinancial and asked about going back to IBR XX/XX/XXXX. I was told I could, and the woman I spoke with asked my income and household size, said Id get an email. I didnt receive any correspondence from EDFinancial. I got on students.gov account and filled out an IDR app XX/XX/XXXX, requesting to go back onto IBR. That application status is still in review to date. The IDR forgiveness tracker graph on the students.gov account said I had a little over 2 years left of repayment, until I reached enough payments for IDR forgiveness. I called EDFinancial XX/XX/XXXX and was told all IDR apps were put on hold because of an injunction with SAVE Plan. I asked why IBR was being impacted, since its not SAVE. There are 5 IDR plans, not just SAVE. I received no resolve with my application. Around this time, the IDR application form was removed from the Dept of ED website, which was really concerning. I called EDFinancial XX/XX/XXXX and inquired about my IBR app again. I also requested a copy of my MPN. I called EDFinancial again XX/XX/XXXX as id not received the copy of my MPN, and to ask about my IBR app. I was told theyd mailed the MPN, it was sent out. I received an email notification from student aid.gov that said IDR apps would start getting processed again to contact your servicer, I believe this was around XX/XX/XXXX. I logged onto student aid.gov XX/XX/XXXX, and notice the graph for the IDR plan forgiveness payments had disappeared from my account homepage. I called students.gov, and she denied knowing anything about what IDR forgiveness info I was talking about, she told me to call my servicer for information on my loans. She told me I also had to keep filling out a new IDR app every time they paused and restarting processing the applications. I was in shock a bit. I then called EDFinancial to ask about my IDR app ( again ). A woman spoke with me. I asked if my IDR ( IBR ) app was any closer to being processed. She said theyre behind, and its taking a long time. She told me the apps have been put on hold three times beginning XX/XX/XXXX with the last time they started processing the apps again was XX/XX/XXXX. She put me on hold when I asked what happened to my IDR repayment forgiveness tracker info that was on my students.gov account. She returned, and told me that as of Friday ( XX/XX/XXXX ) the Dept of Ed told EDFinancial they were not allowed to discuss IDR forgiveness payments with borrowers. I said that was preposterous, and I asked for a statement of how many months if been in repayment. I was told a statement of my payments would be mailed, and could take up to 15 days. I also asked for a copy of my MPN ( for the third time ). I asked why Id not received it, after asking for it twice already. She said it was mailed to me XX/XX/XXXX. She told me shed ask for another copy of my MPN to get mailed to me, and it would also take up to 15 days. She told me I should be able to see it on my studentaid.gov account. I asked why I can not access it on my EDFinancial account. I can not access it on my students.gov account, either. It says theres no record of my MPN on my studentaid.gov account. I asked her why my IBR application was still not processed as its been almost 3 months since I submitted it. Ive been in forbearance for 9 months when I shouldve been in repayment due to no fault of my own, a court injunction with 1 of 5 available repayment options is causing this issue. I also read that the court may have had an opinion on ICR and PAYE. This still has nothing to do with IBR or PSLF. I can not get a copy of my XXXX from EDFinancial, and it says there is not record of if on my studentaid.gov account. My IDR repayment information has been disappeared from my students.gov account, and I was told by EDFinancial that they could not talk to anyone about IDR forgiveness or payments that had been made to count towards that ( by the DOE on XX/XX/XXXX ). This doesnt seem legal. Its really confusing bouncing back and forth between the Dept of ed ( students.gov ) and EDFinancial. I graduated in XX/XX/XXXX. Ive been in repayment since XX/XX/XXXX. My eldest was born that year, and now as a single mother, I am trying to get him into university this fall. This is really stressful. Thank you.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally demand the immediate discharge of my XXXX XXXX in their entirety, and the immediate cessation of any collections or other financial obligations associated with these loans, due to the unlawful and unauthorized access of my personal financial records by XXXX XXXX and Dodge. The actions taken by these parties, which I have reason to believe were conducted with or through your departments involvement, constitute a serious violation of federal and state privacy laws, including but not limited to the Right to Financial Privacy Act ( RFPA ), the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ( GLBA ), and New Jerseys Consumer Fraud Act, among others. 

This unauthorized access of my financial data without my express consent is not only a breach of my privacy rights but also an egregious violation of multiple legal protections that safeguard consumer data.

I. VIOLATION OF FEDERAL PRIVACY LAWS Right to Financial Privacy Act ( RFPA ), 12 U.S.C. 3401 et seq.

The RFPA was designed to protect the privacy of personal financial information and restricts the unauthorized access of financial records by any government agency or third party. The actions of XXXX XXXX and Dodge in accessing my student loan records without my consent are a direct violation of this law. The RFPA requires that consumers be notified when their financial records are accessed, and in this case, no such notice was provided to me, further compounding the violation. 

Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ( GLBA ), 15 U.S.C. 6801 et seq.

The GLBA mandates that financial institutions, including student loan servicers, establish privacy policies and procedures to safeguard consumers ' nonpublic personal information. The unauthorized access of my financial data by XXXX XXXX and Dodge constitutes a flagrant violation of the GLBA, as it has failed to protect my sensitive information. The act mandates consumer notification, which was not provided in this case. 

Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq.

The FCRA regulates the collection, dissemination, and use of consumer credit information. Unauthorized access to my financial information by third parties, including any disclosure to unauthorized parties, violates the provisions under the FCRA. Additionally, the student loan servicers failure to inform me of such actions or to properly safeguard my data further compounds these violations.

II. VIOLATION OF NEW JERSEY STATE LAWS New Jersey Consumer Fraud Act ( CFA ), N.J.S.A. 56:8-1 et seq.

Under the New Jersey Consumer Fraud Act, it is unlawful for businesses to engage in deceptive or fraudulent practices, including the unauthorized access of personal financial records. The unauthorized viewing of my financial data by XXXX XXXX and Dodge constitutes an unfair or deceptive practice under this statute. I demand that you take immediate action to rectify this breach, including the complete discharge of my XXXX XXXX  as per the terms that would have applied had this unauthorized access never occurred. 

New Jerseys Data Breach Notification Law, N.J.S.A. 56:8-161 et seq.

Under New Jersey 's Data Breach Notification Law, any entity that accesses a consumers personal financial information is required to notify that consumer within a reasonable time frame. I have not received such a notification and therefore demand an immediate explanation of how and why my private financial records were accessed, as well as the immediate removal of any such unauthorized access and the discharge of my XXXX XXXX 

New Jerseys Identity Theft Protection Act, N.J.S.A. 56:11-1 et seq.

Given the unauthorized access to my private financial records, I believe this incident could also be considered an act of identity theft under New Jerseys Identity Theft Protection Act. Any action or access by XXXX XXXX and Dodge is a direct violation of my right to privacy and protection under New Jersey law.

III. DEMAND FOR REMEDIAL ACTION Based on the unauthorized access of my financial records by XXXX XXXX and Dodge, I demand the following : Immediate discharge of my student loans, in accordance with the laws governing consumer protection and privacy rights, including but not limited to the RFPA, GLBA, FCRA, and New Jersey privacy laws. 

A full written explanation from your department detailing how and why XXXXXXXX XXXX and Dodge gained access to my financial records, and what actions have been taken to rectify this breach. 

A formal apology from both XXXXXXXX XXXX and Dodge for their unlawful actions, along with their acknowledgment of violating my privacy.

Immediate cessation of any further actions relating to the collection or servicing of these loans, and the removal of any and all negative credit reporting related to this debt from my credit reports.

Full restitution of any fees or charges applied to my account as a result of this unlawful breach of privacy.

A copy of all internal communications within your department and with XXXX XXXX and Dodge regarding my student loan account and any access to my private financial records.

If I do not receive a satisfactory response to this demand within 10 business days of receipt of this letter, I will take all necessary legal actions to pursue civil damages, including seeking a lawsuit for breach of privacy, violations of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), and any other relevant claims.

IV. CONCLUSION Let this letter serve as an official notice of my intent to take legal action if these violations are not rectified immediately. I trust that you will take swift action to address this issue and make me whole for the harm caused by the breach of my privacy and the subsequent mishandling of my XXXX XXXX account.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Issue: Improper use of your report
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally submit a complaint regarding EdFinancial Services submitting my personal information to the credit bureaus without my written consent. Again, I express that EdFinancial does NOT have my written consent to report my personal private information which violates my rights. The mishandling of my student loan account, the unauthorized and inappropriate disclosure of my information, and the resulting negative impact on my credit report. 

According to EdFinancial Services published policy, they are only authorized by law to provide information concerning your education loan account to your school and the U.S. Department of Education ( for any federal loans ). However, my credit report reflects adverse information related to my student loans that appears to have been disclosed or reported in a manner inconsistent with this policy and without proper notice or written consent. 

This disclosure violates 20 U.S. Code 1232g ( FERPA ), which governs the privacy of student education records and limits disclosure of personally identifiable information without the students consent, except under narrow legal exceptions. I did not provide such consent, and I was not informed that my data would be shared with third parties in a way that could damage my credit. 

In addition, this situation raises concerns under 20 U.S. Code 1092, which mandates that institutions and their agents must clearly disclose all terms of student loans, including repayment obligations, grace periods, and the consequences of default or late payment. If I had not been properly informed of how and when credit damage could occur - or if disclosures were ambiguous or incomplete- this would constitute a failure to meet federal disclosure requirements. 

Under The Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S. Code 1681, specifically, the account reported by EdFinancial Services relating to my student loans is inaccurate and misleading and was reported without proper disclosure and authorization. The information on this account, including late payment history does not reflect accurate or complete information and has been reported in violation of FCRA. 

If I do not receive a response within 15 days, I will proceed to file formal complaints with the U.S. Department of Education, including the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) and the Federal Student Aid Group. I also reserve the right to pursue further legal remedies as needed. 

I appreciate your immediate attention to this matter and look forward to your prompt response. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Nelnet XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Re : Formal Response to XX/XX/XXXX Letter Unauthorized Access & Privacy Violation Account Number : XXXX Dear XXXX XXXX, I am writing in direct response to your letter dated XX/XX/XXXX, regarding my inquiry submitted to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau concerning the potential unauthorized access to and misuse of my federal student loan data. I respectfully reject your conclusion that Nelnet has not engaged in unauthorized or unlawful activity, and I reiterate the legal basis and evidence supporting my concerns. 

Statutory Violations and Oversight 1. Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 As a borrower, my federal student loan records are classified as protected education records under FERPA. Unauthorized access, review, or disclosure of my financial aid data without my written consent is a clear violation of 34 CFR 99.30 and constitutes a breach of privacy.

2. Privacy Act of 1974 5 U.S.C. 552a As a federal loan servicer contracted by the U.S. Department of Education ( ED ), Nelnet is subject to the Privacy Acts provisions. The act mandates that all systems of records containing personal data be safeguarded against unauthorized access or disclosure. Your statement that consent is granted only when lawful and necessary lacks documentation showing compliance with 552a ( b ) and ( e ) ( 10 ). I request to review audit logs and security measures related to this data access.

3. Breach of Contract I entered into a binding loan agreement with the reasonable expectation that Nelnet and the Department of Education would take all necessary steps to safeguard my sensitive data. Unauthorized accesswhether by internal actors, affiliates, or outside entities like XXXX XXXX XXXX as suspected ) constitutes a breach of fiduciary and contractual duty. 
4. Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) 15 U.S.C. 16811681x If any financial data or records were accessed or viewed by an unauthorized entity without a permissible purpose, that is a violation of 15 U.S.C. 1681b ( f ) and subject to enforcement by the CFPB.

5. Federal Information Security Modernization Act ( FISMA ) & OMB Circular A-130 As a federal contractor managing personally identifiable information ( PII ), Nelnet is required to adhere to the safeguards and audit procedures under FISMA and OMB Circular A-130. Your statement does not address whether security logs have been reviewed or if a breach report was filed with ED. 



Formal Demands Under Federal Law In accordance with FERPA, the Privacy Act, and other applicable statutes, I am demanding the following : 1. A full audit trail of all users and entities who accessed my account data from XX/XX/XXXX to present. 
2. Disclosure of any data breach reports or unauthorized access incidents involving my loan data.

3. Clarification of data retention practices, security measures, and breach notification protocols in line with 552a ( e ) ( 10 ). 
4. Determination of contract breach eligibility for discharge, per borrower defense regulations under 34 CFR 685.206 ( c ).

5. Legal basis for denial of remedy, if applicable, including why breach-based forgiveness was not considered.

Notice of Escalation If these issues are not fully addressed within 30 days of receipt, I will pursue further escalation with the Student Privacy Policy Office, Federal Student Aid Ombudsman Group, CFPB, Department of Education Office of Inspector General, and, if necessary, legal counsel. 

Your response, while acknowledging the concern, is legally insufficient. Nelnets duty is not only to comply with laws but to demonstrate compliance through verifiable actions and transparent reporting. 

Sincerely, Federal Student Loan Borrower

Issue: Credit monitoring or identity theft protection services
Sub-issue: Problem with product or service terms changing
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding the unauthorized access and breach of my educational records, financial aid data, and IRS tax information by the U.S. Department of Education ( DOE ) and the Department of Government Efficiency ( DOGE ). This breach constitutes a direct violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and Title IV regulations, as well as an egregious violation of my personal privacy and financial security.

I recently discovered that my sensitive and legally protected records were accessed and potentially shared without my consent. This includes but is not limited to : 1. My academic records and personally identifiable information ( PII ).

2. My Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) data, including financial aid history and loan information.

3. My IRS tax transcripts, which were obtained and used without proper authorization.

These actions violate my rights under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), which grants me the right to control access to my educational records, as well as Title IV of the Higher Education Act, which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information. Furthermore, unauthorized access to my IRS tax data raises serious concerns regarding potential identity theft, fraud, and violations of federal data security standards.

Given the severity of this breach and the direct impact on my financial security and privacy, I demand the following corrective actions : 1. Immediate discharge and cancellation of all my federal student loans due to the breach of my financial aid and tax records, which invalidates the integrity of my loan agreements.

2. A formal investigation into this data breach, including details on how my records were accessed, who accessed them, and for what purpose.

3. A full report on the extent of my data exposure and the corrective measures being implemented to prevent future violations.

4. Immediate notification to all major credit bureaus ( XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ) to place a fraud alert and investigate any unauthorized activity that may have resulted from this breach.

This breach has caused significant distress and concern regarding the security of my personal and financial data. If my demands are not met within 30 days, I will be left with no choice but to escalate this matter through legal channels, including filing complaints with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), and pursuing legal action against the responsible parties.

I request a written response addressing these concerns and outlining the immediate actions being taken to remedy this situation. Please direct all correspondence to the address listed above. 
Thank you for your prompt attention to this urgent matter. I look forward to your immediate response and resolution. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX XXXX instructed his team, the Department of Government Efficiency ( DOGE ) to gain access to multiple internal systems within the Department of Education, including financial aid dataset that contains the personal information of millions of students enrolled in the federal student aid program. My information was among that dataset that has been compromised.

Violation of FERPA and Privacy Act Rights Unauthorized Access to My Educational Data Dear Sir/Madam, I am writing to formally file a complaint regarding a serious breach of my privacy and violation of my rights under both the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and the Privacy Act of 1974 ( 5 U.S.C. 552a ). It has come to my attention that my personal and sensitive information, including my Social Security Number ( SSN ) and financial status, was accessed without my consent by individuals who should not have had access to it. Specifically, I believe that XXXX XXXX and XXXX  ( Doge ), a cryptocurrency-related entity, have unlawfully obtained and accessed my educational records stored by the Department of Education XXXX 
I have not provided any consent for such individuals or entities to review or use my data. This breach of my private information is alarming, and I demand an immediate investigation into this unauthorized access. 
As per FERPA, my educational records, including personally identifiable information, are protected from unauthorized disclosure. Further, under the Privacy Act of 1974 ( 5 U.S.C. 552a ), personal data maintained by federal agencies such as the Department of Education must not be disclosed without my consent, except under specific and limited circumstances. The act also outlines that agencies must establish safeguards to ensure the privacy of such data. Clearly, this breach represents a violation of both FERPA and the Privacy Act, and I believe that immediate corrective action is necessary.

The following actions are requested : 1. Investigation : An immediate inquiry into how and why my educational records were accessed by XXXX XXXX and XXXX without my permission, in violation of FERPA and the Privacy Act.

2. Clarification of Access : A detailed explanation of the process that allowed these parties to access sensitive data such as my SSN and financial details, in breach of the legal protections afforded to me under both FERPA and the Privacy Act.

3. Corrective Action : Steps to rectify the breach and ensure that such unauthorized access does not occur again in the future. This includes taking measures to enhance safeguards as mandated by 5 U.S.C. 552a.

4. Notification : Confirmation of the individuals or entities that have viewed or obtained my information and clarification on how my data has been used, in violation of both the Privacy Act and FERPA. 
I trust that the Department of Education takes these legal concerns seriously and will uphold my privacy rights in accordance with both FERPA and the Privacy Act. I expect a prompt response and resolution of this matter. Please contact me at the provided phone number or email address with updates on the status of the investigation. 
Thank you for your immediate attention to this critical issue.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Follow-Up to CFPB Complaint # XXXX Discrepancies, Fraud Concerns, and Inadequate Validation of Federal Loan To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to submit an updated and urgent follow-up to my complaint under case number XXXX regarding an alleged student loan serviced by Aidvantage. 

While the loan is claimed to fall under the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, and I have received a Master Promissory Note ( MPN ) as validation, I must emphasize that this documentation does not adequately validate the debt as legally mine for the following reasons : 1. Name Discrepancy and Identity Concerns The MPN Aidvantage provided lists the name " XXXX XXXX '', which does not match my legal name, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX used in all my official and financial documentation, including Secretary of State records . 
This inconsistency raises a serious concern regarding potential identity confusion or fraud, particularly in light of historical fraud issues related to XXXX XXXX, where this loan is allegedly connected. 

2. MPN Is Not Sufficient Debt Validation While the MPN is a required form under federal student loan programs, it does not, by itself, prove current ownership, standing, or servicing rights. It is a general form that anyone with identifying information could potentially sign, and does not : Prove I signed it, Confirm my consent to this specific loan, Show that the debt is still owed and collectible, or XXXX Aidvantage as a legal party authorized to collect.

Federal law requires debt collectors including federal loan servicers to validate debts upon dispute, especially where there are concerns of fraud, identity mismatch, or payment errors. 

3. Potential Fraud and Misrepresentation The MPN itself states under False Certification and Unauthorized Payments that borrowers may be discharged from loan obligations in cases of : Identity theft, Falsified signatures, Fraudulent certification by the school, and Situations where the borrower did not attend the school or did not benefit from the program. 

XXXX XXXX the institution linked to this loan has a documented history of irregularities and possible fraud. Given the time period ( XXXX ), and that I attended for only six months and understood the balance was paid in full, I am asserting my right to request : A full and itemized payment history, Proof of loan disbursement, Verification of the identity and authorization used to originate the loan, and A statement confirming Aidvantages legal servicing rights. 

4. Right to Dispute and Protection Under Federal Law As a borrower, I am protected by federal law, including : The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) ( where applicable ), The Higher Education Act of 1965, and The Federal Trade Commission Act, particularly in cases involving potential misrepresentation or fraud. 

Requested Actions : I request that the CFPB compel Aidvantage to provide : Full documentation verifying that the loan is connected to my legal identity ( XXXX XXXX ) ; Clear proof of loan disbursement and servicing rights ; A complete transaction and payment history ; Documentation to confirm the loan remains valid and unpaid ; and A response to the possibility of false certification or identity misuse under federal loan discharge conditions. 

Without this verification, I do not acknowledge this debt as legitimate or collectible. 

Thank you for your time and advocacy in helping ensure transparency and borrower protections.

According to 15 USC 1692 ( a ) ( 4 ) - '' Creditor '', [ Proves Consumer as the original creditor ] as the consumer answers the question " who created the debt? '' Creditor means ANY person who offers or extends credit, creating a debt or to whom a debt is owed. Also excludes alleged creditors because it does not include any person who receives an assignment. 
Notice : it is a fact, pursuant to 15 USC 1692 ( a ) ( 4 ), the term creditor means any person who extends credit creating an alleged debt. Consumer extended the credit which makes her the original creditor in fact and the holder in due course. 

Please, stop the harassing activity by all means-mail, calls, emails etc unless they can prove the alleged debt and who extended it.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
Thank you for giving me a voice to express concern and frustration. For the last 15 years, I have tried DOZENS of times to dispute the amount that the student loan people have been charging me. 

I graduated college in XXXX and my wife, likewise, graduated in XXXX. Shortly thereafter, we combined our loans. In XXXX, I even went through bankruptcy and was told student loans were off-limits. I am a XXXX XXXX and have good number-sense, so in the early XXXX 's, I felt that the interest and totals I was being charged for were inaccurate. I started making calls and got nowhere. 

Not knowing the details of the law, in about XXXX, I wrote a letter asking if this was something that could be settled ( like an IRS bill ), explaining that I was nearing retirement age and may be no longer able to pay the full amount, to which I never received a reply. 

In XXXX, my wife applied for and was approved for a XXXX discharge. After the payments were resumed, there was no lowering of the amount of our combined loan. I made several calls about this and asked for proof that my wife 's portion of the loans were actually discharged from our combined loan. 

In XXXX, they sent me a redacted promissory note that shows all of the individual loans that were added to the combined loan, but any dates or colleges that they are tied appear to be redated. I made literally dozens of calls since that time that got nowhere. 

When I bought my current house in XXXX and again when I refinanced in XXXX, I even had to have the student loan people verify to the mortgage loan people that my loans were in dispute so that I could obtain those loans. 

After my loan was transferred to another servicer - YET AGAIN - I asked for proof and they sent me the same exact redacted promissory note. 

Because of the runaround, and the multiple changes to my loan servicer over the years, it is my feeling that the student loan people have no way to actually prove the exact total of student loans, an accurate accounting of any payments I have made, an accurate accounting of interest accumulated, nor any proof that my wife 's loans were actually removed from the account. 

In the civilian world, this would be grounds for breach of contract and voiding of the loan ( s ). I've had several lawyers tell me I have an easy case to win, but I do not have the means to do so, so I am depending on you fine folks to make this situation right. It should not be legal for the government to send me a bill for a loan that they can actually prove I owe. 

Thank you for your time and effort.

Formal Complaint Against XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ( XXXX ) for Financial Misconduct and Misclassification Dear CFPB Representative, I am submitting this formal complaint to request your office 's investigation into XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ( XXXX ) for engaging in deceptive financial practices, student misclassification, and systemic failure to correct financial aid-related recordsactions that have caused me severe financial harm and appear to violate multiple federal statutes.

I notified XXXX of this error more than a month ago, yet they have taken no corrective action or provided documentation to confirm any updates.

Work with the Department of Education and relevant state agencies to ensure institutional compliance. 

Provide guidance on how I may seek compensation, student loan recalculation, or other financial remedies.

I believe this issue may impact many more students, and as such, I am urging your office to assess whether XXXX has engaged in systemic financial misconduct that has harmed consumers. 

Please confirm receipt of this complaint. I am available to provide documentation, including copies of my student records, loan statements, and correspondence with XXXX. 

Thank you for your time and attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX ID : XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

These actions violate my rights under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), which grants me the right to control access to my educational records, as well as Title IV of the Higher Education Act, which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information. Furthermore, unauthorized access to my IRS tax data raises serious concerns regarding potential identity theft, fraud, and violations of federal data security standards.
