XX/XX/XXXX Account Number XXXX Social Security Number. XXXX Borrower Name : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Dear Borrower XXXX You XXXX XXXX XXXX the XXXX Department of Education ( Department ) that you believe that a credit report incorrectly describes a debt you owe or owed to the Department. You contest the accuracy of the debt information as shown on the credit report, not as shown in the Department 's records. 
The Department discloses information about debts it holds, on a monthly basis, to XXXX  major national credit repositories, XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX & XXXX, as required by Federal Law : Sections 463 ( c ) and 430a of the Higher Education Act of 1965 as amended and 31 U.S.C. 
3711. Credit reports, even if they are compiled by local credit bureaus, usually include information from XXXX of these XXXX repositories. The Department is not responsible for ensuring that credit repositories or credit bureaus update their information in a timely fashion, but such agencies must comply with the Federal Fair Credit Reporting Act, or FCRA, ( 15 U.S.C. 1681 ). 
The Department is required to report defaulted debts to credit reporting agencies as referred for collections. If a previous servicer of your debt reported information to credit reporting agencies, that information may still appear on your credit report. You should contact the previous servicer if you have concerns regarding information that they reported. 
The FCRA allows consumers to contest information contained in their credit files at a credit bureau. To do so, send the credit bureau a written notice explaining the matter you dispute. The bureau must then investigate the accuracy of that information and correct any inaccurate information. If they do not receive verification or correction of the disputed information within 30 days, they must delete it. Consumers may also have the credit bureau include in later credit reports that the information is disputed. 
To dispute information you believe is inaccurate, send to the credit bureau whose credit report you dispute and also to the XXXX credit repositories a letter that states : I dispute the following information on my credit report about the defaulted Federal education debt owed to the U.S. 
Department of Education and that then describes the information you believe is inaccurate.Page XXXX The XXXX credit repositories are : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally file a complaint regarding the mishandling of my federal student loan account, which was originally serviced by XXXX and later transferred to Aidvantage. The lack of communication and accountability from both parties has negatively impacted my credit and caused considerable confusion and stress. 

When I attended college, I took out federal student loans serviced by XXXX. I consistently made payments on time and maintained a good standing with my account. However, in XXXX, XXXX ceased servicing federal student loans. After this transition, I was no longer able to access my XXXX account, and I received no further communication regarding the status of my loan or its transfer to another servicer. 

In the fall of XXXX, during a routine credit check, I noticed that my student loan was now being reported under Aidvantage. I immediately contacted Aidvantage and provided my information, but they were unable to locate any account under my name. They advised me to contact Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ), which confirmed that I did, in fact, have an account with Aidvantage. FAFSA informed me that I would need to contact Aidvantage again to resolve the matter. I did so, but once again, Aidvantage could not find my account. 

Fast forward to XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX noticing that my credit score had dropped by XXXX pointsI called Aidvantage again. According to my credit report, my account had been current through XX/XX/XXXX. However, by XXXX, it was marked as 90 days past due, which is not chronologically possible. To my surprise, Aidvantage was now able to locate my account. I explained the entire situation and was informed that they had been servicing my loan since XX/XX/XXXX. This was extremely concerning to me, as I had received no communication during that time to notify me of the transfer. 

When I asked why they couldnt find my account during my earlier calls in the fall, I was told repeatedly that they had sent communications via phone and email. However, I never received any such messages. The only communications I had with Aidvantage were ones that I initiated. It felt as though they were shifting the blame rather than acknowledging the issue.

After getting nowhere with the initial representative, I requested to speak with a supervisor. I once again explained the entire situation and asked if anything could be done to remedy the situation so that I would not be penalized for something outside of my control. The supervisor told me that Aidvantage does not charge late fees, and that the only increase in the loan amount was due to accrued interest. They were able to remove a pending {$200.00} payment so that my account would be brought current, although this did not reduce the balance of the loan.

I requested that the accrued interest be waived given the lack of communication and inability to access my account, but was told that Aidvantage could not do this, as they are only the loan servicer and not the loan owner. I was advised to contact FAFSA for any adjustments to interest. The representative also helped me regain access to my online account so that I could resume payments.

After this, I called FAFSA to inquire about having the interest removed. The first representative I spoke to stated that they do not handle financial aspects of loans and that only the servicerAidvantagecould address that matter. He remarked that it seemed like Aidvantage was mishandling my account, as evidenced by their earlier inability to locate it. He transferred me to another department that handles issues like mine.

The second representative I spoke to stated that Aidvantage does in fact own my loan and does have the authority to reduce or remove the accrued interest. She also told me that I could and should file a
formal complaint with the Department of Education via StudentAid.gov, as well as with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ). That is the purpose of this letter.

Upon conducting further research, I discovered that I am not alone. Many other former XXXX borrowers have experienced similar issuesonly learning of the transfer to Aidvantage through a credit check, rather than direct communication. I also found an article from the CFPB which details how XXXX was banned from servicing federal student loans and was ordered to pay {$120.00} XXXX for widespread lending failures ( https : //www.consumerfinance.gov/about-us/newsroom/XXXX ).

I have made every effort to resolve this matter responsibly and in good faith. I was unaware of the transfer, was denied access to my account for years, and was given conflicting information by the servicer. Despite finally resolving the account status, my credit score dropped XXXX points in less than a month and will take significant time to recover. This situation was entirely out of my control, and I should not be penalized for the lack of transparency and communication from XXXX and Aidvantage. 

I respectfully request that this matter be reviewed, and that appropriate corrective actions be taken, including the removal of accrued interest and a correction to my credit report.

I am in the process of purchasing a home and this has caused my loan to be halted until this is remedied. This has caused extreme financial distress and this error in reporting needs to be remedied immediately. I did not authorize any changes to my account status, and I no longer feel comfortable having my student loans serviced and reported to the credit bureaus under these conditions.

Violations and Consumer Protection Rights 1. Failure to Provide Notice of Negative Credit Reporting - Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), loan servicers are required to provide accurate and fair reporting. I was not notified in advance that these accounts would be marked late, which denied me the opportunity to address any potential issues before they were reported.

2. Possible Unauthorized Reporting and Account Compromise Due to Data Breach - The reported data breach involving XXXX raises serious questions about the integrity of my loan accounts. If my data was exposed or manipulated, XXXX may have incorrectly or fraudulently reported late payments that I did not actually incur.

3. Failure to Properly Investigate and Verify Account Status - Given the security risks and errors in reporting, I request full verification and documentation proving the legitimacy of the late payments, including a detailed account history showing how and when they were marked late.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Formal Complaint Regarding Data Breach, FERPA and Title IV Violations, and Request for Immediate Discharge of Student Loans To Whom It May Concern : I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding the unauthorized access and breach of my educational records, financial aid data, and IRS tax information by the U.S. Department of Education ( DOE ) and the Department of Government Efficiency ( DOGE ). This breach constitutes a direct violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), Title IV of the Higher Education Act, and federal tax privacy laws, as well as an egregious violation of my personal privacy and financial security.

Upon recent discovery, I have learned that my sensitive and legally protected records were accessed and potentially shared without my consent. This includes, but is not limited to : Academic records and personally identifiable information ( PII ), including my name, Social Security number, and educational history.

Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) data, including my financial aid history, loan information, and related financial records.

IRS tax transcripts, which were obtained and used without proper authorization or legal justification.

These actions violate my rights under FERPA, which grants me the right to control access to my educational records, and Title IV of the Higher Education Act, which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information. Additionally, the unauthorized access to my IRS tax data raises serious concerns regarding potential identity theft, fraud, and violations of federal data security standards, including the Internal Revenue Code ( IRC ) 6103, which protects taxpayer confidentiality.

Given the severity of this breach and its direct impact on my financial security and privacy, I demand the following corrective actions : Immediate discharge and cancellation of all my federal student loans due to the breach of my financial aid and tax records, which undermines the integrity and legality of my loan agreements.

A formal investigation into this data breach, including : A detailed explanation of how my records were accessed.

Identification of the individuals or entities who accessed my records.

The specific purposes for which my records were accessed or shared.

A comprehensive report on the extent of my data exposure and the corrective measures being implemented to prevent future violations.

Immediate notification to all major credit bureaus ( XXXX XXXX XXXX, and XXXX XXXX ) to place a fraud alert on my credit profile and investigate any unauthorized activity resulting from this breach. 

This breach has caused me significant distress, financial insecurity, and concern for the safety of my personal and financial data. If my demands are not addressed within 30 days of receipt of this letter, I will have no choice but to escalate this matter through legal and regulatory channels, including : Filing formal complaints with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), and the U.S. Department of Educations Office of Inspector General.

Pursuing legal action against the responsible parties for violations of FERPA, Title IV, and federal tax privacy laws. 

I request a written response addressing these concerns and outlining the immediate actions being taken to remedy this situation. Please direct all correspondence to the address listed above. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this urgent matter. I expect a resolution to this issue without delay.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Consumer complaint narrative:
On or about XX/XX/XXXX, MOHELA took over the XXXX student loan servicing duties. 
On or around XX/XX/XXXX, I received a letter in the mail that stated XXXX had transferred my loan servicing to Mohela and that my XXXX student loan account was 186 days late. Once I confirmed that Mohela was legally authorized to accept payments, I made the payment that was requested on the delinquent notice. 

Within a few days of making the payment to bring my account current, Mohela reported my account delinquent to the credit bureaus. Even after I paid off one of the two loans, they continued to report negative information. 

On XX/XX/XXXX sent them a letter explaining that they did not follow the regulations set by the Secretary of Education and, therefore, have violated my rights by reporting this information to the national credit bureau agencies without proper notice. In that letter, I also cited caselaw which read, the Secretary of Education has issued several regulations that articulate the standards for diligent collection of student loans. See 34 C.F.R. 682.410 ; 34 C.F.R. 682.411. For example, after a borrower misses a payment, the lender must send at least one written notice or collection letter to the borrower within 15 days that notifies the borrower of the delinquency. Mohela DID NOT SEND A LETTER UNTIL my account was 186 days past due.

34 C.F.R. 682.411 ( c ). If the debtor is still delinquent after 15 days, the lender must send four collection letters to the borrower and make four diligent efforts to contact the borrower by telephone ; one telephone contact must occur on or before the 90th day of delinquency, one must occur after the 90th day of delinquency, and at least two of the collection letters must warn the borrower that if the loan is not paid, the default will be reported to all national credit bureaus. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Student Loan Providers, Case No. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  Mohela did not follow any of these statutory guidelines. Further, their reckless actions caused my credit score to drop XXXX points ( from XXXX to XXXX ). The damage to my credit has caused me great hardship because I was not able to obtain the business loans and other opportunities that were afforded to me.

Issue: Improper use of your report
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX, enacted in 1974, is designed to protect the privacy of student education records, restricting unauthorized access and disclosure. Notably, XXXX does not XXXX individuals the right to sue for violations ; enforcement is the federal government 's responsibility. When i signed up for the income driven repayment plan it was a legal binding document recently A federal court issued an injunction preventing the U.S. Department of Education from implementing the Saving on a Valuable Education ( SAVE ) Plan and parts of other income-driven repayment ( IDR ) plans. The online income-driven repayment ( IDR ) plan and loan consolidation applications are available. My FERPA. XXXX XXXX was not and is not an elected official of the United States Government I am reaching out to provide important information regarding the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( XXXX ) a federal law that protects the privacy of student education records.

What is FERPA?

FERPA grants parents and eligible students ( those over XXXX  or attending a postsecondary institution ) the right to : 1. Inspect and review their education records maintained by the school. 
XXXX. Request corrections to records they believe are inaccurate or misleading. 
3. Control the disclosure of personally identifiable information from education records, except under certain permitted conditions.

Who Can Access Education Records?

Generally, schools must have written permission from a parent or eligible student to release any information from a students education record. However, FERPA allows disclosure without consent to certain parties or under specific conditions, such as : School officials with legitimate educational interests Other schools to which a student is transferring Accrediting organizations Compliance with a judicial order or subpoena. XXXX XXXX did not have XXXX order and or subpoena to have access to my student loan information.

FERPA allows schools to disclose directory information ( such as a students name, address, and honors received ) without consent unless parents or eligible students opt out. Schools must inform families of this policy and provide time to request that directory information not be disclosed. The legal due process was not taken

Consumer complaint narrative:
I spoke with a representative on the phone this morning XX/XX/XXXX at XXXX on the matter, but wanted to send a message as well using my own words and providing some documentation. 

I moved states and had two different addresses in the past couple years. I attempted to access my NelNet account several times last year online throughout the year to update my moving information, but the NelNet online account system was down for several months at least ( in hindsight, I recognize that I should've taken screenshots every time I attempted access ). I was also a XXXX XXXX up until XXXX of XXXX, which for months after graduating, I made multiple attempts to re-access my account for updating contact information and also to see the status of restarting loan payments.There are several internet forms online that show hundreds of other individuals experiencing the same difficulties accessing their online account. 
I had also previously set up a monthly payment plan with my student loans before they were paused. I had the same bank account, so I assumed whenever they restarted it would be withdrawn from my account as before. For some reason, they were canceled and therefore did not realize this either. When I could finally access my online account, I realize Nelnet notified me via account inbox and mailing, however due to address changes and no access to the online account system, once again since the online system was down, I never received this notice. 

I understand it is fully my responsibility to update contact information and to make timely payments for my loan account. I fully intend to abide by this loan policy, and otherwise have near excellent payment history with creditors ( attached credit report ) with the rare exception of an automatic payment hiccup- however, I'll always immediately fix the issue the moment I become aware of it. Upon discovering this mishap, I immediately made a payment to put my account current and re-set up automatic monthly payment plans. This will not be an issue going forward. 

I am currently in the process of searching for an apartment again, and I do not have a support system where I am, so I am heavily reliant on utilizing my credit score to find affordable housing for myself ( I have two pets which make it more complicated without good credit ).

Also I was not allowed to get a PXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  ), I was XXXX  for XXXX in XXXX XXXX

These records were accessed and reported without my consent or proper authorization, which I believe violates my rights under the FCRA.

Details of the Student Loan Accounts : Loan Servicer ( s ) or Creditor ( s ) Name ( s ) : EdFinancial Services Account Number ( s ) : XXXX Reported Amount ( s ) : {$110000.00} As a result of this unauthorized access, the student loan ( s ) listed above were reported on my credit report inaccurately and without my permission. I believe that these actions are in direct violation of 15 U.S.C. 1681b, which requires consumer consent for the access and reporting of certain personal information, including student loan data.

I request the immediate removal of these student loans from my credit report due to the following reasons : 1. The DOE records were accessed without my consent or proper authorization.

2. This unauthorized reporting constitutes a violation of my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). 
I kindly ask that you investigate this issue and remove the student loan accounts from my credit report as required by the FCRA. Please notify me once the investigation is complete, and provide a copy of any corrected information. 
If you require further documentation or clarification to proceed with this request, please do not hesitate to contact me at the provided phone number or email address. 
Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your prompt resolution of this issue. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
Company Name : Debteaze Category : Student loan assistance Incorrect information or unauthorized activity What happened : I signed up with a company called Debteaze that claimed they would help manage and consolidate my student loans. After some time, I found out through a direct conversation with my actual federal loan servicer, XXXX, that Debteaze submitted false information on my income-driven repayment ( IDR ) application. 

Specifically, they falsely claimed I had two dependents, when I have zero. I never authorized them to include this false information. I was never asked or made aware that they would be submitting that claim. 

I also requested a full refund, but they denied it even after I pointed out that their application was built on falsehoods. They now claim I only made one payment to them, but I have proof of additional payments. 

They are threatening to send me to collections even though their actions were misleading and potentially fraudulent. Their customer service insisted cancellation can only be done by phone, which I refused because their phone tactics are confusing and pressure-based. 

This company has caused me emotional stress and fear through misrepresentation and intimidation, and I believe they are preying on vulnerable individuals looking for student loan help. 

Desired Resolution : A full refund of the amount I paid- I have screenshots of bank statements to prove I paid several times to their scam business Removal of any false or unauthorized information they submitted on my behalf An investigation into Debteaze for potential fraudulent practices
Company public response: Company believes the complaint is the result of a misunderstanding

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding the unauthorized access and breach of my educational records, financial aid data, and XXXX XXXX information by the U.S. Department of Education ( DOE ) and the Department of Government Efficiency ( DOGE ). This breach constitutes a direct violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and Title IV regulations, as well as an egregious violation of my personal privacy and financial security. 
I recently discovered that my sensitive and legally protected records were accessed and potentially shared without my consent. This includes but is not limited to : 1. My academic records and personally identifiable information ( PII ).

2. My Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) data, including financial aid history and loan information. 
3. My XXXX XXXX XXXXranscripts, which were obtained and used without proper authorization. 
These actions violate my rights under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), which grants me the right to control access to my educational records, as well as Title IV of the Higher Education Act, which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information. Furthermore, unauthorized access to my IRS tax data raises serious concerns regarding potential identity theft, fraud, and violations of federal data security standards. 
Given the severity of this breach and the direct impact on my financial security and privacy, I demand the following corrective actions : 1. Immediate discharge and cancellation of all my federal student loans due to the breach of my financial aid and tax records, which invalidates the integrity of my loan agreements.

2. A formal investigation into this data breach, including details on how my records were accessed, who accessed them, and for what purpose.

3. A full report on the extent of my data exposure and the corrective measures being implemented to prevent future violations.

4. Immediate notification to all major credit bureaus ( XXXX XXXX XXXX, and XXXX XXXX ) to place a fraud alert and investigate any unauthorized activity that may have resulted from this breach. 
This breach has caused significant distress and concern regarding the security of my personal and financial data. If my demands are not met within 30 days, I will be left with no choice but to escalate this matter through legal channels, including filing complaints with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), and pursuing legal action against the responsible parties. 
I request a written response addressing these concerns and outlining the immediate actions being taken to remedy this situation. Please direct all correspondence to the address listed above.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint against MOHELA for mismanaging my federal student loan ( loan XXXX ), incorrectly classifying it as a Smart Consolidation HEAL Loan and improperly ending my in-school deferment, despite my eligibility under FFELP rules. This error, combined with their disorganized handling, is causing financial stress and potential harm to my loan status. 
Background : I graduated with a XXXX XXXX in XXXX and consolidated multiple federal loansXXXX HEAL loans ( XXXX to XXXX ), XXXX Perkins, XXXX SLS XXXX and XXXX subsidized Stafford loansinto a FFELP Consolidation Loan ( loan XXXX ) in the late XXXX. XXXX lists loan XXXX as FFELP Consolidated, and MOHELAs records show loans XXXX to XXXX as HEAL, {$0.00}, Consolidated and Paid in Full, confirming the late XXXX FFELP consolidation. Ive maintained half-time enrollment ( XXXX credits, cash-paid ) at XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX for over XXXX  years, qualifying for in-school deferment under FFELP regulations ( 34 CFR 682.210 ( b ) ( 1 ) ), which require only half-time status with no time limit. 
Issue : MOHELA insists loan XXXX is a Smart Consolidation HEAL Loan requiring full-time enrollment for deferment, a nonexistent loan type not recognized by federal regulations or XXXX. They set its deferment to end in XX/XX/XXXX without the standard FFELP XXXX grace period ( 34 CFR 682.210 ( b ) ( 3 ) ), unlike my other FFELP loans ( XXXX, XXXX ), which are deferred until XX/XX/XXXX with a XXXX grace period for XXXX clearinghouse verification of my half-time status. This misclassification began after XXXX transferred my loans to MOHELA in XXXX, likely a data error from the transition. 
Actions Taken : XX/XX/XXXX : I emailed MOHELA, stating loan XXXX is FFELP Consolidated, not HEAL, citing studentaid.gov and their own XXXX {$0.00} HEAL records. I noted XXXX years of half-time deferment by XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX ) and Navient ( XXXX ) and that loans XXXX and XXXX are half-time deferred. I requested correction and warned of Ombudsman escalation. 
XX/XX/XXXX : XXXX claimed # XXXX smart HEAL, promised a letter to clear things up after escalation. 
XX/XX/XXXX : Received a notice ( researching reply if appropriate ). Calledanother representative said # XXXX, # XXXX stay deferred ( XXXX a grace period ), but # XXXX ends XXXX ( HEAL, no grace ). She admitted # XXXX might be FFELP, apologized, but said Id need to call back for deferment if corrected. She noted NSLDS shows a XXXX graduation date and suggested a Summer XXXX class ( not my normFalls enough ) to secure deferment by XXXX. Theyre waiting a reply from a registry email ( escalation or NSLDS ). 
XX/XX/XXXX Email : MOHELA responded, reiterating # XXXX a Smart HEAL Loan needing full-time enrollmentincorrect. I replied, restating # XXXX FFELP Consolidated status, studentaid.gov, XXXX {$0.00} HEALs, XXXX years half-time, and demanded correction or Ombudsman action. Got an auto-reply ( high email volume respond soon ). 
Harm Caused : MOHELAs errormisclassifying # XXXX and ending deferment prematurelythreatens financial strain, as I rely on half-time deferment ( LAVC, XXXX credits, cash-paid ) to manage payments. Their disorganized responses ( waiting registry email, vague notice, auto-reply ) and inconsistent process ( unlike XXXX XXXX/XXXX  seamless deferments ) cause stress and uncertainty. Loans XXXX, XXXX correct half-time treatment proves # XXXX should matchMOHELAs glitch is unjustified. 
Requested Resolution : 1. Correct loan XXXX status to FFELP Consolidated, as per studentaid.gov and MOHELAs XXXX records. 
2. Reinstate in-school deferment for half-time enrollment ( XXXX credits, LAVC, Spring/Summer XXXX ), matching loans XXXX, XXXX, with FFELPs XXXX grace period. 
XXXX. Provide written confirmation of the correction and deferment. 
XXXX. XXXX MOHELAs handlingdisorganization ( XXXX Navient transfer errors, smart HEAL mislabel, delayed responses ) harms borrowers. 
MOHELAs failure to resolve despite my clear evidencestudentaid.gov, XXXX {$0.00} HEALs, XXXX years half-timewarrants CFPB intervention. XXXX prepared to enroll in XXXX XXXX ( half-time, cash-paid ) to ensure XXXX verification, but # XXXX misclassification must be fixed now to align with FFELP rules and my other loans.

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Problem with forgiveness, cancellation, or discharge
Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/year> Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) Complaint Against TransUnion for Failure to Investigate and Accurately Report XXXX Account Violations of the FCRA and XXXX XXXX Guidelines Dear CFPB Complaint Review XXXX, I am filing this complaint against TransUnion, LLC for their failure to conduct a meaningful and legally compliant investigation into inaccurate credit reporting regarding my XXXX student loan account. Despite repeated contact and documentation, TransUnion has failed to uphold its obligations under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and industry-standard Metro XXXX compliance procedures. 
Background : Over the course of several months, I have submitted multiple disputes and inquiries to TransUnion concerning the accuracy and reporting status of my XXXX account. Despite receiving XXXX vague, non-committal emails from TransUnion stating they are looking into it, there has been no evidence of a proper reinvestigation or corrective action, in direct violation of federal law. 
In addition to contacting TransUnion directly, I have filed formal written complaints and submitted evidence to : The United States Senate and Congressional Representatives The Attorney Generals Office The Consumer Protection Division The U.S. Department of Education, including the Office of General Counsel Federal Student Aid ( FSA ) Complaint Center XXXX and TransUnion ( via email and certified mail ) Furthermore, I submitted an application for the Loan Discharge Request ( XXXX ) in XX/XX/year>, which has remained in " review '' status without any decision, updates, or correspondence from XXXX. Despite this pending application, my student loans were allowed to default, severely damaging my credit and causing financial and emotional distress. I received no contact by phone, email, or postal mail notifying me of the default status. 
To date, I have submitted a total of XXXX XXXX applications and XXXX formal Discharge application seeking relief. None of these have been responded to or processed properly. Meanwhile, TransUnion continues to report inaccurate and incomplete information about this account without verifying its accuracy or properly documenting the ongoing disputes and discharge requests. 

Legal Violations : XXXX. Failure to Conduct a Reasonable Reinvestigation FCRA 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ) requires CRAs to conduct a reasonable reinvestigation when a consumer disputes information. TransUnion has failed to comply by providing no detailed response or outcome while continuing to report disputed data. 
XXXX. Failure to Maintain Procedural Accuracy FCRA 607 ( b ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ) TransUnion is required to maintain procedures to ensure maximum possible accuracy of consumer data. Reporting a defaulted XXXX account despite a pending discharge/LDR application demonstrates procedural failure and negligence. 
XXXX. Metro 2 Compliance Violations Under Metro 2 reporting standards, furnishers and CRAs must correctly reflect dispute codes, deferment/forbearance status, and discharge claims. TransUnion has failed to apply the appropriate codes or suppress reporting while the dispute is ongoing. 
XXXX. Negligent and Willful Noncompliance FCRA 616 & 617 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681n, 1681o ) TransUnion has demonstrated both negligence and willful disregard for the law by continuing to report inaccurate information and failing to correct or investigate the errors, despite ample notice Requested Resolution : Immediate reinvestigation of the XXXX account, with full validation of data and detailed documentation of the source. 

Immediate correction or removal of any XXXX tradeline inaccurately reported in violation of the FCRA and XXXX XXXX guidelines. 

Cease reporting any default status or negative information while XXXX XXXX and XXXX applications remain pending. 

An official written response from TransUnion outlining their investigation and confirming full compliance with legal obligations. 

Referral or enforcement action by the CFPB for TransUnions consistent failure to follow the FCRA and industry standards. 

TransUnion 's ongoing disregard for procedural accuracy and consumer rights not only violates federal law but causes serious, real-world harm. I am requesting the CFPB hold them fully accountable for their lack of action and require proper investigation and correction. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative:
In 2011, I enrolled at XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXn XXXX, Texas. Unfortunately, on the second day of classes, I was removed from the program due to an error in the financial aid processing conducted by the university. Specifically, XXXX XXXX  failed to properly account for my father 's per diem income during the initial financial aid calculation, which led to a determination that I did not meet the eligibility requirements for federal student aid. 

As a result, I was dismissed from classes by the university on the second day of attendance. I did not attend classes long enough to qualify for federal student aid disbursement. According to the U.S. Department of Educations Federal Student Aid Handbook, a student must begin attendance in all classes for which Title IV aid is awarded in order to remain eligible ( XXXX XXXX, Volume XXXX, Chapter XXXX ). Since I was removed from the institution before establishing meaningful attendance, I should not have been considered as having officially begun the academic period for purposes of loan disbursement. 

Furthermore, I requested documentation and clarification from XXXX XXXX  regarding this incident, but did not receive a response. I was informed that staffing transitions in the relevant department prevented timely fulfillment of my request.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing a formal complaint against Heartland ECSI for inaccurate and unfair negative reporting on my credit file related to my student loan account ( Heartland Key : XXXX ). 

Despite maintaining active autopay and making every scheduled monthly loan payment, Heartland ECSI reported me as delinquent for XX/XX/XXXX. This delinquency is unfair, inaccurate, and caused by servicing failures, not borrower fault. 

Here are the facts : I have made every required $ 40 monthly payment on time through active autopay, including XX/XX/XXXX. 
In XXXX, Heartland previously mishandled my payments they failed to process a payment despite my bank information being valid. I contacted their customer service last year through phone, made an additional {$40.00} payment by phone to cover any late fee or outstanding balance, and was assured that the issue was resolved. 
Despite this, Heartland failed to process my payment and again claimed a balance due from a late fee without properly charging my active autopay account or notifying me effectively beyond mailing letters. 
I reasonably believed that my account was in good standing because I continued to make my required loan payments and had valid bank information on file for automatic payments. 
At no time did I intentionally miss any loan payment or receive real-time electronic notice that additional manual payment was needed. 

Even if a small late fee existed, the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and servicer guidance make clear that borrowers who are current on their scheduled payments should not be reported delinquent solely for administrative fees. 

Heartlands actions failing to process payments correctly, failing to clear balances after extra payments, and then improperly reporting me delinquent are servicing errors that have unfairly damaged my credit score. 

I am requesting that Heartland ECSI : Immediately correct my account to reflect no delinquency. 
Remove the derogatory information from XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
Provide written confirmation of the correction. 

I am attaching documentation showing consistent monthly payments and my active autopay setup. I respectfully ask for CFPB intervention to ensure my rights under the FCRA are enforced and my credit is restored.

Consumer complaint narrative: I was a victim of Navient 's predatory lending problems. Navient failed to work with me at any point while my loans were in repayment to get me onto a plan that was Income Based. Chiefly the issue was that it seems the governmental standard of income to live in XXXX, or XXXX is apparently same same to live in Kansas or Nebraska. So despite me making just enough money to eat and barely keep a roof over my head and having proben it with tax returns, apartment leases, bank statements, Navient still thought I could afford nearly {$1000.00} a month in loans. For a long time this was more than my rent. It was laughable they assessed it was the same cost of living for me to live in the XXXX metro are as it was to live in South Dakota. No consideration made. So Navient agreed with me and put my loans in forebearance until I was able to work something else out. I tried over and over and over and over again to get them to develop a plan where essentially I could afford to pay less than {$400.00} or so a month, and even then I'd have to sell my car and take the bus to work but I was willing to do it and they could not get me into any plan that was affordable for me at any point and just kept putting me in forbearance over and over and over. I went to a 4 year in state university for my bachelors, and a 2 year XXXX XXXX at another in state school. The total tuition for both school together is less than $ XXXX for both degrees. Before Navient shut down and my loans were moved to XXXX, the were at over $ XXXX. More than double what it cost for me to go to school. I met every single piece of criteria for Navient 's lawsuit and class action relief. I received nothing at all. No relief at all. My account was put into the XXXX plan at XXXX XXXX essentially leaving me in limbo for years. I have not been able to get anyone to help me. Even though I am a victim of Navient 's predatory lending, nobody at XXXX XXXX XXXX has helped, nobody at Aid Vantage, nobody at Navient. I expect the government to disband XXXX soon which will put me right back into possibly my entire life being ruined, going into bankruptcy or something just as horrible if nobody will help me get my loans to a managable place. I dont think I should have to pay double, or lose my home, or go into bankruptcy because of Navient. I need help!

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Problem with forgiveness, cancellation, or discharge
Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding the unauthorized access and breach of my educational records, financial aid data, and IRS tax information by the U.S. Department of Education ( DOE ) and the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ). This breach constitutes a direct violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and Title IV regulations, as well as an egregious violation of my personal privacy and financial security. 
I recently discovered that my sensitive and legally protected records were accessed and potentially shared without my consent. This includes but is not limited to : 1. My academic records and personally identifiable information ( PII ).

2. My Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) data,
including financial aid history and loan information.

3. My IRS tax transcripts, which were obtained and used without proper authorization.

These actions violate my rights under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), which grants me the right to control access to my educational records, as well as Title IV of the Higher Education Act, which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information. Furthermore, unauthorized access to my IRS tax data raises serious concerns regarding potential identity theft, fraud, and violations of federal data security standards. 
Given the severity of this breach and the direct impact on my financial security and privacy, I demand the following corrective actions : 1. Immediate discharge and cancellation of all my federal student loans due to the breach of my financial aid and tax records, which invalidates the integrity of my loan agreements.

2. A formal investigation into this data breach, including details on how my records were accessed, who accessed them, and for what purpose.

3. A full report on the extent of my data exposure and the corrective measures being implemented to prevent future violations. 
4. Immediate notification to all major credit bureaus ( XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX XXXX ) to place a fraud alert and investigate any unauthorized activity that may have resulted from this breach.

This breach has caused significant distress and concern regarding the security of my personal and financial data. If my demands are not met within 30 days, I will be left with no choice but to escalate this matter through legal channels, including filing complaints with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), and pursuing legal action against the responsible parties. 
I request a written response addressing these concerns and outlining the immediate actions being taken to remedy this situation. Please direct all correspondence to the address listed above. 
Thank you for your prompt attention to this urgent matter. I look forward to your immediate response and resolution. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Issue: Incorrect information on your report
Sub-issue: Personal information incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX, I was shocked to discover a significant drop in my credit scorefrom XXXX to XXXX. Assuming there was fraudulent activity, I immediately filed a report with XXXX to investigate. The report revealed that Nelnet had posted 16 delinquent payments to my accountall on the same day. 

Confused, I contacted Nelnet and learned that they had taken over my student loans from Great Lakes. Under Great Lakes, I was enrolled in an income-driven deferment program due to unemployment, meaning I was not required to make payments. However, when Nelnet assumed control of my loans, they removed my deferment status without notifying me. Complicating matters further, I had originally three loans with Great Lakes, but Nelnet reorganized them into 16 separate accounts, drastically increasing the impact of their reporting. 

Since I had moved out of state, I never received any mail from Nelnet, leaving me completely unaware of the situation. I was also unable to set up an online account with them initially, as my address did not match what they had on file. After persistent efforts, I finally gained access to my Nelnet account and started receiving correspondence. 

Adding to my frustration, I discovered that Nelnet is currently facing multiple class-action lawsuits for similar issues. When I asked them for details about my loan transition, they could not provide any information about my original Great Lakes balances or interest rates. Since Great Lakes is no longer in service, I have no way of verifying my previous records. 

I have formally disputed the delinquent payments with XXXX, as I was never informed of them, yet Nelnet refuses to remove them. For 16 years, I maintained an excellent credit history, and this sudden, unjust drop in my score is now severely impacting my ability to demonstrate creditworthiness.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Detailed Timeline and Description : XXXX XXXX : I received an email communication from XXXX offering a {$500.00} bonus for refinancing my student loans with them. 


Prior to XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX ) : Before applying, I carefully reviewed the terms and conditions of the {$500.00} bonus offer. To ensure eligibility, I contacted XXXX customer service directly on XXXX separate occasions and confirmed both times that I qualified for the promotion based on its terms. 


XX/XX/XXXX : Based solely on the availability of the {$500.00} bonus and the multiple confirmations of my eligibility, I applied for and was approved for a student loan refinance with XXXX. I understood this would result in a hard inquiry on my credit report, which I accepted only because of the value of the promised bonus. 


XXXX - XX/XX/XXXX : The bonus was not received within the expected timeframe ( typically mentioned in the offer terms, often XXXX days post-disbursement ). 


XX/XX/XXXX : I contacted XXXX customer service via phone to inquire about the missing {$500.00} bonus. During a lengthy call, the SoFi representative explicitly confirmed my eligibility for the bonus and stated that I would receive it in my account in early XX/XX/XXXX. I relied on this information. 


XXXX XXXX : The bonus was still not received by XXXX. 


XX/XX/XXXX : I contacted XXXX customer service again. During this call, I was informed by the representative that I was not eligible for the {$500.00} sign-up bonus, directly contradicting the information provided to me prior to application and during the XX/XX/XXXX call. I requested that XXXX review the recording of my XX/XX/XXXX call to verify the confirmation I received from their representative. 


Ongoing : I have spent numerous hours contacting XXXX attempting to resolve this issue, receiving conflicting information from their representatives. 


Unfair/Deceptive Practices : SoFi induced me to refinance my student loan ( and incur a hard credit inquiry ) based on a specific monetary offer ( {$500.00} bonus ). They confirmed my eligibility twice before I applied. After I completed the refinance and waited the required period, they failed to pay the bonus. Furthermore, a SoFi representative confirmed the bonus would be paid on a specific timeline ( early XX/XX/XXXX ), only for the company to later reverse this position and deny eligibility. This constitutes a bait-and-switch and a failure to honor promotional terms and subsequent confirmations by their own staff.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX XXXX instructed his team of Department XXXX  Government Efficiency ( DOGE ) to gain access to multiple internal systems within the Department of Education, including financial aid dataset that contains the personal information of millions of students enrolled in the federal student aid program. My information was among that dataset that has been compromised. 

Dear CFPB, I am writing to formally dispute my federal student loans and request a full discharge due to a serious breach of my personal and financial information. My information was compromised without my authorization, which violates multiple federal laws designed to protect student records and personal privacy. 

Under these circumstances, I request the immediate cancellation and discharge of my student loan debt in full, as my rights have been severely violated. Below are the key reasons for my request : Violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) : My student records were disclosed without my consent, violating FERPAs strict confidentiality protections.

Breach of the Privacy Act of 1974 : My personal and financial information was improperly accessed and shared without my authorization, violating my privacy rights under federal law.

Violation of the Higher Education Act : As a student loan borrower, my information should have been protected, but the mishandling of my data demonstrates a failure to uphold these legal protections.

Breach of Contract and Negligence : The entity responsible for safeguarding my data failed to do so, putting my financial security at risk.

Unauthorized Disclosure to Third Parties : It has come to my attention that personal borrower information has been shared with unauthorized entities, including XXXX XXXX, constituting a severe breach of trust and professional responsibility. 

These violations have caused significant distress and potential long-term harm to my creditworthiness and financial future. I am requesting the following actions be taken immediately : 1. Full discharge and cancellation of all associated student loan debt.

2. Immediate removal of this account from all credit reporting agencies.

3. A full investigation and explanation regarding how my data was mishandled, including all parties who had access to or received my information.

4. Written confirmation of the outcome of this dispute.

Please consider this letter a formal complaint and request under all applicable federal protections. I expect a timely and comprehensive response in accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), the Privacy Act, and any other relevant legislation. 

If no resolution is provided, I reserve the right to escalate this matter to the U.S. Department of Education, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), and other appropriate legal channels. 

Thank you for your attention to this serious matter. I look forward to your swift and just resolution. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) XXXX

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer

Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom It May Concern : This matter is directly connected to the following formal complaints I filed with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) regarding unlawful actions taken by Aidvantage and the U.S. Department of Education : Case # XXXX # XXXX # XXXX Each of these complaints documents a repeated and systemic failure by your organization to act in good faith, comply with federal lending laws or provide proper validation of the alleged debt. Despite my numerous attempts to resolve the issue through lawful channels, Aidvantage and the Department of Education have continued to enforce a debt that is both factually and legally invalid. This is no longer a mere disputeit is a documented pattern of unlawful enforcement and ongoing harm. 
I am issuing this legal notice to put your office on formal record. This student loan account, allegedly serviced by Aidvantage, does not belong to me. The contract associated with the account is not legally binding, and I reject any attempt to attach it to my name or financial records.

Key Legal Violations and Supporting Facts : 1. The Account Was Paid in Full and the School Committed Fraud The alleged loan was fully paid in 2008.

The school that received the funds was shut down for fraud, which qualifies the loan for full discharge under Borrower Defense to Repayment ( 34 CFR 685.206 ). 
Despite this, your office has continued to report and enforce this invalid account for over 15 years, which constitutes consumer abuse and actionable federal harm. 
XXXX. The Promissory Note Is Fraudulent and Unenforceable The promissory note does not contain my legal name and was not signed by me. 
I never consented to the terms and conditions of repayment. 
No repayment schedule, interest rate, or total obligation was disclosed to me as required by the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA 1631 ).

A contract can not be enforced without mutual agreement, full disclosure, and proof of consent.

3. No Legal Validation or Verification Provided I have repeatedly requested all documents required by law to validate the debt. You have failed to provide : A wet-ink original signed contract, A lawful chain of assignment, A complete disbursement history, Or any verifiable proof that I owe this alleged debt. Under FCRA 1681s-2, reporting unverifiable deb
t is illegal.

Under RESPA 2605 ( e ), failure to respond to a Qualified Written Request is a federal violation.

4. I Will Not Submit a Fraud ReportThis Is Not My Debt Demanding that I file a police report or fraud affidavit implies guilt for an act I did not commit. 
I will not file any document that could be used against me to legitimize a false claim. 
Under the XXXX Amendment, I can not be compelled to make any self-incriminating statement. 
The burden of proof lies on the creditornot the consumer. 
XXXX. XXXX XXXX and XXXX Protocols Violated The account is not being reported in compliance with the XXXX XXXX credit reporting format. 
The dispute has not been resolved using the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( CDIA ) XXXX protocol. 
You are knowingly and willfully misreporting a legally disputed and invalid debt. 
XXXX. Continuous Damage Since 2008 Legal Basis for Federal Suit I have experienced financial loss, credit damage, emotional distress, and ongoing harm due to your illegal enforcement. 
You are in violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ), and the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act ( RESPA ). 
I reserve the right to file a federal lawsuit and pursue maximum civil damages and injunctive relief. 
Formal Legal Demands : Cease and desist all collection and enforcement activities immediately. 
Discharge and void the alleged loan account under applicable federal law. 
Permanently remove any reference to this account from my credit reports with XX/XX/XXXX 
Provide written confirmation within XXXX business days that the account has been removed and no further actions will be taken. 
Issue a formal written apology acknowledging the error, harm, and unlawful conduct.

Final Notice : I reserve all rights under UCC 1-308 without prejudice. Any further contact, reporting, or enforcement efforts regarding this matter will be considered willful violations of federal law and will be met with appropriate legal action

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX a XXXX XXXX XXXX, Ga XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Subject : Formal Complaint Regarding Violations of 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( FCRA ) and FERPA To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally file a complaint regarding what I believe to be clear violations of both federal statutes under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), codified at 15 U.S.C. 1681, and the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ).

Specifically, I have become aware that my sensitive personal and educational information has been improperly accessed, used, and/or disclosed without my consent. The following concerns are at the center of this complaint : 1. Violation of 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( FCRA ) : My consumer report information appears to have been accessed or shared without permissible purpose, in direct violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act. 
I did not provide consent for such inquiries or disclosures, and I was not notified of these actions as required by law.

Inaccurate information may have been reported and/or used in decision-making processes affecting my creditworthiness, employment opportunities, or other vital matters, constituting a breach of my rights under the FCRA.

2. Violation of FERPA : My educational records, or personally identifiable information contained within them, appear to have been disclosed without my explicit written consent.

These unauthorized disclosures violate FERPA regulations, which mandate that such information remains confidential unless prior consent is provided or unless a specific exception applies. 
To date, I have not been provided with any satisfactory explanation or record of these disclosures, despite my request for full access and accounting of my education records as FERPA entitles me.

The mishandling of my personal, financial, and educational information has caused me significant distress and has potentially impacted my opportunities and reputation. I respectfully request that the responsible parties conduct a full and immediate investigation into these violations. I also request that I be provided with : A full accounting of any and all instances in which my records and personal data were accessed, shared, or used.

Remediation of any inaccurate or improperly disclosed information.

Assurance of compliance with federal law moving forward, including corrective action plans.

Please consider this letter a formal complaint. If necessary, I am prepared to escalate this matter to the appropriate regulatory authorities, including the U.S. Department of Education for FERPA violations and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) for FCRA violations.

I appreciate your prompt attention to this serious matter and expect a written response within [ 15/30 ] days of receipt of this letter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Issue: Incorrect information on your report

Consumer complaint narrative:
To : Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) Subject : Formal Complaint Against MOHELA for Improper Collection and Credit Reporting During Federal Pause Dear CFPB, I am writing to file a formal complaint against MOHELA regarding their handling of my federal student loan account, including attempts to collect payment during the federally mandated payment pause, improper credit reporting, and failure to provide notice of a loan servicer transfer. 

Despite the federal student loan forbearance in place at the timewhich clearly paused payments, interest, and collection activitiesMOHELA attempted to collect payment from me. This action was in direct conflict with the terms of the federal pause. Furthermore, my loan account has since been negatively reported to credit bureaus based on these improper collection attempts, causing harm to my credit standing. 

To make matters worse, my loan was transferred from a previous servicer to MOHELA without my knowledge or consent, and I did not receive any official notification of the transfer. As a result, I was left unaware of any changes in account status or payment expectations, further complicating the situation and increasing the potential for errors and misunderstandings. 

These actions by MOHELA appear to violate consumer protections and the terms of the federal student loan relief measures. I am requesting that the CFPB investigate this matter, ensure any inaccurate credit reporting is corrected, and hold MOHELA accountable for any non-compliant or deceptive practices. 

Please let me know what additional documentation or information you may require from me to move forward with this complaint. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX il XXXX XXXX XXXX

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative:
Thank you for reviewing my concerns. I respectfully disagree with the assertion that nothing was reported late on Aidvantages end, as it disregards the core issue : incorrect and inconsistent reporting of my repayment start date. 

My final coursework in the University XXXX  Georgia XXXX XXXX program concluded in summer XXXX, and my degree was conferred on XX/XX/XXXX. Despite this, Aidvantage incorrectly relied on a XX/XX/XXXX graduation date, as reported in an earlier data transfer, and initiated repayment with a due date of XXXX XXXXwithout verifying the updated NSLDS information. This misalignment led to the wrongful early start of my repayment period. 

I proactively worked with the University of Georgia to correct the record. On XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX, Senior Assistant Registrar, confirmed that UGA  manually updated the graduation date in the NSLDS Clearinghouse to reflect my summer XXXX graduation term. This means Aidvantage has access to the correct data and still failed to adjust my grace period or repayment terms accordingly. 

Aidvantages statement that " there is no negative reporting '' is misleading. While they may not have marked payments as formally delinquent, the incorrect repayment start date has affected the accounts age, status, and monthly payment history, which are critical components of credit scoring models used by mortgage underwriters, financial institutions, etc. The impact is not limited to delinquencyaccuracy matters. 

Despite calls and emails, including my direct outreach to my assigned representative, XXXX, I have not received confirmation that : Aidvantage received and processed the corrected NSLDS data ; My grace period has been properly reinstated ; My repayment start date has been realigned with the correct graduation date ; My credit file has been updated to reflect these changes. 

Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), furnishers of credit information have a legal obligation to report accurate and complete information. Whether a late payment is marked or not, the inaccurate reporting of account status, timing, or terms still constitutes a violation of that obligation.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative:
Trying to relieve my father 's financial burden, I linked my bank account to pay the Parent Plus loans that were under his name. On XX/XX/XXXX, my father, the borrower of a Parent PLUS loan for my college education, passed away. The loan, managed by Nelnet, was eligible for discharge upon his death, per federal student loan rules. His death certificate was sent to the company after grieving, however there was a problem with the discharge that I was not made aware of. Automatic payments continued to be withdrawn from my personal bank account, which I had linked to the loan years earlier to help my father with payments, and I didn't notice them amongst the other student loan payments that were under my name. Between XX/XX/XXXX, and XX/XX/XXXX, I paid a total of {$9100.00} on the loan, despite it being dischargeable.

I have screenshots of the withdrawals from my bank account and the servicers receipts confirming these payments, which I can provide. The loan was discharged on XX/XX/XXXX, but the servicer did not refund the payments I made after my fathers death. I contacted Nelnet multiple times to remedy this. On XX/XX/XXXX, I requested a refund of the {$9100.00}, explaining that I paid from my account unknowingly on a discharged loan. They denied my request to refund the bank account being drawn from because they said it had to be sent to the estate despite the funds not being drawn from my late father 's estate. They sent a check which can not be cashed, but this is not a sufficient solution.

These payments were not my legal obligation, as I was not the borrower, and my fathers estate is closed with no assets. The {$9100.00} overpayment has caused me financial strain. I request that Nelnet refund me the full amount, supported by my evidence of payments made after XX/XX/XXXX. Please help assist me in resolving this issue promptly.

Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally dispute the inaccurate and inconsistent reporting of my federal student loan balance across all three major credit bureaus ( XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX ). Despite my loan balance being in deferment, the balance has increased from approximately {$46000.00} to {$48000.00}, indicating that interest was improperly applied during this period. This constitutes a direct violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ), which requires credit reporting agencies to maintain maximum possible accuracy in their reporting.

Violation of Federal Laws and Privacy Protections 1. Improper Accrual of Interest During Deferment My student loan has been in deferment, during which no interest should have accrued on a federally subsidized loan. 
The reported balance increase indicates a clear error, violating federal regulations governing student loan deferment. 
2. Failure to Notify of Deferment Ending or Interest Accrual I never received any written or electronic notification that my student loans would exit deferment or that interest would begin accruing.

This failure to notify is a violation of the Higher Education Act of 1965, which mandates proper borrower notification.

3. Unauthorized Disclosure and Mishandling of Personal Financial Information My personal financial information was compromised without my authorization, a direct violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ), 20 U.S.C. 1232g, 34 CFR Part 99. 
Additionally, the XXXX data breach exposed sensitive information of millions of consumers, including myself, further contributing to these inaccuracies. 

The CFPB has ongoing litigation against XXXX and XXXX for systemic failures in protecting consumer data, including inaccuracies in credit reporting and mishandling sensitive information. Given the scope of these violations and the continuing harm caused by XXXX XXXX data breach, I am formally requesting inclusion in any class-action lawsuit related to these violations. 

The XXXX data breach resulted in millions of consumers personally identifiable information ( PII ) being compromised, including mine. This breach not only exposed my data but also created ongoing risks of identity theft, unauthorized access, and inaccurate reporting of financial information, all of which are directly tied to the current inaccuracies in my credit report.

1. Permanent Removal of All Student Loan Accounts from My Credit Report Due to these documented violations, the continued reporting of my student loan balance constitutes furnishing inaccurate and unverifiable information, prohibited under 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ).

Under 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) ( A ), if this information can not be verified within five ( 5 ) business days, it must be permanently deleted.

2. Immediate Full Discharge and Cancellation of My Federal Student Loans Due to the unauthorized access, breach of security, and failure to properly notify me of my loan status, my loan agreement is legally void.

Violations of FERPA, Title IV of the Higher Education Act, and the Privacy Act of 1974 ( 5 U.S.C. 552a ) support the immediate discharge of this loan.

3. Recognition and Inclusion in Any Class-Action Lawsuit I formally request to be included as a claimant in any class-action lawsuit involving : The CFPBs ongoing case against XXXX and XXXX. 
The XXXX data breach settlement or any subsequent litigation regarding inaccurate credit reporting and mishandling of sensitive information. 

I am not requesting a fraud alert but have already secured my credit information by freezing my reports. Due to the urgency of this matter, I require a written response within five ( 5 ) business days detailing the corrective actions being taken.

Failure to comply will result in immediate escalation, including formal complaints with : The Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) for FCRA violations.

The U.S. Department of Educations Office for Civil Rights for FERPA violations.

The Florida Attorney General for failure to protect my rights under state and federal laws. 
Pursuing legal action against all responsible parties. 

Please provide all correspondence in writing to my address listed above. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative: I applied for an XXXX in XXXX. It was denied without notice, and without telling me why. I found out about this on XX/XX/XXXX and immediately applied again. However, since I was never told why my first application was denied, I didn't know if I needed to fix or change anything on my second application. After my first application, my loans were automatically put into processing forbearance. After my second application, they were not. I messaged to ask them to please put them into processing forbearance several times ( XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, and XX/XX/XXXX ), and only received generic and irrelevant messages in response. I'm also serving an XXXX term and am eligible for my loans to be in forbearance due to that. I was unable to request this on Mohela 's website because there is no option for it, despite a button that says " I'm in the military or public service - volunteer for a nonprofit, XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX, etc. '' When you click that button, it takes you to a page where the only option is military service. I was able to apply through XXXX, and it took them XXXX days to approve the request, but when they did they only approved it for XXXX of my loans. I want them ALL in forbearance. In the meantime, due to the processing pause on XXXX applications, their website had a notification that said, " If you have an IDR application that has not been processed within XXXX days and have an unpaid bill within XXXX days of the due date, MOHELA will automatically place a processing forbearance as directed by Federal Student Aid to your account. No action is required by you. '' This applies to me. So I was waiting for my loans to be put into forbearance but they never were. My bill was well over ten days past due, and still nothing. I paid the bill out of fear for my credit score, but this is completely unacceptable. If no action is required by me, why am I having to message them twice about it ( on XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX ) only for nothing to happen? I have sent them five messages total ( on XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, and XX/XX/XXXX ) about this whole fiasco, and have never had a helpful response, if I received one at all. The three responses I have gotten ( the dates of which I'm unsure of because they don't contain a timestamp, which at this point feels purposeful and malicious ) have been an obviously copy and pasted default answer in response to the words " XXXX '' or " forbearance '' and do not at all relate to my specific questions and situation. I've also tried calling, but have never been able to connect with a real person, just an unhelpful robot. I work full time and I don't have time to sit on hold for hours on end. I submitted a complaint to XXXX, who said they would respond within XXXX  days, but today is day XXXX and I have reached my limit of what I'm willing to deal with. This is the absolute worst company I have every had the displeasure of working with. Their customer service is non-existent, and they do not follow through with the claims they make on their website. The stakes here are very high, and they continue to drop the ball and they can not be trusted. I can no longer find the notification on their website about the XXXX application that hasn't been processed in XXXX days. It's been replaced with one that says " Borrows that have a pending IDR application may also be placed on a forbearance until no later than XX/XX/XXXX. '' So which one is it? They can not claim to be automatically putting loans into forbearance in one notification, and then say that it's only a possibility in another one. I'm glad I took a screen shot of the first notification, otherwise I wouldn't have any proof of this. I understand that this is a stressful and uncertain time for federal loans, but it is completely unacceptable to leave me in this situation.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am submitting this complaint regarding the credit reporting practices of Nelnet, my previous federal student loan servicer. My loans have since been transferred to a new servicer, XXXX and the accounts are currently in Administrative Forbearance, with no payments due until XX/XX/XXXX and all accounts paid up and in good standing. 

During my time with Nelnet, I did fall behind on payments in XX/XX/XXXX. However, I believe the resulting credit damage is severely disproportionate, and the transition was poorly communicated, creating confusion about my loan status and available options. 

First, Nelnet has a documented history of consumer complaints related to poor communication, lack of transparency during delinquency, and unclear servicing practices, especially during periods of account transition. In my case, I was not informed clearly or promptly that my loans were being transferred, nor was I provided consistent information about whether payments were still due or whether forbearance or deferment options were available. 

After the transfer to XXXX, the accounts were placed into Administrative Forbearance, and no payments are currently required. Despite this, my credit reports still reflect dozens of 90-day late payment entries reported by Nelnet, one for each individual loan, even though the loans are no longer delinquent and have not entered default. 

I believe this reporting violates the principles of fair and accurate credit reporting, and does not reflect the current status of the account. While the technical reporting may be accurate from Nelnets perspective, the outcome for me as a borrower is deeply harmful and inconsistent with the spirit of federal student loan policy, especially when my accounts are now current and in government-sanctioned forbearance. 

I have attached a screenshot from my loan servicer portal showing the Administrative Forbearance status and the fact that no payment is due. 

Thank you for your time and assistance.

In summary, as a full-time doctoral student for over XXXX year now at this university, I technically and legally meet every requirement in order to be given an in-school deferment through the length of my studies here in XXXX. The paperwork indicates that I am abiding by their requirements, and they are unlawfully withholding this and being entirely evasive and duplicitous.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing a formal complaint regarding a 90-day late payment reported on my credit file by Nelnet, my federal student loan servicer. This derogatory mark has caused a significant and distressing drop in my credit score. 

I want to clarify that I have already scheduled a payment to bring my account current, and I am prepared to pay the full balance in full if that would help resolve this issue. I have never been careless with my financesthis situation is deeply uncharacteristic of my history and values. 

During this period, my wife and I were dealing with the XXXX XXXX of our child on XX/XX/year>. I was working full-time while also acting as a primary caregiver to my wife and newborn. As a result, I was stretched thin physically, emotionally, and financially. 

Adding to the hardship, Nelnet 's communication during the federal student loan repayment restart was confusing and unclear. I did not receive timely, straightforward notice that my repayment had resumed or that my account was becoming delinquent. I only discovered the late mark after reviewing my credit report and immediately took action to fix it. 

We are currently in the process of preparing to buy our first home, and this single reporting event could cost us XXXX  of dollars in interest over the life of our loanor worse, disqualify us from favorable lending options. I am urgently asking for a goodwill adjustment to remove or reclassify the late payment due to the extraordinary and clearly documented personal hardship I was facing, compounded by poor communication from my servicer. 

I have always paid my financial obligations on time, and I would never knowingly jeopardize my credit standing. This mark is not a reflection of my character or intentit is a product of a system restart that was messy, unclear, and poorly communicated to borrowers like myself. 

I respectfully request the CFPB investigate this situation and help facilitate the removal or correction of this late payment so that I can continue building my financial future on stable footing.
