Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Legal Notice Concerning Nelnets Unlawful Collection Activity and Third-Party Status To Whom It May Concern, This memorandum is provided as a formal legal assertion that XXXX is operating as a third-party loan servicer and/or debt collector, and is thereby subject to full compliance with all applicable federal and state consumer protection laws, including the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), 15 U.S.C. 1692 et seq., the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq., and related statutes governing financial servicer. They are not excluded from any federal statutes I. XXXX XXXX of XXXX as a XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX although often referred to as a student loan servicer, is not the original creditor for most federal and private loans it services. When loans are originated by the Department of Education or a private lender and later transferred to XXXX, it becomes a third-party loan servicer a distinction with significant legal consequences. The legal classification of XXXX is not unlike that of a debt collector when it services or collects debts not originally extended by itself, per 15 U.S.C. 1692a ( 6 ). 

Further, any debt that has been sold or assigned to XXXX must be supported by an unbroken and legally verifiable chain of title, as established under UCC 9-406, UCC 3-301 , and relevant federal case law. Absent such legal documentation, XXXX lacks standing to collect or enforce the debt in question. 

XXXX. Legal Violations by XXXX Assuming the debt has been sold, XXXX, or otherwise extinguished, any attempt by XXXX to collect constitutes a series of violations under both federal and state laws, including but not limited to : A. Violation of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1692e False or Misleading Representations : If XXXX continues to collect on a debt that has been sold, settled, or legally discharged, and fails to disclose that it is no longer the creditor or servicer with authority, it engages in deceptive practices.

2. 15 U.S.C. 1692g Failure to Validate Debt : XXXX is legally obligated to validate the debt within five days of initial contact, including the name of the original creditor and a breakdown of the debt. Failure to comply invalidates the legitimacy of the collection.

3. 15 U.S.C. 1692f Unfair Collection Practices : Continuing to attempt collection without a valid, enforceable interest in the loan constitutes unfair and unconscionable conduct. 

B. Violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : If XXXX is reporting this debt to credit reporting agencies without the legal authority to do so, and after the debt has been transferred, discharged, or extinguished, it violates 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2, which prohibits the furnishing of inaccurate or outdated information to consumer reporting agencies.

C. Violation of State Consumer Protection Statutes : Most states ( e.g., Californias Rosenthal Fair Debt Collection Practices Act or New Yorks Debt Collection Procedures Law ) mirror or exceed FDCPA protections. XXXX must be in compliance with the relevant state-specific provisions, including licensure, consumer notice, and verification obligations. 

D. Lack of Legal Standing Under the UCC : Under Uniform Commercial Code 3-301, only a holder in due course may enforce a negotiable instrument. XXXX must prove it is legally entitled to enforce the debt, with documented assignment and authorization. The absence of such renders all collection efforts unenforceable as a matter of law. 



XXXX. Rejection of Feudal or Quasi-Governmental XXXX XXXX is a publicly traded private corporation, not a federal agency, and it does not enjoy sovereign authority or immunity. Although it may be contracted by the U.S. Department of Education, it is not a fiduciary arm of the government, and as such, it is fully subject to civil liability under FDCPA, FCRA, and other statutes. This precludes any claim of sovereign protection or implied enforcement authority. Its operations are commercial in nature, and governed accordingly by contract law, consumer protection laws, and commercial codes.

IV. Legal Demand for Immediate Erasure of Debt and Remedial Action Given that : The debt has been sold or otherwise transferred ; XXXX has not proven legal standing to enforce it ; The debt may have been discharged or forgiven ; Continued attempts to collect constitute violations of multiple federal and state statutes ; It is hereby demanded that all efforts to collect or report this debt cease immediately, and that the account be permanently removed from all consumer credit reports pursuant to 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ).

Failure to comply will result in formal complaints to the : Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) State Attorney Generals Office and may result in civil litigation
seeking injunctive relief, statutory damages, and attorneys fees under 15 U.S.C. 1692k.

Delete off report immediately
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
This is my formal complaint against Aidvantage and the U.S. Department of Education regarding their failure to validate an alleged federal student loan debt.

Despite multiple disputes and certified mailings, Aidvantage has failed to provide legally sufficient documentation. They submitted a generic master promissory note ( XXXX  ) with my name typed in, but no signature, no IP address, no e-signature audit trail, and no proof of borrower authentication or consent. This does not meet legal standards under the ESIGN Act, FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i, 1681e ( b ) ), or the Privacy Act ( 5 U.S.C. 552a ). 

The payment records they provided are corrupted many fields show # # # # # # # # or Unavailable. There is no complete loan accounting, no deferment documentation, and no evidence that I authorized interest capitalization or balance increases. 

Additionally, Aidvantage has submitted a transaction summary log that claims I signed the XXXX, but again, no actual signature, clickwrap agreement, IP address, or timestamp confirmation was included. They have not verified the debt, transfer of servicing rights, or my consent under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ).

I am attaching a rebuttal letter, the transaction log they provided, and a formal Notice of Intent to Sue. I am also filing complaints with the Office of Inspector General and the Department of Education. If this issue is not resolved immediately, I will proceed with a federal lawsuit for statutory and actual damages under the above laws.

Requested Resolution : - Immediate discharge of the loan due to lack of validation - Written confirmation that Aidvantage can not lawfully service this account- Cessation of all activity on this disputed account

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer

Consumer complaint narrative: The issue I have with repaying my loans is that there was major miscommunication regarding the pay back of my federal student loans. I XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXX/XX/XXXX. From there, I consolidated what I believed were my federal and private loans. Since the day I graduated, I have never missed a single payment on repaying my loans. XXXX weeks ago, I received an email from XXXX XXXX stating that my XXXX XXXX dropped. It is now in the XXXX range when it has been between XXXX my entire life. I checked why it dropped and it was because Nelnet reported missed student aid payments to my credit since XX/XX/XXXX. Meanwhile, I have never heard of Nelnet. I had to create an account with them to view what the issue was. From there, I saw there were were loans that were apparently not refinanced into my original account from XXXX years ago, which was very odd and shocking. I had no idea those loans even existed, nor was I ever told my loans were sold from Great Lakes to Nelnet. The email they somehow had on file was not an email address I use, so I never saw any of their email correspondences. They rarely called and if they did, it was a pre-recorded voicemail, not an actual person, whereupon they would ask for my social security number right away. The address they had on file was also not my address, so I never received any mail. My father cosigned on my loans and he was never contacted in any capacity from them. They also do not have my legal name on file. My legal name is XXXX XXXX XXXX. They somehow only had " XXXX XXXX '' in their system, despite me never having an account to begin with, which is alarming. I am extremely concerned about my credit score being as low as it is and when I spoke to someone on the phone to explain the situation and emphasized their lack of communication, they said there was nothing they could do that, despite the loans not even technically being in my name, which I have major issues with and am extremely confused by. Now, I am stuck with a terrible credit score and wondering what happened with this whole situation. First, I would like to know whether or not those loans are truly mine given that my legal name is not the name attached to those loans. This is causing me to question whether or not there was some sort of foul play here because I always use my legal name on official documents and legal matters. Second, I am wondering if Nelnet can contact the credit companies to take all these missed payments off my record due to their poor communication and if I am obligated to pay those loans, then I will make the payments.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing a formal complaint against Nelnet regarding improper interest accrual and mismanagement of my student loan account during and after my enrollment in the SAVE repayment plan.

Before consolidating my loans, I had a principal balance of {$260000.00} and {$20000.00} in accrued interest. That interest was capitalized and added to the principal during consolidation, raising my balance significantly. I was never clearly informed that this would occur.

During the lengthy processing period of my consolidation application, an additional {$5500.00} in interest accrued by the time I was placed in the SAVE program. I did not receive proper disclosure that interest would accumulate during this time. I called several times, and multiple representatives apologized for the misinformation. This is in the call logs. 

In XX/XX/year>, I submitted my IDR recertification. Shortly after, I received a letter from Nelnet stating that my loans would be placed in forbearance and would not accrue interest during this time. Despite this assurance, my interest has now ballooned to over {$9000.00}. This contradicts Nelnets written communication and represents a misrepresentation of loan servicing terms.

I have attempted to resolve this directly with Nelnet, but I continue to receive inconsistent responses, no clear accountability, and no correction of the errors.

Issue: Improper use of your report
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XX/XX/year> To : U.S. Department of Education Student Privacy Policy Office XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX CC : [ Name & Address of Credit Bureaus XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX ] Subject : Formal Complaint Regarding Data Breach, FERPA and Title IV Violations, and Request for Immediate Discharge of Student Loans To Whom It May Concern I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding the unauthorized access and breach of my educational records, financial aid data, and IRS tax information by the U.S. Department of Education ( DOE ) and the Department of Government Efficiency ( DOGE ). This breach constitutes a direct violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and Title IV regulations, as well as an egregious violation of my personal privacy and financial security. 
I recently discovered that my sensitive and legally protected records were accessed and potentially shared without my consent. This includes but is not limited to : 1.My academic records and personally identifiable information ( PII ). 
2.My Free Application for Federal Student Aid ( FAFSA ) data, including financial aid history and loan information. 
3.My IRS tax transcripts, which were obtained and used without proper authorization. 
These actions violate my rights under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), which grants me the right to control access to my educational records, as well as Title IV of the Higher Education Act, which governs the use and protection of federal student aid information. Furthermore, unauthorized access to my IRS tax data raises serious concerns regarding potential identity theft, fraud, and violations of federal data security standards. 
Given the severity of this breach and the direct impact on my financial security and privacy, I demand the following corrective actions : 1.Immediate discharge and cancellation of all my federal student loans due to the breach of my financial aid and tax records, which invalidates the integrity of my loan agreements. 
2.A formal investigation into this data breach, including details on how my records were accessed, who accessed them, and for what purpose. 
3.A full report on the extent of my data exposure and the corrective measures being implemented to prevent future violations. 
4.Immediate notification to all major credit bureaus ( XXXX XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX place a fraud alert and investigate any unauthorized activity that may have resulted from this breach. 
This breach has caused significant distress and concern regarding the security of my personal and financial data. If my demands are not met within XXXX  days, I will be left with no choice but to escalate this matter through legal channels, including filing complaints with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), and pursuing legal action against the responsible parties. 
I request a written response addressing these concerns and outlining the immediate actions being taken to remedy this situation. Please direct all correspondence to the address listed above. 
Thank you for your prompt attention to this urgent matter. I look forward to your immediate response and resolution. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX, XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I have XXXX XXXX  that are in the process of being discharged due to misconduct by my school. This process is called borrowers defense, and applies to my loans from the XXXX XXXX. I have attached the emails regarding notification of this matter. According to the Department of Education and Nelnet, this process can take many years. In addition, there is no where I can go as the borrower to see the progress or status of this process. During this process, there should be no negative consequences or impact on me as the borrower. Part of the process for the discharge is a refund of all payments made towards the loans. Due to multiple changes in servicers over the years and the fact that my loans were consolidated, there was very little information available about the specifics of these loans from the very beginning of the process. I previously asked Nelnet in late XXXX for a record of all payments and loans- and I was told at that time that the information was unavailable due to the processing of the borrowers defense case. They did inform me that I would be getting a refund of approximately {$600.00}, which is the full amount they said I paid on these loans in over 10 years. I had serious doubts about that amount, but had XXXX recourse to prove otherwise. They informed me that the payment would be coming from the XXXX Treasury and provided instructions on how to sign up for direct deposit through the IRS website. I enrolled in direct deposit, and on XX/XX/XXXX, I received a deposit in the amount of {$690.00} from the XXXX Treasury. Due to not expecting any other payment, I contacted Nelnet and they confirmed that this is the refund for my borrowers defense case. They informed me that the Department of Education would be sending correspondence to confirm this, but nothing was received. I had spent another few hours at this point between calling Nelnet and the Department of Education, and I let it all go assuming itd all be made clear when the process was complete. 

I enrolled in school for the winter of XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX ) with no issues, and all loans were put into a forbearance status due to being a XXXX XXXX XXXX. I was eligible for financial aid at this point. I took the next semester off, and began the process to enroll for XXXX XXXX. I am going to a different school, so I had to login to update my XXXX form at the beginning of XX/XX/XXXX. Upon logging into the Department of Education, there was a bold warning about my loans being in default. I immediately contacted the Department of Education - because my loans are absolutely not in default and even if they were, there is absolutely no way they could go from good standing in XX/XX/XXXX to default in XX/XX/XXXX due to the amount of time needed to get into a default status. The Department of Education informed me that Nelnet, as the servicer, of these loans is solely responsible for updating loan status. I was told to contact Nelnet. Upping logging into the Nelnet website, there is no information about any late payments, default status or record of the defaulted loans. They are not even reported on my loan history. I called Nelnet, and I was informed that the process of refunding payments during a loan discharge can put the loan into a erroneous status of default. They informed me that there was nothing they could do about this, and I had to wait for the borrowers defense case to be resolved and all information would be updated and made right at that time. I requested a supervisor, who reiterated that there was nothing they could do and that this was just part of the process. I informed them that due to being in a default status, I can not return to school and obtain XXXX XXXX, and there are serious consequences to my credit report. In addition, when the government returns to wage garnishments in XX/XX/XXXX, my wages will be garnished for a defaulted loan that I dont owe. Nelnet again told me they had no solution, and that I just had to wait. They were unable to provide any specific timeline, but did inform me that it will likely be a year or more before any update is made to my account. They informed me that this is because the Department of Education controls all processing and they generally take 3-5 years in total for a borrowers defense case. 

I filed a complaint with the XXXX Department of Education to attempt to resolve this matter in early XX/XX/XXXX, however there has been no resolution to date. I have attached records of my Nelnet account, Department of Education account, deposit of refund, and original emails informing me of approval of my borrowers defense case. There is no other correspondence available by either entity, nor any other correspondence sent to me.

2. Failure to Verify Legitimacy of Debt The loan servicer has failed to provide evidence of legal ownership, collection rights, or servicing obligations in light of the agencys abolishment.

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute my federal student loans and request a full discharge due to a serious breach of my personal and financial information. My information was compromised without my authorization, which violates multiple federal laws designed to protect student records and personal privacy. Under these circumstances, I request the immediate cancellation and discharge of my student loan debt in full, as my rights have been severely violated. Below are the key reasons for my request ; Violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) ; My student records were disclosed without my consent, violating FERPA 's strict confidentiality protections.

Breach of the Privacy Act of 1974 ; My personal and financial information was improperly accessed and shared without my authorization'ating my privacy riahts under federai law. Violation of the Higher Education Act ; As a student loan borrower, my information should have been protected, but the mishandling of my data demonstrates a failure to uphold these legal protections. Breech of contract and negligence the entity responsible for safeguarding my data failed to do so putting my financial security at risk and unauthorized disclosure to third parties.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
To whom it may concern : I am writing to file a complaint in regards to Treasury Department and the Office of Personnel Management accessing my PII, or Personally Identifiable Information, and/or SPII, Sensitive Personally Identifiable Information. As per the Handbook for Safeguarding Sensitive PII : " In its mission to secure the Homeland, the Department of Homeland Security ( DHS ) collects personal information, also known as Personally Identifiable Information ( PII ), from U.S. citizens, Lawful Permanent Residents ( LPR ), visitors to the U.S., and employees or contractors to the Department. As an employee, contractor, appointee, detailee, intern, or consultant ( hereafter referred to as DHS staff ), you are obligated by law and by DHS policy to protect PII to prevent identity theft or other adverse consequences, such as a privacy incident, compromise, or misuse of data. '' I am concerned that my information will be not only compromised, copied for malicious use, and altered. The origination dates for my loans were already changed when they were sold to a different servicers over different years. I have lost status when a servicers I was transferred to without my control or consent lost federal accreditation status is what I was told. I am tired of people accessing my loans and changing things without my consent, my permission, and then expecting to just accept it and just keep paying what they tell me to and how they tell me too. I always have to deal with the fall out. Why do we have the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection. Why do we have thy Fair credit reporting act? I have including the following : FCRA section 604 ( f ) provides that a person shall not use or obtain a consumer report for any purpose unless the consumer report is obtained for a purpose for which the consumer report is authorized to be furnished under [ FCRA section 604 ] and the purpose is certified in accordance with FCRA section 607 by a prospective user of the report through a general or specific certification. [ 12 ] FCRA section 619 imposes criminal liability on any person who knowingly and willfully obtains information on a consumer from a consumer reporting agency under false pretenses. [ 13 ] Also section Section 604 ( a ) ( 3 ) states : XXXX XXXX interprets the permissible purposes in FCRA section 604 ( a ) ( 3 ) to apply only with respect to the consumer who is the subject of the user 's request.

XXXX XXXX XXXX interpretation is based on the plain language of FCRA section 604 ( a ) ( 3 ) itself, which makes clear that whether a user has a permissible purpose under that section is analyzed on a consumer-by-consumer basis. For example, FCRA section 604 ( a ) ( 3 ) ( A ) permits a consumer reporting company to provide a consumer report to a person which it has reason to believe... intends to use the information in connection with a credit transaction involving the consumeron whom the information is to be furnished and involving the extension of credit to, or review or collection of an account of, the consumer. [ 19 ] Similarly, FCRA section 604 ( a ) ( 3 ) ( F ) permits a consumer reporting company to provide a consumer report to a person which it has reason to believe... has a legitimate business need for the information... in connection with a business transaction that is initiated by the consumer or to review an account to determine whether the consumer continues to meet the terms of the account. [ 20 ] Thank you, XXXX XXXX

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative: My loan was placed in deferment for the month of XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX. On XX/XX/XXXX I received an email from Nelnet stating I had a payment due of XXXX that payment would be due on XX/XX/XXXX. On XX/XX/XXXX I logged into Nelnet and I reviewed my dashboard it States that I now have a payment of XXXX due on XX/XX/XXXX which was more then what was listed on the bill. On XX/XX/XXXX I make a payment of XXXX and receive a confirmation email stating the payment was received and will reflect on my account on XX/XX/XXXX and processing can take up to XXXX. On XX/XX/XXXX I log back into nelnet to ensure payment processed. Under my dashboard it states I still owe XXXX however a payment was received on XX/XX/XXXX in the amount of XXXX. On XX/XX/XXXX I receive an email from nelnet stating XXXX monthly payment of XXXX was due on XXXX XXXX. At this time I was unable to contact nelnet because they were closed. On XXXX XXXX I contact nelnet at XXXX eastern time to discuss the matter. At this time I explained to the advisor the same thing I explained above. She stated the bank returned payment. I asked why I was not informed of the matter prior to this phone call on XX/XX/XXXX. She states shes not sure but I would be able to make a payment now to ensure my account is in good standings. At this time I did make a payment and I did receive another confirmation email stating that the payment effective date would be XX/XX/XXXX and would not reflect on my account as past due. Today I open up the nelnet app to ensure everything is going accordingly and I notice that my new payment states that I owe XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX and that there is a late payment of XXXX. I called nelnet again to speak about the matter.. I was told dont worry about it it wont reflect on your credit report unless its 90 days past due at this time it is only one day past due again I made the payment and i spoke with an advisor who also stated my payment would not reflect a late payment as the effective date would be the due date and I had nothing to worry about. It is obvious that they are into late reporting and it need to be addressed as Im sure I am not the only person going through false reporting at this time.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear CFPB, I am submitting this complaint regarding EdFinancial 's misrepresentation and mishandling of my student loan, which has resulted in financial hardship and damage to my credit. 

Key Issues : Misrepresentation of Refund Impact on Loan Forgiveness : In XX/XX/XXXX, EdFinancial explicitly told me I could request a refund of payments made during the COVID-19 forbearance period without affecting my eligibility for student loan forgiveness.

Relying on this, I requested and received a refund of {$14000.00} in XX/XX/XXXX. 

I had already fully paid off my loan in XXXX, believing my financial obligations were settled. 

I was never informed that accepting the refund would reinstate my loan balance or accrue additional interest.

Unfair and Deceptive Practices : Despite being assured my loan forgiveness eligibility was unaffected, my balance was reinstated, now totaling {$15000.00} with added interest.

Had I been properly informed of the consequences, I would not have proceeded with the refund.

Mishandling and Lack of Transparency : EdFinancial claimed my loan records from XXXX were lost due to a server overhaul. 

For years, I sought clarification but was ignored. Only after I escalated my complaint to CFPB and provided bank records did EdFinancial acknowledge the issue that lead to an unsatisfactory result.

Financial & Credit Damage : The reinstated balance and
accumulated interest have caused a significant financial burden and negatively impacted my credit score.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
I was a full-time student with my federal loans in deferment, serviced by Edfinancial. I recently discovered that my Direct Unsubsidized Loans had accrued over {$4000.00} in interest during that periodwithout a single statement, alert, or proactive communication informing me that this was happening. 

I understand that unsubsidized loans accrue interest during deferment. However, I believe it was negligent for Edfinancial to allow years of interest to build up without providing any regular account updates or balance change notifications. Other types of lenders ( credit card, auto loan, mortgage ) are required to issue statements regardless of payment due, and student loan servicers should be held to the same basic transparency standards. 

Had I been notified, I would have made interest-only payments and avoided thousands in added debt. Instead, I was left unaware until after the interest had accrued significantly. This lack of communication caused real financial harm, and I believe it reflects a broader issue in student loan servicing that deserves regulatory attention. 

I am requesting that Edfinancial provide me with a full interest accrual timeline and an explanation for their lack of notification, and that the CFPB investigate whether this practice violates any borrower protection standards.

Issue: Problem with fraud alerts or security freezes
Sub-issue: None
Consumer complaint narrative:
Im filing this complaint against XXXX due to severe and unjustified negative credit reporting that has significantly impacted my financial standing. My credit report was recently updated to reflect over 20 late payment entries from DEPT OF ED/ XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX VA XXXX which has caused my credit score to drop by over XXXX points. This action was taken without any prior notice, warning, or correspondenceI did not receive any emails, letters, or alerts informing me of this drastic change before it was reported to the credit bureaus.

Additionally, I have become aware of an ongoing data breach involving student loan accounts, which raises serious concerns regarding unauthorized access to my personal and financial information raising concerns over a FERPA violation. Given this security lapse, I have reason to believe that my account records may have been compromised or altered without my consent.

I am in the process of purchasing a home and this has caused my loan to be halted until this is remedied. This has caused extreme financial distress and this error in reporting needs to be remedied immediately. I did not authorize any changes to my account status, and I no longer feel comfortable having my student loans serviced and reported to the credit bureaus under these conditions.

Violations and Consumer Protection Rights 1. Failure to Provide Notice of Negative Credit Reporting - Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), loan servicers are required to provide accurate and fair reporting. I was not notified in advance that these accounts would be marked late, which denied me the opportunity to address any potential issues before they were reported.

2. Possible Unauthorized Reporting and Account Compromise Due to Data Breach - The reported
data breach involving XXXX raises serious questions about the integrity of my loan accounts. If my data was exposed or manipulated, XXXX may have incorrectly or fraudulently reported late payments that I did not actually incur.

3. Failure to Properly Investigate and Verify Account Status - Given the security risks and errors in reporting, I request full verification and documentation proving the legitimacy of the late payments, including a detailed account history showing how and when they were marked late.

Requested Resolution - Immediate removal of all reported late payments from my credit report, as they were reported without proper notice and under potentially compromised circumstances.

- A formal investigation into reporting of DEPT OF ED/ XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX VA XXXX practices to determine whether my data was mishandled or compromised. 

- A written response from DEPT OF ED/ XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX VA XXXX confirming the deletion of these late payments from my credit file. This situation has caused me extreme distress, financial harm, and damage to my creditworthiness.

- I expect a prompt and thorough resolution in compliance with federal consumer protection laws.

Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter. 

XXXX XXXX Social Security number is XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Pennsylvania XXXX XXXX XXXX

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have been trying to resolve this issue for nearly two and a half years now. Despite assurances that my claim would be reviewed and I would be contacted, neither happens unless I follow up. I am now calling every month or two to follow upwhile my loan accrues interest on money I dont actually owe. Each time I call, and the last two times was with a supervisor, I am told that they will contact me as soon as they know more. Despite my account now being labeled as an emergency, they still have not called me back. 
It wasnt until I persisted in following up on my concerns that they finally searched their records and found nearly {$2000.00} worth of unrecorded payments that were not applied to my loan balance. I did receive one email from them a few months ago acknowledging that they " found '' roughly {$1500.00} of the payments I made -- without apology or repaying me for interest I didn't owe. I have repeatedly asked them to address this as well and with the same results -- no response. 
Throughout this time, EdFinancial has repeatedly stated that I owe them money and that my account is " delinquent. '' This is verifiably wrong and representatives know this. They have told me to ignore these emails, but this seems absurd. How am I supposed to know when the company is sending me inaccurate information and when to believe them? This company seems to be in the business of making money off of its customers while giving them the runaround, if not outright stealing from them via disappearing payments.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative:
NOTICE This Complaint Is Not a Duplicate : Any Attempt to Misclassify It Constitutes Procedural Misrepresentation and Regulatory Misconduct ========================================================================= This complaint is not a duplicate of any prior submission, including but not limited to CFPB Complaint ID XXXX. It documents a new, independently reportable violationspecifically, Aidvantages continued misrepresentation of a prior CFPB complaint filed against XXXX ( ID XXXX ) as the basis for its internal fraud classification, as well as its stated policy of collapsing multiple complaints into a single response record. 
========================================================================= Any attempt by Aidvantage to mischaracterize this complaint as previously addressed or duplicative will be treated as a fraudulent procedural act and a misuse of the federal consumer complaint system, in violation of : 12 U.S.C. 5536 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ) Prohibition on deceptive and abusive acts or practices ( UDAAP ) ; 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ) Furnishers duty to correct and update inaccurate information ; D.C. Code 28-3904 ( e ), ( f ) Misrepresentation and failure to honor consumer rights under the D.C. Consumer Protection Procedures Act ; 18 U.S.C. 1001 Material false statements to a federal agency or in a matter within federal jurisdiction. 
========================================================================= This complaint arises from a new, post-dated violation that took place after prior complaints were filed. It involves a materially false assertion made by Aidvantage in its XX/XX/2025 response, falsely linking a separate CFPB complaint ( filed against XXXX ) to its internal servicing records, and reaffirming a pattern of improper fraud designation and procedural concealment. 
========================================================================= Furthermore, Aidvantages stated policy of responding to multiple complaints under one CFPB complaint number constitutes an attempt to suppress individualized complaint visibility, obstruct the official regulatory record, and evade accountability for ongoing and distinct legal violations. 
========================================================================= Any further attempt by Aidvantage to mislabel this submission as duplicative or to suppress its factual and legal claims through internal aggregation policies will be preserved as evidence of regulatory misconduct and will be escalated as warranted. 
========================================================================= NOTICE : Aidvantages continued misuse of the CFPBs complaint designation system to obscure procedural violations is being independently tracked as part of an active evidentiary dossier for potential regulatory enforcement and civil litigation, if warranted. 
========================================================================= Subject : Systemic Misrepresentation by Aidvantage False Identity Theft Designation, Unauthorized Use of CFPB Complaint Record, and Violation of Federal Furnisher Obligations ========================================================================= To : Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, FTC ========================================================================= CC : Aidvantage Credit Bureau Management ========================================================================= Date : XX/XX/2025 ========================================================================= Complainant : XXXX XXXX XXXX ========================================================================= Complaint ID Referenced ( for background ) : ========================================================================= XXXX ========================================================================= XXXX ========================================================================= XXXX ========================================================================= XXXX ========================================================================= Affirmation of Independent Legal Action and Federal Record Accuracy ========================================================================= I submit this complaint in my individual legal capacity and affirm that I am not affiliated with any credit repair organization. This submission documents federal loan servicing misconduct and preserves all rights for civil, regulatory, and evidentiary enforcement. Aidvantage is formally on notice. 
========================================================================= I. Unauthorized Identity Theft Designation of Federal Loan Account ========================================================================= Aidvantage unilaterally designated one or more of my federal student loan accounts as involving identity theft without my authorization, without law enforcement documentation, and without any identity theft report submitted by me. 
========================================================================= This act constitutes : ========================================================================= A material misrepresentation of the status of a federal student loan, ========================================================================= A falsification of servicing records, ========================================================================= A violation of FCRA 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ) and 12 U.S.C. 5536 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ) ( UDAAP ). 
========================================================================= I have submitted a notarized affidavit and two FTC Fraud Reports affirming no identity theft was reported. Aidvantage proceeded with a fraud designation despite this documentation. 
========================================================================= XXXX. Misuse of CFPB Complaint System to Justify Internal Fraud Protocol ========================================================================= In its XX/XX/2025 response, Aidvantage cited CFPB Complaint ID XXXX was filed against XXXX the basis for initiating a fraud classification on my federal loan. 
========================================================================= This claim is demonstrably false. 
========================================================================= The referenced complaint does not mention identity theft, was not submitted against Aidvantage, and was never intended as a fraud-related dispute. Aidvantages use of this record to trigger internal fraud protocols constitutes a misrepresentation in a federal proceeding and may violate : ========================================================================= 18 U.S.C. 1001 False statements to a federal agency, ========================================================================= 12 U.S.C. 5536 ( a ) ( 2 ) Misrepresentation to a consumer or regulator, ========================================================================= FCRA 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ) Furnisher duty to correct inaccurate information. 
========================================================================= III. Transmission or Attempted Transmission of False Identity Theft Information ========================================================================= Aidvantage has either transmitted or attempted to transmit this false identity theft classification to one or more consumer reporting agencies through E-Oscar or equivalent systems. 
========================================================================= This conduct violates : ========================================================================= FCRA 1681e ( b ) Failure to ensure maximum possible accuracy, ========================================================================= 12 C.F.R. 1022.42 Accuracy and Integrity Rule under FACTA, ========================================================================= CFPB Bulletin 2014-01 Prohibition on furnishing misleading or false information. 
XXXX Aidvantage has not produced documentation identifying the system or person responsible for triggering the fraud classification despite multiple formal requests. 
========================================================================= IV. Procedural Suppression of the Official Regulatory Record ========================================================================= Aidvantages statement that multiple complaints regarding the same concerns will be responded to under one CFPB complaint number reflects a policy of collapsing distinct complaints to limit regulatory exposure. 
========================================================================= This tactic obstructs the integrity of the Bureaus public complaint system. Each complaint filed documents new dates, new legal violations, and escalating conduct. Collapsing separate records may violate : ========================================================================= 12 U.S.C. 5495 CFPB coordination and supervisory authority requirements. 
========================================================================= This behavior appears designed to evade systemic accountability for recurring violations. 
========================================================================= V. Enforcement Referral and Legal Preservation ========================================================================= Pursuant to the Bureaus statutory mandate under 12 U.S.C. 5495 ( Coordination ), I formally request that this matter be referred for supervisory and enforcement review, and that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau coordinate with relevant federal and state agencies to ensure proper oversight, investigation, and legal remedy. 
========================================================================= The following agency referrals are warranted based on distinct legal authorities, each directly implicated by Aidvantages conduct : ========================================================================= 1. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) Enforcement Division ========================================================================= Aidvantages actions violate core provisions of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, including : ========================================================================= o 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ) : Duty of furnishers to correct and update inaccurate information.

========================================================================= o 15 U.S.C. 1681i : Failure to conduct a reasonable reinvestigation upon notice of dispute.

========================================================================= o 12 U.S.C. 5536 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ) : Prohibition on deceptive or abusive acts or practices under the Consumer Financial Protection Act ( UDAAP ).

========================================================================= These violations fall squarely within the CFPBs enforcement jurisdiction and implicate the agencys role in overseeing the accuracy and integrity of the credit reporting system.

========================================================================= 2. Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) ========================================================================= Aidvantages repeated misrepresentations to both consumer and regulatorparticularly its misuse of an unrelated CFPB complaint to justify a false fraud designationviolate the Federal Trade Commission Act, specifically : ========================================================================= o 15 U.S.C. 45 ( a ) : Prohibition on unfair or deceptive acts or practices in or affecting commerce. 
========================================================================= The FTC retains parallel jurisdiction over non-bank servicers and deceptive consumer-facing practices, and is positioned to investigate systemic misrepresentation or pattern violations. 
========================================================================= 3. Department of Justice ( DOJ ) Civil Division, Consumer Protection Branch ========================================================================= Aidvantages conduct may constitute federal offenses under : ========================================================================= a. 18 U.S.C. 1001 : False statements in matters within the jurisdiction of a federal agency.

========================================================================= b. 18 U.S.C. 1341 : Mail fraud, based on the use of USPS to transmit materially false information.

========================================================================= c. 18 U.S.C. 1343 : Wire fraud, where electronic systems ( including CFPB portal and E-Oscar transmissions ) were used to perpetuate misrepresentations. 

========================================================================= DOJ is authorized to initiate both civil and criminal proceedings where false statements or fraudulent schemes affect federal records or regulatory systems. 
========================================================================= 4. National Association of Attorneys General ( NAAG ) ========================================================================= Aidvantages conduct may violate multiple state-level consumer protection laws, including : ========================================================================= d. D.C. Consumer Protection Procedures Act ( CPPA ), D.C. Code 28-3904 ( e ), ( f ) : Prohibiting misrepresentation and omission of material facts in connection with consumer services. 

========================================================================= Given the multistate and federally regulated nature of the loan, a NAAG-coordinated review is appropriate under 5495s requirement for intergovernmental coordination to prevent regulatory evasion. 


========================================================================= All factual assertions, sworn affidavits, and certified documents are preserved in accordance with the Federal Rules of Evidence 902 and 1005. No further burden-shifting, misclassification, or procedural obfuscation by Aidvantage will be accepted. This matter now requires cross-agency supervisory action. 
========================================================================= Submitted by : XXXX XXXX XXXX
